nodes.works as: 1808-1810: conservateur de tableaux or 'Artistic inspector' for Joseph I: Administration générale du mobilier de la Couronne (or Administración general del Real Menage). He had a key role in the planning of the Museo Josefino, to be installed at the Palacio de Buenavista. He is dismissed by Joseph I on 21 July 1810 due to doubts regarding his honesty. He contributed to the looting of the Spanish royal collections during the Peninsular War

nodes.label: G.D. Tiepolo
nodes.lives in: Venice; Würzburg, Baviera (1751-53); Madrid (1762-70): assisted his father in the decoration of the Royal Palace
nodes.parents: Giambattista Tiepolo and Maria Cecilia Guardi
nodes.collector of Goya's works: at the time of his death in Venice in 1804, he owned proofs of most of Goya's etchings executed bfore that date, including a set of the Caprichos (Harris 1964, vol.I, p.7)
nodes.link to Goya's work: Goya's early prints such as Saint Francis of Paola (c.1776-78) were clearly influenced by G.D. Tiepolo's series of Raccolta di Teste (c.1757-70) (McDonald, 2012, p.236).
nodes.sales: Paris, 10-12 November 1845: Goya works lots 76-81, including a 1st-edition set of the Caprichos, Blind guitarist on the horns of a bull and plates after Velázquez (see Harris 1964, vol.I, p.13; Wilson Bareau 2016, p.38, note 22). The catalogue was distributed by the print dealer Pierre Defer, who was in contact with Carderera from 1841, with whom he 'talked about Goya' in 1855 (Lanzarote Guiral 2016, p.314)
author of: Paintings: The Minuet or Carnival Scene, 1754-55, Louvre; The Minuet, 1756, MNAC; The Tiepolo Family, private collection (unfinished); Patron Saints of thee Crotta Family, 1750, Städel Museum; Christ and the Woman Taken in Adultery, 1752, LACMA; The Charlatan (The Tooth-Puller), 1754-55, Louvre; The Triumph of Pulcinella, 1760-70, Statens Museum for Kunst (Copenhagen); El mundo nuevo, c.1765, Prado; The Immaculate Conception with Saint Lawrence and Saint Francis of Padua, 1770s, Strasbourg; Pulcinella in love, 1793, Ca' Rezzonico; The swing of the polichinelles, 1793, Ca' Rezzonico
Prints: Picturesque Scenes from the Flight into Egypt, 1750, etchings

nodes.author of: Iconografía espan̂ola: Colección de retratos, estatuas, mausoleos y demás monumentos (...), in Spanish and French, 1855-1864
mentions of Goya: 1835 El Artista 2, 'Biografía de D. Francisco Goya, pintor', 253-55: 'La nueva escuela romántica de los pintores franceses ha puesto en evidencia el mérito de nuestro artista, y en bastantes cuadros pequeños y en muchísimas litografías y aguas fuertes que adornan las ediciones de Victor Hugo y otros célebres contemporáneos, se ve el deseo de imitar a Goya, y se columbran los originales y románticos duendecitos esparcidos en sus ochenta caprichos' (p.255) (Fayos Pérez 2024, p.325). With a lithography by Federico Madrazo (Vicente López's portrait of Goya).

1838-VII-15 Semanario Pintoresco español 120, 631-33: 'Los aficionados estrangeros tiempo ha las buscan [Caprichos] con mas pasion que los nuestros, y hoy vemos reproducidos y transformados sus duendecitos y alguaciles en los grabados y litografiados que nos vienen de allende sin pretensión de ocultar el plagio' (p.633) (Fayos Pérez 2024, p.328)

1860-VIII-15 Gazette des Beaux-Arts 7, 'François Goya: sa vie, ses dessins et ses eaux-fortes', 215-27, translated and annotated by Philippe Burty, with a preface by Charles Blanc and a print by Bracquemond. It includes a short biography of Goya and an account of his drawings. Carderera claims ownership of 2 sheets from Album A, 112 preparatory drawings of the Caprichos, 50 of Tauromaquia and 72 of Disasters of War (Fayos Pérez 2024, p.347). [Gallica](https://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k2030710/f231.item#)

1863-VII-1 Gazette des Beaux-Arts 15, 'François Goya', 237-49. It focuses on the advertisement of the Caprichos in the Diario de Madrid (6 Feb 1799). It includes Jacquemart's 'Spanish scene', based on Goya. Also mentions the Prado commentaries. It quotes Théophile Gautier's essay on the Disasters of War (Voyage en Espagne, 1845, p.136). He mixes up the Disparates with the drawing series Sueños ('Les proverbes ou rêves', p.244) (Fayos Pérez 2024, p.350). [Gallica](https://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k2030791/f257.item#)
nodes.collector of Goya's works: Carderera gathered a large part of Goya's prints and drawings, acquired from Javier and Mariano Goya, and Ceán Bermúdez. He possessed at one time some 400 of Goya's drawings, 272 of which were acquired by the Prado in 1886, as well as the engraved work. His collection also included rare working proofs from the collection of Ceán Bermúdez, now at the BNE (acquired from Carderera in 1867 and from his descendants), as well as the famous proofs from the Stirling-Maxwell collection, now at the Boston Museum (Harris 1964, vol.I, p.11)
nodes.bibliography: Fayos Pérez 2020; Lanzarote Guiral 2016; Harris 1964

nodes.label: Taylor
nodes.profession: politician, artist, playwright, philanthropist, military member
in Spain: 1st trip in 1820
1823 [Cien Mil hijos de S. Luis]
in 1832 (with Dauzats)
July 1833 (with Dauzats): introduced to José Madrazo by Blanchard, portrayed by Madrazo

1835-36 commissioned by Louis-Philippe to acquire paintings for Galerie espagnole (assisted by Dauzats and Blanchard, and benefited by active help and advice from the Madrazo family and Carderera [Lanzarote Guiral 2016 p.574]): 1836 Feb-Aug (8 paintings attributed to Goya from Javier Goya)
nodes.worked for: Charles X; Louis-Philippe: acquiring Spanish paintings for the Galerie espagnole (1838-48)
works as: Administrateur général de la Comédie-Française (1825-30, 1831-38): he stages Alexandre Dumas's 'Henri III et sa cour', and Hugo's 'Hernani' and 'Marion Delorme'.

Commissaire du roi (Charles X) auprès du Pacha d'Égypte (1830): commissioned with gathering Egyptian antiquities for the Louvre (with a credit of 100.000 fr.). He brings the Luxor obelisk to Paris (Place de la Concorde since 1836).
Inspecteur général des Beaux-Arts (1835): Galerie espagnole.
nodes.author of: Voyage pittoresque en Espagne, en Portugal et sur la côte d’Afrique, de Tanger a Tétuan (1826); Voyages pittoresques et romantiques dans l'ancienne France, in collaboration with Charles Nodier and Alphonse de Cailleux (started in 1818; published 1820-1878)

Nadar: 1877, photograph; 1872-75, [MoMA](https://www.moma.org/collection/works/44376) 35.1964; caricatures: (<i>Portrait charge du baron Taylor), [Louvre](https://collections.louvre.fr/en/ark:/53355/cl020503287) RF 43361, Recto, and another one, charcoal heightened with gouache, 23.5 x 15 cm, [Artnet](https://www.artnet.com/artists/nadar/isidore-justin-s%C3%A9verin-baron-taylor-2vDIG4UNfoRw8E-JsSPruQ2)

1868 commissioned by Madame Aldema with four illustrations of characters from the Arabian folktale One Thousand and One Nights. He died before being able to finish and there was a lawsuit.

nodes.label: Ochoa
in Paris: 1828-1834 at the École d'Arts et d'Offices. He meets Moratín and Godoy
1837-1844: works for editors Baudry & Rosa. In contact with circle of politicians around the exiled Queen María Cristina
1855: visits Exposition Universelle
author of: Translations of French Romantic works: Victor Hugo's Hernani (watched by Théophile Gautier in 1840 in Valladolid); George Sand; Honoré de Balzac; Jules Janin; Jules Sandeau; Alexandre Dumas; Frédéric Soulié
Translations from English: David Hume (Historia de Inglaterra; Walter Scott

1844 Catálogo razonado de los manuscritos españoles existentes en la Biblioteca Real de París: seguido de un suplemento que contiene los de las otras tres bibliotecas públicas (Arsenal, Ste Geneviève and Mazarine), París, Imprenta Real

1861 París, Londres y Madrid: he mentions Dumas, Balzac, Gautier, Delacroix, Dauzats, Nodier, Lamartine, Ingres, Vernet, Decamps, Delaroche, Eugène Sue, Feuillet, Houssaye and others. He does not mention Goya, Taylor, Javier Goya or Mariano Goya. HathiTrust [https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=hvd.32044014808356&seq=203&q1=Sand]
editor of: El Artista (1835) con Federico Madrazo: spreads Romanticism in Spain and imitates the French journal L'Artiste
Horas de invierno (1836-37): volume of short stories by famous European writers such as Hoffmann

In Paris: Colección de los mejores autores españoles; Catálogo razonado de los manuscrito españoles existentes en la Biblioteca Real de París (1844); Revista Encilopédica de la Civilización Europea (1843), with Patricio de la Escosura
nodes.works for: Baudry & Rosa, Paris 1837: volumes of Spanish literature and translations; Colección de los mejores autores españoles; Catálogo razonado de los manuscrito españoles existentes en la Biblioteca Real de París (Paris, 1844)
nodes.works as: editor; librarian (bibliotecario segundo de la Biblioteca Nacional); politician (jefe político de Huesca; diputado); Administrator of the Imprenta Nacional; Director General de Instrucción Pública
nodes.bibliography: Raquel Sánchez, 'Busto de Eugenio Ochoa por Ponciano Ponzano (Pieza del trimestre julio-septiembre 2018)', Ministerio de Cultura; Romero Tobar 1997; Ochoa 1861
nodes.member of: Real Academia Española: honorary member, then miembro titular in 1847 (for the letter 'H')

nodes.label: S. Masarnau
nodes.founder of: Colegio de Massarnau (with his brother Vicente, in 1841, Madrid).
nodes.parents: Santiago de Masarnau y Torres and Beatriz Fernández y Carredano
nodes.siblings: Vicente Masarnau
nodes.works as: gentilhombre de casa y boca (Fernando VII); Catholic militant (Conferencias de San Vicente de Paúl).
nodes.portrayed by: Federico Madrazo, 1834, drawing (Prado); Federico Madrazo, 1836, drawing (BNE)

nodes.label: V. Masarnau
nodes.studies in: Seminario de Vergara; Instituto de San Isidro
nodes.curiosities: he is mentioned by the writer Benito Pérez Galdós in Fortunata y Jacinta and El doctor Centeno.
nodes.profession: scientist (Doctor in Sciences and Pharmacy); teacher
nodes.member of: Real Academia de Ciencias Exactas, Físicas y Naturales (1847-1879) (founding member); Real Academia Nacional de Medicina (1861-1879).
nodes.founder of: Colegio de Massarnau (with his brother Santiago, in 1841, Madrid).
nodes.parents: Santiago de Masarnau y Torres and Beatriz Fernández y Carredano
nodes.siblings: Santiago Masarnau
nodes.works as: Professor of Pharmacy, Chemistry and Physics at the University of Madrid; Treasurer of the Real Academia de Ciencias Exactas, Físicas y Naturales; Inspector General de Instrucción pública (1857).
nodes.portrayed by: Federico Madrazo, 1834, drawing (Prado); Federico Madrazo, 1836, drawing (BNE)

nodes.label: Mérimée
nodes.profession: writer, historian, archaeologist, anthropologist, playwright, politician, translator, draughtsman
nodes.works as: Inspecteur général des monuments historiques (1834). Senator (1853). He was one of the main translators of Russian into French, and also knew Arabic, English and Greek.
nodes.studies in: Lycée Henri-IV. Then he studies Law and Music (piano), obtaining his final certificate in Rome.
author of: Fiction: Théâtre de Clara Gazul (1825): 6 short pieces. 2 more pieces in 1830 (after trip to Spain). Mérimée read it out loud in the salons
Fiction: Mateo Falcone (1829, Revue de Paris); La Vénus d'Ille (1837)
Fiction: Carmen (1845 written; 1847 published in La Revue des Deux Mondes)

Art criticism and travel literature: Les Grands Maîtres au Musée de Madrid (1830); Lettres d’Espagne (1831-1833 in La Revue de Paris et dans L'Artiste): Les Combats de taureaux, Une exécution, Les Voleurs, Les Sorcières espagnoles; Notes de voyages (1835—1840)
History: Don Pedro Ier, roi de Castille (1848)
Visual arts: , Homme en Grande Bottes, watercolor drawing, Walters Art Museum 37.2790 (possibly from Perrault's Le Petit Pouchet)
nodes.writes in: Revue des Deux Mondes; Revue germanique; Revue de Paris
nodes.member of: Académie des inscriptions et belles-lettres (1843-1870); Académie française (1844-1870), replacing Charles Nodier; Société des antiquaires de la Morinie; Société de l’histoire de France; Académie du dessin de Florence
nodes.decorations/awards: Grand officier de la Légion d'honneur; Grand prix des Meilleurs romans du XIXe siècle (1952)
in Spain: Trips: 1830 (Madrid, Córdoba, Sevilla, Cádiz, Granade and Barcelona), 1831, 1840, 1846

1855-VI-21 letter: 'Vos amis [les carlistes] m’empêchent d’aller en Espagne où je suis mieux qu’ailleurs. Ils brûlent à présent les malles-poste et je pense qu’ils ne tarderont guère à brûler les voyageurs' (Correspondance inédite 1896)
1856-VI-28 letter: 'je m’en irai en Italie si j’ai du courage, ou en Espagne si je n’en ai pas' (Correspondance inédite, 1896)

1857-III-6 letter: 'Je n’ai pas encore une opinion arrêtée sur Philippe II. Il flotte entre grand homme ou imbécile, grand politique de l’école de Machiavel ou mais très méchant. En Espagne sa mémoire est respectée, et cependant c’est à lui qu’il faut faire remonter toutes les misères de ce pays. J’ai eu souvent de grandes disputes à son sujet avec Mme de Montijo qui l’admirait fort'
nodes.visits the Prado Museum: in 1830 (doesn't mention Goya in his account)
nodes.parents: Léonor Mérimée and Anne Louise Moreau
nodes.portrayed by: Anne Moreau in 1808 (as a child); Charles Reutilinger, photograph (1850); Simon Jacques Rochard, pastel, 1852 (Musée Carnavalet); Mathilde Bonaparte, drawing, 1869 (Musée Carnavalet); Nadar, caricature, BNF RESERVE BOITE ECU-NA-88, [Gallica](https://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/btv1b8540006w.item)
nodes.pseudonyms: L' Auteur du Théâtre de Clara Gazul, Clara Gazul, Joseph Lestrange, Hyacinthe Maglanovich
mentions of Goya: Several mentions of Goya in Mérimée's correspondence: 3:345, 5:194, 14:494 (anonymous contribution)

1843-III-25 letter to Eugenia de Montijo: he mentions 'une très belle chose de Goya et fort rare' that she mentioned; 'Si vous pouvez me la procurer sans peine, cela me fera grand plaisir' (Canavaggio 2016, p.340)

1847-X-22 letter to Eugenia de Montijo: 'Était-ce le mari de cette belle femme en robe de satin peinte par Goya, dont le portrait est dans votre salon attenant à ma chambre ?' (i.e. Portrait of the Marchioness of Lazán, Palacio de Liria, Madrid) (Canavaggio 2016, p.340)
1856-VII-8 letter to Valentín Carderera: mention of Goya's print series, some of which before being published (Fayos-Pérez 2020 and 2021; see Mérimée-Carderera node)

1869-V-16 letter to Marcello: 'Je ne vous pardonne pas votre admiration pour Goya. J'ignorais qu'il eût jamais eu de la passion pour la duchesse d'Albe, qu'il a peinte en veste jaune et robe transparente, mais ses eaux-fortes, pas plus que ses tableaux ne me plaisent. Il a fait quelques eaux-fortes d'après Vélasquez, qui ont cependant le mérite de rappeler les originaux à qui les a vus. Mais comment osez-vous trouver beau les Désastres de la guerre ? [...] Les caprichos qu'il a faits, lorsqu'il était plus qu'à moitié fou, ont quelques drôleries assez bonnes. Quand à ses tableaux, ils me font horreur, non par les sujets, mais par l'exécution [...]' (Géal 2017, p.73; Fayos-Pérez 2020 and 2021) (See Mérimée-Marcello node)
curiosities: As Inspecteur général des monuments historiques, he named Viollet-le-Duc in charge of the restoration of the Vézelay basilica (1840), the cathedral Notre-Dame de Paris (1843) and the Cité de Carcassonne (1853).
He was a close friend of Empress Eugènie (Eugenia de Montijo).
In 1978 a 'base Mérimée' was created in his honour for the classification of historical monuments in France.
bibliography: Recent literature: Cahiers Mérimée; Fayos-Pérez 2020 and 2021; Géal 2017; Canavaggio, Les Espagnes de Mérimée, 2016

Correspondence: Maurice Parturier, Prosper Mérimée, Correspondance générale: t.I 1822-35, t.II 1836-40 (1941-42), t.III 1841-43, t.IV 1844-46, t.V 1847-49, t.VI 1850-52. 2nd series: t.I 1853-55, t.II 1856-58, t.III 1859-60, t.IV 1860-61, t.V 1862-63, t.VI 1864-65, t.VII 1866-67; t.VIII 1868-69; t.IX 1870

Early literature: Augustin Filon, Mérimée et ses amis, 1896; 'Mérimée, Une Correspondance inédite de Prosper Mérimée', Revue des Deux Mondes, 4e période, tome 134, 1896 (pp.5-40); Maurice Tourneux, Prosper Mérimée, ses portraits, ses dessins, sa bibliothèque, Paris, Charavay, 1879

nodes.label: Eugenia M.
nodes.full name: María Eugenia Ignacia Agustina de Palafox y Kirkpatrick
nodes.aristocratic titles: XI Countess of Mora and Grandee of Spain, XVII Baroness of Quinto, XVIII Marchioness of Moya, XIX Countess of Teba, XVI Marchioness of Ardales, IX Marchioness of Osera, IX Countess of Ablitas, XII Countess of Baños, IX Countess of Santa Cruz de la Sierra
nodes.political views: she embraced the Bonapartist cause; she advocated equality for women: she tried (unsuccessfully) to convince the Académie Française to elect George Sand as its first female member; she personally intervened on behalf of Julie-Victoire Daubié for the signing of her baccalaureate diploma; she also intervened for the award of the Légion d'honneur to painter Rosa Bonheur; and obtained Madeleine Brès's enrolment in the Faculty of Medicine
nodes.siblings: María Francisca de Sales (Paca), who marries the XV Duke of Alba in 1849
nodes.studies in: Convento del Sagrado Corazón, Paris (1835) and Gymnase Normale, Civile et Orthosomatique
nodes.children: Louis-Napoléon Bonaparte
nodes.parents: Cipriano de Palafox y Portocarrero and María Manuela Kirkpatrick de Grevignée
nodes.portrayed by: Franz Xaver Winterhalter, 1853; Winterhalter, 1854; Édouard Louis Dubufe, 1854; Winterhalter, L'Impératrice Eugènie entourée de ses dames d'honneur (1855); Gustave Le Gray, photograph, 1856; Winterhalter, Eugènie portant son fils Louis Napoléon (1857); Napoléon, Eugénie and the Imperial Prince, photograph 1858; André-Adolphe-Eugène Disdéri, 1858, photograph; Sergey Lvovich Levitsky, c.1862, photograph; Gustave Le Gray, oil painting, 1869; W. & D. Downey, 1880, photograph; 1920 photograph
nodes.decorations/awards: Orden de la Reina Maria Luisa (1853); Order of Saint Isabel of Portugal (1854); Order of the British Empire (1919); Ordre de Notre-Dame de Guadalupe; Order of the Starry Cross of Austria; Imperial Order of Saont Charles of the MExican Empire (1865)
nodes.curiosities: in her will, she bequeathed 100,000 francs to the Committee for Rebuilding the Cathedral of Reims.

nodes.label: Kirkpatrick
nodes.full name: María Manuela Kirkpatrick de Closeburn y de Grévignée
nodes.trips: London 1837 (friendship with George Villiers, later Lord Clarendon, ambassador in Spain)
in Paris: She received a francophile education and she her adolescence she travelled to Paris, where she stayed at her aunt's Catalina, married to a French diplomat Mathieu de Lesseps.
Her cousin Ferdinand, Viscount of Lesseps, would introduce her in the high society of Paris in the 1830s and 1840s.
In 1816 she met her future husband in Paris.

When her husband was imprisoned for conspiring agains Ferdinand VII in the early 1830s, she went to Paris with her daughters to complete their education. In 1834, her husband inherited the title of VIII Count of Montijo and moved to Madrid, but she stayed in Paris.
c.1849 Manuela and Eugenia move back to Paris. In 1853, Eugenia marries the Emperor Napoleon III at the Notre Dame cathedral.
in Madrid: c.1843 she moves to Madrid with her daughters, and actively participates in the high society with balls and concerts in her palace at Plaza del Ángel and her countryside residence in Carabanchel
In 1847 she starts work as dama de la reina for Queen Isabel II, and then camarera mayor (highest rank).
In 1848 her daughter Paca marries the Duke of Alba.
She leaves the court after a feud with the Marquis of Miraflores, president of the Senate and governor of the Palace.
She returns to Madrid after the marriage of Eugenia in Paris.
nodes.works for: Queen Isabel II as dama de la reina and camarera mayor
nodes.aristocratic titles: Countess of Teba (1817-34), Countess of Montijo (1834-1839), Countess widow of Montijo (1839-79)
nodes.decorations/awards: Dama noble de la Orden de la Reina María Luisa (from 1845); Dama gran cruz de la Imperial Orden de San Carlos (2nd Mexican Empire).
nodes.parents: Guillermo Kirkpatrick and María Francisca de Grévignée
nodes.married to: Cipriano Portocarrero, VIII Count of Montijo: they met in Paris in 1816 and married in 1817.
nodes.children: María Francisca de Sales Portocarrero Palafox y Kirkpatrick, IX Countess of Montijo, known as Paca Alba, (married to the Duke of Alba), and María Eugenia de Guzmán, known as Eugenia de Montijo, Countess of Teba, Empress of the French (married to Napoleon III)
nodes.portrayed by: Federico de Madrazo, 1830s?, oil painting, Palacio de las Dueñas; Disdéri, 1860s, Paris, 'Duchesse d'Albe mère'; unknown, photograph, c.1850-70; Jean Laurent, photograph, 1879 (post-mortem), and subsequent print.
nodes.bibliography: Soledad Maura, Os escribo a todos, Esfera de los Libros, 2025; Charlez Dantzig, Lettres de Prosper Mérimée à Madame de Montijo, Paris, Mercure de France, 1995.

nodes.label: Nadar
nodes.address: workshop in 113, rue Saint-Lazare (c.1854); 35 boulevard des Capucines (1860) (where takes place the first Impressionist Exhibition in 1874)
nodes.studies in: Lycée Condorcet (formerly collège Bourbon). Starts to study Medicine in Lyon but stops to take care of his family after his father's death
nodes.parents: Victor Tournachon-Molin & Thérèse Maillet
nodes.siblings: Adrien
nodes.children: Paul Nadar (Paul Tournachon)
nodes.works in: Le Charivari (from 1848); La Revue comique à l'usage des gens sérieux (founded by Hetzel); Journal pour rire; Petit journal pour rire (chief editor); Le Journal illustré.
participates in: 1848 The légion polonaise (French army in Poland) with his brother.

1850-51 Musée des gloires contemporaines: <300 figures of his time, with >1,000 drawings. Later printed as [Panthéon Nadar](https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/366762) (4 lithographic plates 1854)
1900 retrospective exhibition at the Exposition universelle de Paris, organised by his son Paul Nadar.
nodes.founder of: Le Livre d'Or (1839), with collaborators such as Balzac, Dumas, Gautier, Nerval, Gavarni and Daumier (it stops after 3 issues)
curiosities: Young Nadar defined himself as 'un vrai casse-cou, un touche-à-tout, mal élevé jusqu'à appeler les choses par leur nom, et les gens aussi'.
His pseudonym comes from a trend around 1840 of adding 'dar' after some words ('Tournadar' > 'Nadar').

When enlisted in the légion polonaise in 1848, he is made a prisoner, refuses to be sent back for free and returns to France by foot. Two months later he returns to Paris and starts to work for Jules Hetzel, then Chief of the Cabinet of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (temporary government), as secret agent to find out about Russian troops at the Prussian border.
He is a pioneer in aerial photography, with the views of Petit Bicêtre in 1858.

His adventures as aeronaut inspired Jules Verne's Cinq semaines en ballon (1862), as well as some characters in De la Terre à la Lune (1865) and Autour de la Lune (1869), where Michel Ardan is an anagram of Nadar.
He goes broke during the Paris Commune in 1871.
His workshop at 35 Boulevard des Capucines holds the première exposition des peintres impressionnistesa in 1874.
He produced the first photographic reportage, illustrating his son's interview to the chemist Eugène Chevreul in Le Journal illustré (1886).
author of: Essay: La Robe de Déjanire, 1845 (reedited 1862, 1882); Le Miroir aux alouettes, 1859; Quand j'étais étudiant, 1861; À terre et en l'air. Mémoires du 'Géant', 1864; Le Droit au vol, 1865 (Hetzel); La Grande Symphonie héroïque des punaises, 1877; Sous l'incendie, 1882; Le monde où on patauge, 1883; Quand j'étais photographe, 1899 (reedited in 1993 and 2017), [online](https://cnum.cnam.fr/pgi/redir.php?onglet=e&ident=12KE639)
Photography: André Barret, Nadar. 50 photographies de ses illustres contemporains, éd. Julliard, 1994; Barret, Nadar
member of: Cénacle des Batignolles (from 1863), from which emerges the Impressionist movement
Société d'encouragement de la locomotion aérienne au moyen du plus lourd que l'air
nodes.mentions of Goya: in the Revue comique à l’usage des gens sérieux (May-Dec 1849)'(…) je me trouvai tout d’un coup installé à une table de marbre, en face d’un monsieur barbu qui ressemblait à un ermite décroché d’un cadre de Goya. Il fumait gravement dans une énorme pipe en bois sculpté, dont le fourneau représentait à s’y méprendre la tête de M. Dupin' (p.73)
nodes.link to Goya's work: in the Revue comique à l’usage des gens sérieux (May-Dec 1849), Nadar made several Goyaesque illustrations, such as those in pp.74-75 [archive.org](https://archive.org/details/revuecomiquelu00pari/page/74/), 83, 104, 105, 117.
nodes.bibliography: Nadar, Correspondance, 1820-1851, tome 1, ed. André Rouillé, 1998; Revue comique à l’usage des gens sérieux (May-Dec 1849)
nodes.archives: Bibliothèque historique de la ville de Paris and Musée Carnavalet (related to aerial photography)

nodes.label: Laurent
nodes.in Madrid: from 1843. He opens a photographic workshop in 1856. His photographic company becomes the most important one in Spain.
nodes.in Paris: in 1868, he opens a photographic establishment in 27 rue Richelieu, to sell his photographs of Spain and Protugal
author of: >12,000 photographs, including portraits of the Spanish royal family, images of Spanish monuments (1857-82), and of artworks (including Goya's)
The journal publishes some of his works (12 June 1858).
Laurent, Catalogue illustré des tableaux du Musée du Prado à Madrid, J. Laurent et Cie, 1899.
nodes.exhibitions: Exposition universelle de 1867, Paris (Vues, musées et costumes d'Espagne et du Portugal; 1996 Paris; 2007 PHotoEspaña; 2008 Sevilla; 2015 Madrid, Museo Arqueológico Nacional (Una visión inédita de la Alhambra: Jean Laurent, Fernando Manso).
nodes.portrayed by: unknown, caricature, 1862, Colección Fernández Rivero de fotografía histórica, Málaga; unknwon, 1887, La Ilustración Nacional
nodes.bibliography: Maite Díaz Francés, J. Laurent 1816-1886: Un fotógrafo entre el negocio y el arte, 2016; Carlos Teixidor, 'Fotografías de Laurent en la Quinta de Goya', Descubrir el Arte, no 154, Dec 2011, pp.48-54

nodes.label: Bonheur
nodes.participates in: the Salon 1841, 1845, 1848, 1849, 1853, 1855. Between 1856 and 1867, she didn't exhibit at the Salon because all her production was sold beforehand. Exposition Universelle 1867 (10 paintings; médaille de 2e classe, because of which she decides not to exhibit at the Salon again). Exposition Universelle de Chicago 1893 (4 paintings)
nodes.author of: Bœufs et Taureaux, Race du Cantal (Salon 1848: médaille de 1er classe d'or), Labourage nivernais (Salon 1849), Le Marché aux chevaux (Salon 1853), La Fenaison en Auvergne (Salon 1855), La Foulaison du blé en Camargue (1864-1899), El Cid (1879, Prado)
nodes.works as: Director of École nationale gratuite de dessin pour les jeunes filles (1849-1860)
nodes.political views: influenced by Saint-simonisme
nodes.parents: Oscar-Raymond Bonheur and Sophie Marquis
nodes.decorations/awards: chevalier de la Légion d'honneur (1865); officière de la Légion d'honneur (1894)
nodes.portrayed by: David d'Angers, 1856, medallion; Edouard Louis Dubufe, 1857, oil painting, Palace de Versailles; Charles-Michel Geoffroy, 1859, print; Eugène Disdéri, 1865, photograph; Anna Klumpke, 1898, oil painting, Metropolitan; c.1900, photograph, Musée Rosa Bonheur
nodes.curiosities: Rosa's father, Raymond Bonheur, was a painter who met and befriended Goya and Moratín in Bordeaux.

nodes.label: Marcello
nodes.full name: Adélaïde Nathalie Marie Hedwige Philippine d’Affry
nodes.in Spain: in 1868 (during the Revolution): she meets painters Henri Regnault and Georges Clarin; she meets and makes a bust after Milans del Bosch; with recommentation letters from Mérimée, Marcello has access to the Prado Museum, and admires, among others, the work of Velázquez (probably of Goya too).
author of: Sculpture: La Belle Hélène (1860); La Gorgone (Salon 1865); L'Imperatrice Eugénie (1866); Marie-Antoinette à Versailles (1866); Hécate (Exposition universelle 1867, commissioned by Napoléon III); La Bacchante fatiguée (1869); La Mauresque souriante (1869); La Pythie (1870); Portrait de madame de Tallenay (1873); La Baronne Keffenbrinck (Salon 1876).
Painting: La Conjuration de Fiesque (Salon 1874: rejected); Portrait de Berthe Morisot (1875).

Printmaking (since 1860): dark, grotesque etchings clearly inspired by Goya's prints, mainly the Disasters of War (see Fayos Pérez 2024, fig.II.68, Marcello, Vision of human skulls); she made 9 etchings and some lithographs inspired by Eugène Delacroix (1873).
Writing: Mémoires, unfinished
nodes.masters: Sculpture: Heinrich Max Imhof, Antoine-Louis Barye (Muséum national d'histoire naturally), Auguste Clésinger. Painting: Ernest Hébert (drawing, at the Villa Médicis), Mariano Fortuny (at his workshop, she meets Eduardo Rosales), Léon Bonnat (from 1872); Marcellin Desboutin (printmaking).
nodes.parents: Louis d'Affry and Lucie d'Affry de Maillardo
nodes.address: 1, rue Bayard, from 1859 (rented to Léon Riesener, Eugène Delacroix's cousin)
nodes.portrayed by: Adolphe Dallemagne, c.1866-67, photograph (BNF); Gustave Courbet, 1870 (Musée de Reims); Edouard-Théophile Blanchard, oil painting, 1877 (Musée d'art et d'histoire de Fribourg)
nodes.decorations/awards: medal for her works at the Exposition universelle de 1873 (Vienna): Le Chef abyssin, Bianca Capello, 2 Marie-Antoinette, Pythie
curiosities: She refused to be portrayed by Édouard Manet.
She was a great admirer of music, and met Charles Gounod and Franz Liszt.
In her will, she donated her work to the city of Fribourg, under the condition of creating a museum.
nodes.bibliography: Fayos Pérez 2024; François Géal, 2017, 'Mérimée/Goya, chronique d'un désamour annoncé', Cahiers Mérimée, pp.55; Gianna A. Mina (dir.), Marcello, Adèle d'Affry (1836-1879), duchesse de Castiglione Colonna, catalogue d'exposition, Fribourg, Musée d'art et d'histoire, 2014; 1980 exhibition catalogue, Fribourg (Dictionnaire de l'estampe 1830-1950, 1985, p.213); Odette d'Alcantara, Marcello : Adèle d'Affry, duchesse Castiglione-Colonna, 1836–1879, sa vie, son œuvre, sa pensée et ses amis, Genève, Éditions générales, 1961

nodes.label: Iriarte
nodes.in France: 1814 with the return of Fernando VII
nodes.works as: 1780 Consejero de Indias (colonies); 1792 member of the Consejo de Ecomercio; 1792 vice-protector of the RABASF; 1797 Minister of Agriculture, Commerce and Navigation; 1809 Diputado de Madrid and Consejero de Estado de la Corona (Joseph I).
nodes.works for: Fernando VI, Carlos III, Carlos IV, Joseph I (Joseph Bonaparte)
nodes.author of: a translation of Voltaire's Tancrède (1765), in connection to the French ambassador Pierre-Paul d'Ossun (Tragedia. El Tancredo).
nodes.member of: Real Academia Española; Real Academia de Ciencias y Artes de Barcelona
nodes.link to Goya's work: it is to Iriarte that Goya sends a letter on 7 Jan 1794 accompanying the series of 14 small paintings that he produced after his disease, with topics of 'capricho e invención'.
nodes.portrayed by: Francisco de Goya, 1797, Strasbourg Museum of Fine Arts
nodes.art collection: started by his uncle Juan de Iriarte (LG 2016, p.98). It included works attributed to Velázquez, Murillo, Titian, Van Dyck and Mengs.
nodes.sales: London (date?). Paris, 15 and 17 Feb 1841, and 21 Jan 1842. Attended by Carderera, who saw a portrait attributed to Velázquez being sold for 100 fr., and a Murillo for 55 fr. (LG 2016, p.98).
nodes.siblings: Tomás de Iriarte (famous fabulist) and Domingo de Iriarte (diplomat)
nodes.bibliography: Lanzarote Guiral 2016

nodes.label: Guillemardet
nodes.profession: diplomat (French ambassador 1798-1800), medical doctor, politician (representative of the Convention)
nodes.portrayed by: Goya, 1798, Louvre
nodes.collector of Goya's works: a set of the Caprichos; his portrait (1798, Louvre MI697); Portrait of Mariana Waldstein, IX Marchioness of Santa Cruz (c.1797-99, Louvre RF1976-79) [authorship doubts]
nodes.commissions Goya with: portrait, 1798, Louvre MI697 (GW.677). This was the first work by Goya to enter the Louvre (donated by his heirs in 1865)

nodes.label: Delacroix
nodes.author of: La Barque de Dante (1822, Louvre); Scenes from the Massacre at Chios (1824, Louvre); Nature morte aux Homards (1826-27, Louvre); The Death of Sardanapalus (1827, Louvre); Liberty guiding the People (1830, Louvre); Les Femmes d'Alger (1834, Louvre); Médée (1838, Lille); Hamlet et Horatio au cimetière (1839); décor de la bibliothèque de l'Assemblée national (Palais Bourbon) (1838-1847); décor de la bilbiothèque du Sénat (palais Luxembourg) (1840-1846); décor de la Galerie d'Apollon (Louvre) (1850-1851); Le Christ sur le lac de Génésareth (1854); décor de Saint-Sulpice (1850-1861)
nodes.studies in: École nationale supérieure des beaux-arts; Lycée Louis-le-Grand; Lycée Pierre-Corneille de Rouen
member of: Société héliographique (from 1851): the first of its kind to be focused on photography

The Société Nationales de Beaux-Arts is founded by Théophile Gautier and Louis Martinet in 1862. The committee includes Eugène Delacroix, Carrier-Belleuse and Puvis de Chavannes. Among the exhibitors were Léon Bonnat, Jean-Baptiste Carpeaux, Charles-François Daubigny, Gustave Doré and Édouard Manet. Upon Delacroix's death, the SNBA organised a retrospective exhibition of his work (1864)
nodes.in Spain: in 1832: 'Tout Goya palpitait autour de moi'
nodes.knows Goya's works: by c.1819, through Ferdinand Guillemardet (Lipschutz 1972, p.10)
nodes.students: Pierre Andrieu, Gustave de Lassalle-Borde, Louis de Planet, Maurice Sand. In 1841 he opens a workshop with students in order to complete different commissions.
nodes.influenced by: Géricault, Antoine-Jean Gros, Pierre Paul Rubens, Francisco de Goya
nodes.parents: Victoire Œben and Charles-François Delacroix
nodes.decorations/awards: Commandeur de la Légion d'honneur (1855)
nodes.portrayed by: Delacroix/Géricault, c.1816, Rouen (oil painting); Nadar, 1858 (photograph)
nodes.curiosities: he became interested in photography since 1851, and commissioned the photographer Eugène Durieu with a series of pictures of nude models (male and female).
nodes.bibliography: Sébastien Allard et al., 2018 exhibition catalogue, Louvre; Maurice Sérullaz, 1989, Delacroix

nodes.label: Llorente
nodes.considered as: part of the group of Spanish 'afrancesados'
nodes.collector of Goya's works: his portrait (1810-11); a set of the Caprichos (probably bought c.1810 when sitting for his portrait).
nodes.disseminates Goya's works: he brings his Caprichos set to France in 1813 during his exile, and wrote an interpretation of them in French (Boston MFA 1973.730), probably to be shared among French speakers (Fayos Pérez 2024, p.35). Since Goya himself was alive in 1813 and in possession of his original explanations of the Caprichos (known as the Prado commentaries), Llorente probably knew this text directly through him, perhaps during his portrait sittings (c.1810)
nodes.works as: Comisario General de Cruzada (1810-11); Comisario del Santo Oficio; Secretario supernumerario de la Inquisición de Corte; canon of Calahorra (1790); literary censor for the Consejo de Castilla; member of the Junta Nacional for Joseph Bonaparte, Consejero de Estado para Asuntos Eclesiásticos, and Caballero comendador de la Orden Real de España (1809)
nodes.in France: exiled from July 1813, first at Lectoure, then Bordeaux, then Paris (1814). In Paris, he publishes 'Histoire critique de l'Inquisition espagnole' (1817-18) in 4 volumes.
nodes.in Spain: back in 1820, after being expelled from France (during the Bourbon restoration) for being a liberal and a Carbonari
nodes.political views: liberal. Supporter of Regalism. Member of Carbonari (secret revolutionary society, patriotic and liberal in nature). Works for the reform of the clergy in Spain
nodes.studies in: Universidad de Zaragoza. Doctor in Canonical Law
nodes.author of: a report about the Inquisition (1793); Histoire critique de l'Inquisition espagnole (1817-18) in 4 volumes; Retrato político de los Papas (1823); Historia crítica de la inquisición de España (1835).
nodes.member of: Real Sociedad Económica de La Rioja (1805)
nodes.portrayed by: Francisco de Goya, 1810-11, Museo de Arte de São Paulo; Vicente Velázquez, in Noticia biográfica de D. Juan Antonio Llorente, escrita por él mismo, Paris, 1818 (BNE IH 5183/4)
nodes.decorations/awards: Orden Real de España
nodes.curiosities: he wrote a zarzuela, El recluta gallego (1782).

nodes.label: Brugada
nodes.curiosities: he witnessed Goya'death in Bordeaux, alongside Molina (Canellas, Diplomatario, no.181, p.512).
nodes.image source: AI generated (DeepAI) because there is no known portrait

nodes.label: Ceán Bermúdez
nodes.considered as: part of the group of Spanish 'ilustrados'
nodes.works as: manager of the Archivo de Indias; Secretary's officer for the Estado de Gracia y Justicia de Indias
nodes.member of: RABASF
nodes.collector of Goya's works: Goya gave a vast number of his works to Ceán Bermúdez, including rare working proofs (now at the BNE); this collection was later acquired by Valentín Carderera
nodes.author of: Colección lithographica de cuadros del Rey de España el Sr. D. Fernando VII (1826-37); Diccionario histórico de los más ilustres profesores de las Bellas Artes en España (1800); Sumario de las antigüedades romanas que hay en España, en especial las pertenecientes a las Bellas Artes (1832, postumous)
nodes.portrayed by: Goya (attributed), c.1783, oil painting (private collection); Goya, c.1786, oil painting (private collection); Goya c.1798-1799, drawing (colección Colomer)
nodes.collector of: Dürer, José de Ribera, Piranesi, among others
nodes.married to: Manuela Camas y de las Heras
nodes.studies in: Universidad Complutense

nodes.label: Esteve
nodes.studies in: Academia de Bellas Artes de San Carlos, Valencia
nodes.masters: Francisco Bayeu; Mariano Salvador Maella; Francisco de Goya
nodes.parents: Agustín Esteve Torralba and María Marqués
nodes.author of: Portrait of the Marchioness of San Andrés de Parma (c.1791); Portrait of Francisco de Borja Téllez-Girón, future X Duke of Osuna (1797, colección Masaveu); Portrait of Martín Antonio Álvarez de Sotomayor y Soto-Flores, conde de Colomera (1798, Prado); Portrait of Manuel Godoy, fundador del Instituto Pestalozzi (c.1806, Museo de Bellas Artes de Valencia); self-portrait, c.1815, Museo Lázaro Galdiano. Copies after Francisco de Goya
nodes.works as: Pintor de Cámara (from 1800); art professor (RABASF)
nodes.member of: RABASF (académico de mérito) (from 1800)
nodes.decorations/awards: first prize of painting at the RABASF (1778)
nodes.bibliography: Albarrán 2018; Albarrán (upcoming)

nodes.label: Moratín
nodes.full name: Leandro Eulogio Melitón Fernández de Moratín y Cabo
nodes.profession: playwright, poet, actor, writer, translator (of Molière and Voltaire)
nodes.works as: Secretary of language interpretation (1797), after the death of one of the Samaniego brothers; member of the Junta de Dirección y Reforma de los Teatros (1799), but he resigns 3 months later; main librarian (bibliotecario mayor) of the Real Biblioteca in 1811, under Joseph Bonaparte (he creates a new catalogue); Juez de Imprentas in 1820 in Barcelona (after the victory of Rafael del Riego)
nodes.founder of: a parodic literary academy called 'Acalófilos o amantes de lo feo' (supporters of the ugly), alongside his friend Juan Tineo Ramírez, nephew of Jovellanos, and the arabist José Antonio Conde; the group was mostly a tertulia (similar to a salon) to read and criticise theatre plays.
nodes.author of: Lección poética. Sátira contra los vicios introducidos en la poesía española (1782); La derrota de los pedantes (1789); La comedia nueva o El café (1792); Apuntaciones sueltas de Inglaterra (1792), Viaje a Italia (1793); translation of Hamlet (1798); El barón (1803); La mojigata (1804); El sí de las niñas (1806), his greatest success; a prologue criticising the recently banished Inquisition, for a failed edition of Fray Gerundio de Campazas (1758) by José Francisco de Isla y Rojo; reedition of Auto de fe celebrado en la ciudad de Logroño en los días 7 y 8 de noviembre del año de 1610 (...) (1811); La escuela de los maridos (1812), with actor Isidoro Máiquez, portrayed by Goya; Obras dramáticas y líricas (1825, Paris). Posthumous: Orígenes del teatro español (1830-1831), Diarios (1968), Epistolario (1973) edited by René Andioc.
in France: In 1787, in a trip accompanying Cabarrús to Paris in a diplomatic mission to advise Louis XVI on counter-revolutionary measures
In his 1792-1797 European tour, he witnessed the assault on the Tuileries on 10 August 1792, and being scared, went to England
1817-1820: fears of the newly restored Inquisition led him back to France on the pretext of taking the waters in Aix-en-Provence; he then went to Montpellier, Paris and Bologna

In 1821 he flees to Bayonne after the plague is declared in Barcelona. He would never return to Spain again. He settles in Bordeaux with his friend Manuel Silvela (also portrayed by Goya). In Bordeaux, he meets Goya again (who makes his second portrait in 1824)
He makes his last trip to Paris in 1828. He dies there that year.
nodes.trips: 1792-1797 European tour (funded by Godoy): France, England, Belgium, Germany, Switzerland, Italy
nodes.member of: Academia de la Arcadia (Roma); Real Academia Española, miembro de número (1821)
nodes.studies in: Universidad de Valladolid
nodes.political views: reformist. Supporter of Godoy. Afrancesado
nodes.parents: Isidora Cabo Conde and Nicolás Fernández de Moratín
nodes.decorations/awards: knight of the Orden Real de España in 1811 (under Joseph Bonaparte)
mentions of Goya: Diary, 21 May 1798 (Canellas no.88): they see together the paintings of San Antonio de la Florida?
Moratín writes Silva á D. Francisco Goya, insigne pintor in 1799 to thank him for his newly made portrait. [Wikipedia](https://es.wikisource.org/wiki/Silva_a_don_Francisco_Goya)
nodes.portrayed by: Francisco de Goya, 1799, RABASF; Luis Paret y Alcázar, Museo de Navarra; Francisco de Goya, 1824, Museo de Bellas Artes de Bilbao
nodes.curiosities: his remains are in the collective mausoleum with Goya, Meléndez Valdés and Donoso Cortés at the Cemetery of San Isidro (Madrid).

nodes.label: Godoy
nodes.full name: Manuel Godoy y Álvarez de Faria Ríos
nodes.aristocratic titles: Príncipe de la Paz, I Marquis and Duke of Alcudia (Grandee of Spain), I Duke of Sueca (Grandee of Spain), I Baron of Mascalbó, VII Prince of Bassano, I Count of Évoramonte, Count of Chinchón (by marriage; Grandee of Spain), and others
nodes.parents: José Alfonso Godoy Cáceres Ovando y Ríos and Antonia Justa Álvarez de Faria y Sánchez Zarzoza
nodes.married to: María Teresa de Borbón y Vallabriga (Condesa de Chinchón); Josefa Tudó y Catalán (1829)
nodes.children: Carlota Luisa de Godoy y Borbón; Manuel Luis de Godoy y Tudó; Luis Carlos de Godoy y Tudó
nodes.author of: Memorias de don Manuel Godoy, Príncipe de la Paz, ó sea cuenta dada de su vida política, para servir a la historia del reinado del señor don Carlos IV de Borbón, 6 volumes, 1836-1838. He wrote them in Paris and they were translated into French by Jean-Baptiste Esménard
in France: 1808: in exile with Carlos IV and María Luisa de Parma, in Compiègne, close to Paris. Then Marseille.
nodes.in Paris: From 1831 Godoy lives in Paris with his second wife Josefa Tudó (9 rue des Mathurins). King Louis-Philippe gave him a modest pension, and he focused on the writing of his autobiography. His wife focused on real state investments (La Parra López 1997). In 1844 and 1847, Queen Isabel II gave him back his titles and properties, but he did not return to Spain. In 1848, he witnessed the revolution in Paris, and the exaltation of Napoleon III
in Italy: 1812: Godoy accompanies Carlos IV and María Luisa de Parma in their exile in Rome, first at the Palazzo Borghese, then at the Palazzo Barberini (where María Luisa died in 1819). The King dies in Naples.
Godoy and Josefa Tudó had a residence in Rome in Via del Corso, 255. They get married in 1829.
nodes.art collection: his collection included works by Zurbarán, Ribera, Murillo, Rubens, Teniers, Tiziano, Goya and Velázquez (including the famous Venus del espejo, known as the 'Rokeby Venus', now at the London National Gallery). His estates, titles and art collection were expropriated when Godoy went into exile, and there are unanswered questions about, for instance, the dubious ways in which the 'Rokeby Venus' ended up in England
nodes.patronage: he commissioned portraits from all the main artists of the moment, including Goya
nodes.collector of Goya's works: Godoy commissioned Goya with a portrait (1801) and the two celebrated 'Majas': the Maja vestida and the Maja desnuda, both paintings now at the Prado (see Goya-Godoy edge).
nodes.mentions of Goya: in his Memorias, Madrid, Imprenta de I. Sancha: t.II, 1836, p.233 (mention of Goya among other artists); t.III, 1836, p.375 ('La calcografia real publicaba la coleccion de vistas del Escorial y las ochenta estampas de los bellos caprichos de don Francisco Goya, dibujados por él mismo'); t.IV, 1837, p.238 (mention of Goya's portrait)
nodes.rivals: Count of Floridablanca; Count of Aranda; Ferdinand VII
nodes.military activity: Guardia de Corps (1784), for Carlos III; Mariscal de campo (Field Marshal) (Feb 1791), teniente general (July 1791), Generalísimo (1801) and Gran almirante (1807) of the Reales Ejércitos; Almirante general de España e Indias (1807) (Alteza Serenísima); Jefe superior de los Reales Cuerpos de Artillería e Ingenieros; Ayudante general del Real Cuerpo de Guardias de Corps; Coronel general de la Guardia Suiza Pontificia.
nodes.works as: military man; Primer Secretario de Estado (1792-1798) and President of the Consejo de Estado; Primer Ministro; Gentilhombre de la Cámara del Rey con ejercicio; Superintendente general de la Renta de Correos (1792-1798).
decorations/awards: Spain: Caballero de la Orden del Toisón de Oro; Gran Cruz de la Orden de Cristo; Caballero de la Orden de Carlos III; Caballero de la Real y Militar Orden de San Hermenegildo; Caballero (1789) y comendador (1790) de la Orden de Santiago. Also he was named protector of the Real Academia de Nobles Artes y de los Reales Institutos de Historia Natural, Jardín Botánico, Laboratorio Químico and the Observatory

Foreign: Bailío gran cruz de la Orden de San Juan de Jerusalén; Caballero de la Orden de la Legión de Honor; Caballero de la Suprema Orden de Cristo (Reino de Portugal); Caballero de la Suprema Orden de Cristo (Estados Pontificios); Caballero de la Orden de San Jenaro (Reino de las Dos Sicilias); Caballero de la Orden de San Fernando y el Mérito (Reino de las Dos Sicilias)
nodes.political views: extremely loyal to Carlos IV and María Luisa de Parma, who gave him countless decorations and aristocratic titles. He limited the power of the high aristocracy. In 1797, he formed a government considered ilustrado: Jovellanos (Secretary of Justice), Francisco de Saavedra (Hacienda), Cabarrús (creator of Banco de San Carlos): sent to Paris as ambassador; he also included Meléndez Valdés and Mariano Luis de Urquijo. Most of these politicians were portrayed by Goya, and many were also his friends.
nodes.portrayed by: Francisco Folch de Cardona, 1788, RABASF; Francisco Bayeu, 1792, RABASF; Juan Adán, 1794, RABASF (sculpture: bust); Francisco de Goya, 1794, private collection (equestrian portrait); Agustín Esteve, 1800, Chicago Art Institute; Francisco de Goya, 1801, RABASF; Agustín Esteve, c.1806, portrait as founder of the Instituto Pestalozzi, Museo de Bellas Artes de Valencia; Antonio Carnicero, c.1807-1808, RABASF; José de Madrazo, c.1816, RABASF
nodes.bibliography: José Belmonte Díaz & Pilar Leseduarte, Godoy: historia documentada de un expolio, 2004; Emilio La Parra López, 'Godoy en el París de Luis Felipe. La atracción de una imagen de prosperidad', La imagen de Francia en España (1808-1850), pp.79-86; Memorias de don Manuel Godoy, Príncipe de la Paz, ó sea cuenta dada de su vida política, para servir a la historia del reinado del señor don Carlos IV de Borbón, 6 volumes, 1839-1841

nodes.label: P. Tudó
nodes.full name: Josefa Petra Francisca de Paula de Tudó y Catalán, Alemany y Luesia
nodes.aristocratic titles: I Condesa de Castillo Fiel (1807), I Vizcondesa de Rocafuerte y Princesa de Bassano
nodes.parents: Antonio de Tudó y Alemany and Catalina de Catalán y Luesia
nodes.married to: Manuel Godoy in 1829 (Rome). They were lovers since c.1797.
nodes.children: Manuel Luis de Godoy y Tudó; Luis Carlos de Godoy y Tudó
in Paris: From 1819, she lives in Paris while Godoy stays in Rome. Her and Godoy make several real state investments.

In the 1820s she is in contact with many famous Spaniards exiled in Paris, such as the Count of Toreno, the Marquis of Pontejos, the Duchess of Híjar and the Duke of San Carlos. She attends the soirées organised by Madame Salazar (La Parra López 1997, p.81).
1831-1834: she lives with Godoy in Paris (9 rue des Mathurins).
nodes.link to Goya's work: Pedro Madrazo created the myth of Josefa Tudó being the model of Goya's naked and clothed Majas, but this is a fabricated story, as explained by Carlos G. Navarro (see Arte compacto, [27 April 2025](https://www.youtube.com/shorts/2HRbEYmYGWY), 'José de Madrazo').
nodes.in Madrid: 1834: she returns from Paris to rehabilitate Godoy's image in Spain and recover the confiscated properties by Fernando VII (dead in 1833).
in Italy: 1812-c.1819: she lives with Godoy in Rome, who accompanies Carlos IV and María Luisa de Parma in their exile.
Godoy and Josefa Tudó had a residence in Rome in Via del Corso, 255. They get married in 1829.
nodes.portrayed by: José Madrazo, c.1810-15; José Madrazo, c.1812, Prado; José Madrazo, 1813, RABASF
nodes.bibliography: Emilio La Parra López, 'Godoy en el París de Luis Felipe. La atracción de una imagen de prosperidad', La imagen de Francia en España (1808-1850), pp.79-86

nodes.id: María Teresa de Borbón y Vallabriga, XV Condesa de Chinchón
nodes.label: Chinchón
nodes.full name: María Teresa Josefa de Borbón y Vallabriga
nodes.parents: Luis Antonio de Borbón y Farnesio and María Teresa de Vallabriga y Rozas
nodes.children: Carlota Luisa de Godoy y Borbón
nodes.in Paris: she went into exile in 1824, alongside her sister María Luisa and her sister's husband, the Duke of San Fernando de Quiroga. This was due to her links with Constitutionalists and her liberal ideas. She confided her financial affairs to Vicente López Arnao. She was surveyed by the French Police, who knew she had paintings by Velázquez and Murillo (Gerard Powell, 2014, p.306, ANP,F/7 12026)
nodes.art collection: her impressive collection included Velázquez's Cristo de San Plácido, now at the Prado
nodes.sales: she tried to sell her collection in July 1824, then in 1826
nodes.aristocratic titles: XV Countess of Chinchón; I Marchioness of Boadilla del Monte (1799). Grandee of Spain (Grande de España) (1823)
nodes.bibliography: Calvo Ruata 2020; Gerard Powell 2014
nodes.portrayed by: Goya, 1783, National Gallery, Washington; Goya, 1784, in Retrato del Infante Don Luis (Fundación Magnani-Rocca, Italy); Goya, 1800, Prado

nodes.label: Vallabriga
nodes.full name: María Teresa de Vallabriga y Rozas
nodes.parents: José Ignacio de Vallabriga y Español and Josefa de Rozas y Drummond de Melfort
nodes.children: María Teresa de Borbón y Vallabriga, XV Condesa de Chinchón; Cardinal Luis de Borbón; Luisa, Duchess of San Fernando de Quiroga
nodes.aristocratic titles: Dama de la Orden de las Damas Nobles de la reina María Luisa
nodes.portrayed by: Goya, 1783, Galleria degli Uffizi (equestrian portrait); Goya, 1783, bust portrait (profile), Pardo; Goya, 1783, Neue Pinakothek Munich; Goya, c.1783, private collection

nodes.label: Infante D.Luis
nodes.full name: Luis Antonio Jaime de Borbón y Farnesio
nodes.address: Palacio de la Mosquera (Arenas de San Pedro, Ávila)
nodes.parents: Felipe V and Isabel de Farnesio
nodes.married to: María Teresa de Vallabriga (1776-1820), 32 years younger
nodes.children: María Teresa de Borbón y Vallabriga, XV Condesa de Chinchón; Cardinal Luis de Borbón; Luisa, Duchess of San Fernando de Quiroga
nodes.aristocratic titles: Infante de España; XIII Count of Chinchón (1761)
nodes.works as: archbishop of Seville; cardinal-archibishop of Toledo and Primado de España
nodes.patronage: Francisco de Goya; Luis Paret; Luigi Boccherini
nodes.portrayed by: Van Loo, c.1737, Prado; Mengs, 1767, San Diego Museum; Goya (attributed), 1783, private collection; Goya, 1784, La familia del infante don Luis de Borbón, Fondazione Magnani-Rocca
nodes.exhibitions: 2012-13, Goya y el Infante Don Luis: el exilio y el reino, [Patrimonio Nacional](https://www.patrimonionacional.es/microsites/goya/)

nodes.label: Paret
nodes.studies in: RABASF
nodes.member of: RABASF since 1780 (same year as Goya)
nodes.lives in: Madrid, Puerto Rico (1775-78: exile), Bilbao (1778-89), Navarra (Viana), Madrid (1789)
nodes.parents: French father and Spanish mother
nodes.masters: Antonio González Velázquez (follower of Corrado Giaquinto); Charles François de la Traverse (1766)
nodes.portrayed by: self-portrait, c.1779, Abelló collection, Madrid
curiosities: From 1775 to 1778, he is banned by Carlos III (accused of acting as Luis de Borbón's pimp), and exiled to Puerto Rico
He has been called 'the Spanish Watteau'.
nodes.works as: vice-secretary of the RABASF (1792)
nodes.author of: La tienda de Geniani (1772, Lázaro Galdiano); La Puerta del Sol en MadridCarlos III comiendo ante su corte (c.1775, Prado); Autorretrato en el estudio (1777, Prado); Joven dormida en una hamaca (1780-81, Prado); La Circunspección de Diógenes (1780, RABASF); Una celestina y dos amantes, watercolor (1784, Prado); El rezo del rosario (c.1784-95, Palacio Real Madrid); Jura de Fernando VII como príncipe de Asturias (1791, Prado)
nodes.exhibitions: 2022, Paret, Prado (Gudrun Maurer); 2021, Museo de Bellas Artes de Bilbao; 2018, Paret's prints and drawings, BNE.
nodes.art collection: he had a rich library that included prints by Hogarth, Bourdon, Stubbs, Vernet and Guercino
nodes.newspaper archive: Ángeles García, 'Luis Paret, el pintor que tuvo la mala suerte de coincidir con Goya', El País, [23 May 2022](https://elpais.com/cultura/2022-05-23/luis-paret-el-pintor-que-tuvo-la-mala-suerte-de-coincidir-con-goya.html)

nodes.label: Gaulon
nodes.studies in: École royale de Sorèze
nodes.participates in: the army of the French Republic in 1791
nodes.works as: editor and lithographer for Gustave de Galard, Eugène Devéria, Pierre Lacour, Francisco de Goya (Bulls of Bordeaux, 1825)
nodes.portrayed by: Goya, 1824-25, lithography (Harris 1964, no.282)
nodes.bibliography: Harris 1964

nodes.label: B. Sureda
nodes.in France: 1800-1803 (to study); in 1812, during the Peninsular War (after the Real Fábrica de Porcelana del Buen Retiro is destroyed by the Duke of Wellington)
nodes.in Paris: 1841-1842 where he meets with Carderera; he works with Viollet-le-Duc in the restoration of the Sainte Chapelle.
nodes.in Madrid: from October 1803. He gets portrayed by Goya
nodes.married to: Thérèse Louise Sureda (also portrayed by Goya) [Washington National Gallery of Art 1942.3.1](https://www.nga.gov/artworks/991-therese-louise-de-sureda)
nodes.children: Alejandro Sureda (architect)
nodes.studies in: Palma, Escuela de Dibujo (from 1785); France (from 1800)
nodes.works as: Director of the Real Fábrica de Porcelana del Buen Retiro (until its destruction in 1812 until 1820) and the Real Fábrica de La Moncloa (from 1817); also Director of the Real Fábrica de Paños de Guadalajara and the Real Fábrica de Cristales de La Granja (from 1822)
nodes.portrayed by: Goya, c.1803-04, Washington, National Gallery of Art. According to Sazatornil & Jiméno, Goya made this portrait to thank Sureda for his help with the printing technique of the Caprichos (2014, pp.108-112)
nodes.bibliography: Sazatornil & Jiméno 2014

nodes.label: A. Sureda
nodes.parents: Bartolomé Sureda and Thérèse Louise de Sureda
nodes.children: Luis Sureda Guignon (architect; worked at the Exposition Universelle de Paris 1878)
nodes.works for: Queen María Cristina: Malmaison and Palace of Braganza in France (1843, 1845-46) and decoration of Palace of Las Rejas in Madrid (1847); Eugenia de Montijo: restoration of Palace of Belmonte, Cuenca (1857-71)
nodes.decorations/awards: Cruz de caballero de la Real Orden de Isabel la Católica (1843), through Carderera
nodes.founder of: the Société d'archéologie nationale, with Lassus and Viollet-le-Duc (1848)
nodes.member of: Sociedad Central de Arquitectos
nodes.works as: inspector of the works of the Sainte-Chapelle, Paris, alongside Viollet-le-Duc (1839); architect (RABASF) from 1850; 2nd architect of the palaces and Reales Sitios (1851-1868); architect at the Teatro Apolo (1871-73); first architect to do works at the Prado Museum (1874-84): refurbishments and interior reform, division of Flemish and Spanish schools, project of the Galería Jónica for sculpture; architect restoring the Belmonte Castle (Cuenca) for Eugenia de Montijo (1857-71); architect for the palace of the Marquis of Cerralbo (from 1883), later the Museo Cerralbo.
nodes.bibliography: Lanzarote Guiral 2016
nodes.image source: AI generated (DeepAI) because there is no known portrait

nodes.label: Matheron
nodes.writes about Goya: first biography of Goya, Goya, 1858, París, Schulz et Thuillié. Digitised in [Prado Biblioteca](https://www.museodelprado.es/aprende/biblioteca/biblioteca-digital/fondo/goya/47f25eaf-29e1-dd74-6727-6227f053e2a2)
nodes.image source: AI generated (DeepAI) because there is no known portrait

nodes.label: Aguado
nodes.Full name: Alejandro María Aguado y Remírez de Estenoz
nodes.profession: banker, military member, collector, art patron
nodes.collection: formed from two collections: that of Bernardo de Iriarte and the Count of Altamira (Lanzarote Guiral 2016, p.LV). Around 360 paintings, mainly by Spanish artists, including Velázquez, Murillo, Ribera and Zurbarán, as well as Italians like Leonardo da Vinci, Rafael, and Dutch-Flemish like Rubens and Rembrandt
nodes.patronage: acquired the Théâtre-Italien (or Comédie-italienne), funded the journals Revue de Paris and Le Constitutionnel, acted as the President of the Athénée des arts
nodes.portrayed by: Francisco Lacoma y Fontanet, 1832 (Madrid, Museo del Romanticismo, CE0509); unknown artist (Palais de Versailles, MV 6727)
nodes.aristocratic titles: I marqués de las Marismas del Guadalquivir
nodes.address: Palais Petit-Bourg, Évry, Paris

nodes.label: Villot
collector of Goya's works: Former attribution to Goya, Portrait of a Young Man (c.1820)[1993.1046](https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/334587); there is another impression at the BM (ex-Burty)

nodes.label: Devéria
nodes.masters: Anne-Louis Girodet; Louis Lafitte; Auguste-Barthélemy Glaize
nodes.participates in: the Salon (from 1822); in 1846, his work is praised by Charles Baudelaire
nodes.parents: François-Marie Devéria (foctionnaire de la Marine)
nodes.siblings: Eugène Devéria; Laure Devéria
nodes.children: Théodule Charles Devéria (Egyptologist), Sara Devéria, Gabriel Devéria
nodes.works as: director of the Département des Estampes at the BNF in 1849; curator of the Department of Egyptian art at the Louvre
nodes.trips: to Egypt, after being appointed curator of Egyptian art at the Louvre
nodes.decorations/awards: Chevalier de la Légion d'honneur (1855)
nodes.address: 45 rue de Notre-Dame-des-Champs (1833) (very close to Victor Hugo), where he would hold a successful salon
author of: Portraits: Honoré de Balzac (c.1825: attributed), Victor Hugo, Alexandre Dumas père (1829), Prosper Mérimée, Franz Liszt (1832)
Original prints: cover of Goethe's Faust

Illustrations: Don Quixote (1821); 10 lithographies after Goya's Caprichos (1825, Charles Motte); La Fontaine's Œuvres complètes (1826; preface by Balzac); Rousseau's Œuvres complètes (1826); Goethe's Faust (illustrated edition after Delacroix, Ch. Motte, 1828); Perrault's Contes (1828); Defoe's Robinson Crusoë (1836); Photographie zoologique ou représentation des animaux rares des collections du Muséum d'Histoire Naturelle (1853-55)
Erotic prints
nodes.copies after Goya: 10 lithographies (in reverse) after the Caprichos (1825): Carricatures [sic] espagnoles, Ni plus ni moins, par Goya, edited by Charles Motte. They are not signed but most scholars agree on this attribution. After Caprichos 10, 14, 15, 18, 23, 32, 41, 43, 52, 55 (Fayos Pérez 2024, p.119; reproduced in Chazal 2008, pp. 302–5, nos.224–34)
nodes.portrayed by: self-portrait, c.1835, lithograph; Louis Boulanger, 1837, oil painting, Louvre
nodes.bibliography: Fayos Pérez 2024; Chazal, Goya graveur, 2008

nodes.label: Motte
nodes.profession: lithographer (one of the first ones in Paris: 1817), draughtsman, printer, engraver (etching)
nodes.works as: lithographic printer: Paris, 13 rue des Marais, Faubourg St. Germain (1818-1830); Lonodn, 23 Leicester Square (1830-31); London, 29 Bedford Street, Covent Garden (1829-1830); London, 70 St.Martin's Lane (1831)
nodes.participates in: The Salon (1827; 1831); Paris, 290 rue Saint Honoré (1831)
nodes.students: Laurent Imbert (who would import the lithographic technique to China)
editor of: Satirical prints in the 1820s, such as Eugène Delacroix's 'Le Déménagement de la Censure' in Le Miroir (1822)
Carricatures espagnoles, Ni plus ni moins, par Goya (1825)
Goethe's Faust (1827-28), illustrated by Eugène Delacroix, with a cover by Achille Devéria
Histoire lithographiée du Palais Royal (1834), illustrated by Horace Vernet
nodes.author of: Napoleon visitant l'atelier de David (1820-1830); Le traité de Tolentino s'exécute (1820-1830)
nodes.link to Goya's work: Motte edits Carricatures espagnoles, Ni plus ni moins, par Goya in 1825, with 10 lithographies after the Caprichos made by Achille Devéria
nodes.parents: Pierre Martin Motte (veterinary) and Ursule Durupt
nodes.children: Céleste Motte (married to Achille Devéria)
nodes.image source: AI generated (DeepAI) because there is no known portrait

nodes.label: Nanteuil
nodes.profession: painter, draughtsman, lithographer (etching, lithography, woodcut), illustrator, museum curator
author of: Covers for his friends: Théophile Gautier's Albertus and Les Jeunes-France; four covers for the edition of Victor Hugo's works (1832); Alexandre Dumas père's Impressions de voyage : de Paris à Cádiz (1846), Angèle and the 1st edition of Théâtre.
Contributes to the illustrations of Furne's edition of the work of Honoré de Balzac.
Advertisement for Honoré Daumier's Cent et un Robert-Macaire (1839).

Lithography: Rabelais (1836) after Eugène Delacroix; reproductions after Titian, José de Ribera, Velázquez and others to illustrate an anthology of paintings of the Royal Museum in Madrid (Prado) by Juan José Martínez (Madrid, 1857).
Woodcut illustrations in the 1840s.
Paintings: he was awarded at the Salon in 1837, 1848, 1861 and 1867. An example is Un rayon de soleil (1848, Musée de Valenciennes).
nodes.studied in: École nationale supérieure des beaux-arts de Paris (from 1827)
nodes.works as: director of the Académie des Beaux-arts (1867); curator at the Musée des Beaux-arts de Dijon
nodes.participates in: the Battle of Hernani (1830)
nodes.founder of: the journal Les Artistes contemporains (1843-1847) with lithographers Eugène Prosper Leroux, Adolphe Mouilleron, and painters Henri Baron and Louis Français
nodes.decorations/awards: Chevalier de la Légion d'honneur (1868)
curiosities: His parents belonged to the circle of Joseph Bonaparte.
He was hoplessly in love with the famous actress Marie Dorval.
nodes.portrayed by: Nadar, 1873 (photograph)
nodes.bibliography: Henri Béraldi, 1890, 'Les graveurs du XIXe siècle : guide de l'amateur d'estampes modernes', Paris, L. Conquet

nodes.label: Fontaney
nodes.participates in: the 1830 Revolution
nodes.in Spain: 1830-1831, accompanying the Duke d'Harcourt (Eugène d'Harcourt), ambassador of France in Spain
nodes.works as: secretary of the French embassy in Madrid [1830]
nodes.author of: Ballades, mélodies et poésies diverse (1829); <'Scènes de la vie castillane et andalouse' (article series in Revue des Deux Mondes)
nodes.collector of Goya's works: Caprichos (1830-1831)
shows Goya: 8 Sept 1831: 'Evening at l'Arsenal; Mélanie, Louise [Soulié] were there. I showed them the Goya' (ed. Jasinski 1925, p.31).

9 Nov 1831, at Belloc's: 'I am going to Mmes Belloc [Louise Swanton-Belloc], Mlle de Montgolfier [Adélaïde de Montgolfier]. (...) (Auguste) Blanqui the conspirator with a long white beard, (Jean-Alexandre) Plocque; (Auguste) Barthélémy;--a fat man who states in regard to Goya: It is not lacking in verve' (p.71).
nodes.partners/lovers: Gabrielle Dorval (daughter of the actress Marie Dorval). They flee together to Spain and England (where he falls sick with phthisis)
nodes.pseudonyms: Lord Feeling (from the Scottish writer Henry Mackenzie)
curiosities: He was (unhappily) in love with Marie Nodier.
After dying of phthisis, both Hugo and Sainte-Beuve forget their recent fallout and attend his funeral.
nodes.bibliography: Fontaney's journal: Fontaney-Jasinski 1925

nodes.label: Hugo
nodes.profession: author, essayist, novelist, playwright, poet, politician
author of: Art criticism: Preface of Cromwell (play) (1827).
Poetry: Les Orientales (1829): illustrated by Louis Boulanger; Les Feuilles d'automne (1831); Torquemada (1869).
Plays: Hernani (1830): takes place in Spain; Marion Delorme (1831); Le roi s'amuse (1832: forbidden); Ruy Blas (1838).
Novels: Le Dernier jour d'un condamné (1829); Notre-Dame de Paris (1831); Les Misérables (1862).
nodes.works as: Peer of France (1845-48); Member of the National Assembly for Seine (1848-51); Member of the National Assembly for Gironde (1871); Senator for Seine (1876-1882)
nodes.member of: Société des gens de lettres (founded by Louis Desnoyer), of which were also members George Sand, Alexandre Dumas and Honoré de Balzac. Académie française (1841-1885)
nodes.political views: as a Pair de France in the Upper Chamber of Parliament (1845), he spoke against the death penalty and social injustice, and in favour of freedom of the press and self-government for Poland. With Napoleon III's seize of power in 1851, he declared him a traitor to France and moved to Brussels, then Jersey, then the Channel Islands, where he was in exile 1855-1870. However, he justified colonialism in terms of a civilising mission, although he was an abolitionist of slavery. During the Paris Commune, he was very critical of both sides. He was also famously anticlerical.
nodes.in Spain: In 1811 (at 9 years old)
nodes.address: 90 rue Vaugirard (later no.88); 11 rue Notre-Dame-des-Champs (later no.27), very close to Achille Devéria
nodes.portrayed by: Jean Alaux (1825; Maison Victor Hugo 253); Achille Devéria, lithograph (1829); Josef Danhauser, Liszt am Klavier, 1840, oil painting, group portrait with Dumas, George Sand, Marie d'Agoult, Liszt, Paganini and Rossini (with Beethoven's bust and Byron's portrait), Alte Nationalgalerie, F.V.42; Charles Hugo, photograph (c.1853-55); Étienne Carjat, photograph, 1875; Nadar, photograph, c.1884
nodes.studies in: Real Colegio de San Antonio de Abad (Madrid); Lycée Louis le Grand (Paris)
nodes.children: Léopold Hugo, Léopoldine Hugo, Charles Hugo, François-Victor Hugo, Adèle Hugo
nodes.parents: Joseph Léopold Hugo and Sophie Trébuchet
curiosities: On 10 July 1816, he wrote in his diary: 'I shall be Chateaubriand or nothing'.
He frequented spiritism during his exile, and participated in séances conducted by Madame Delphine de Girardin (Delphine Gay).
When asked in 1872 if he was a Catholic, he answered, 'No. A Freethinker'.
Notre-Dame de Paris was listed as a 'forbidden book' by the Church.

nodes.label: Gautier
nodes.founder of: SNBA (Société Nationales de Beaux-Arts) with Louis Martinet in 1862. The committee included Eugène Delacroix, Carrier-Belleuse and Puvis de Chavannes. Among the exhibitors were Léon Bonnat, Jean-Baptiste Carpeaux, Charles-François Daubigny, Gustave Doré and Édouard Manet
nodes.address: Hôtel de Fourcy (1828-1834); impasse du Doyenné (current Place du Carrousel), near Camille Rogier, Arsène Houssaye and Nerval. He shares an apartment with Eguène Piot
nodes.partners/lovers: Carlotta Grisi (dancer), who leads in Gautier's ballet Giselle (1842)
nodes.children: Théophile Gautier fils, Judith Gautier, Estelle Gautier
nodes.parents: Jean-Pierre Gautier and Adélaïde Cocard
author of: Essays: Les Jeunes-France (1833); 1840 Spanish trip essays in La Presse, reedited as Tra los montes (1843) and as Voyage en Espagne (1845). 1843 August: Gautier, ‘La Tauromachie’, Le Musée des familles, pp. 341–48.13 Illustrated with seven drawings by Gautier (signed ‘T. G.’) engraved by ‘A.B.L’ (Andrew, Best and Leloir) (see Fayos Pérez 2024); Histoire du romantisme (1874). A volume of articles published as Les Grotesques. A biography of Honoré de Balzac. Art criticism: musicians (Berlioz, Gounod, Wagner) and painters (Delacroix, Manet, Gustave Doré, Théodore Chasséirau, Goya).
Fiction: La Cafetière (1831); Mademoiselle de Maupin (1835); Militona (1847), set in Madrid; Les deux étoiles (184); Roman de la momie (1857); Capitaine Fracasse (1861-63)
Poetry: La Comédie de la Mort (1838); España (1845); Poésies complètes (1845); Émaux et Camées (1852)
Theatre: Une larme au diable (1839)
Libretti: Giselle (ballet; 1841)
nodes.trips: Belgium and Holland (1836: with Nerval); Spain (1840); Algeria (1845); Spain (1846); Italy (1850); Greece and Turkey (1852); Russia (1858); Egypt (1869)
mentions of Goya: 1831-IX-8 Albertus
1832-VIII-5, Onophrius Wphly, La France littéraire, pp.388-418: 'El sueno de la razon produce monstruos. Goya' (Capricho 43)

1834 preface of Mademoiselle de Maupin: 'Quant au genre monstre, vous savez comme ils l’ont traité (...) Ni les grands traits à la Michel-Ange, ni les curiosités dignes de Callot, ni les effets d’ombre et de clair à la façon de Goya, rien n’a pu trouver grâce devant eux' (pp.34-35)
1838-VII-5, Les Caprices de Goya; (La Presse): mentions Goya's Album B of drawings?

1842 ‘Franco Goya y Lucientes’, Le Cabinet de l’Amateur, pp.337–45: Gautier acknowledges here the Disasters of War, over 20 years before they were published by the RABASF (1863); he must have known them via Eugène Piot and Carderera. For this article, Gautier has Carderera's help (Lanzarote Guiral 2016, p.550)
1845 mentions Disasters of War (Voyage en Espagne, nouvelle édition révue, p.136) [quoted by Valentín Carderera in 1863] (Fayos Pérez 2024).

1855 Les Beaux-arts en Europe: 'L'Espagne a oublié Velasquez, Ribera, Murillo, Zurbaran et même Goya; elle ne peint plus avec sa sombre palette d'autrefois des moines au froc brun [...] elle n'a plus cette ardeur farouche, cette passion catholique qui la caractérisaient [...]' (p.8)

1874 Histoire du romantisme: 'Victor Hugo, s’il n’était pas poète, serait un peintre de premier ordre ; il excelle à mêler, dans des fantaisies sombres et farouches, les effets de clair-obscur de Goya à la terreur architecturale de Piranèse'; '[...] cette entente des terreurs nocturnes qu’on ne rencontre que dans les Caprices de Goya'; '[Louis Boulanger] Tantôt c’était Rubens, tantôt c’était Véronèse, et puis Titien ; d’autres fois, franchissant les monts, il allait à Velasquez et à Goya'.
in Spain: He first knows Spain through Alfred de Musset's Contes d'Espagne et d'Italie (1829) and Victor Hugo's Les Orientales (1829)
In 1840, with Eugène Piot, watches Hugo's Hernani (translated by Eugenio Ochoa; Gautier praises the translation)
In 1846, invited by Louis-Philippe, to the wedding of the Duke of Montpensier with the Infanta Luisa Fernanda
nodes.studies in: Lycée Louis-le-Grand (1820); Lycée Charlemagne, where he meets Gérard de Nerval (Gérard Labrunie)
nodes.writes in: La Chronique de Paris, La Presse (of Émile Girardin) (editor until 1855), L'Artiste, Le Moniteur universel (from 1855), Le cabinet de l'amateur, Le Figaro, L'Univers illustré, Revue nationale et étrangère
nodes.decorations/awards: Officier de La Légion d'honneur
nodes.member of: Société héliographique (1851); Jeune-France; Société nationale des beaux-arts
nodes.participates in: the Battle of Hernani (1830); Les Français peints par eux-mêmes (1840)
knows Goya's works: The Caprichos: in late 1830-late 1831 (Lipschutz 1972, p.118). Through Antoine Fontaney? (brought a Caprichos set in January 1831)

Disasters of War: at least since 1842 (Cabinet de l'Amateur, with Eugène Piot and Frédéric Villot). He regains interest in this series in 1871 when he writes a necrological piece on Regnault, and he borrows Burty's working-proof set (through Asselineau)
nodes.collector of Goya's works: Bulls of Bordeaux; Tauromaquia (lot 66, 24-25 Feb 1873 sale): sold Sotheby's Paris, 14 Dec 2022, lot 37 (showing Valentín Carderera's dedicatory to Gautier); Tauromaquia set given by Valentín Carderera on 13 Nov 1859 (Lanzarote Guiral 2016, p.431)
nodes.portrayed by: Auguste de Châtillon, 1839, Musée Carnavalet (oil painting); Bertall, 1850 (photograph); Amédée Bodin after Théodore Chassériau, 1850 (drawing); Nadar, photographs, 1850, 1854-55 (Getty), 1855, 1856; Albert-Ernest Carrier-Belleuse, 1862 (sculpture: bust); Hippolite Mailly, 1862 (caricature); André Gill, 1869, L'éclipse (caricature)
nodes.bibliography: Fayos Pérez 2024; Lanzarote Guiral 2016; Lacoste-Veysseyre 2014; Hovasse 2001; Moulinat 1995; Lacoste-Veysseyre 1982; Delesalle 1982

nodes.label: Espronceda
nodes.works as: secretario de la Legación española en La Haya (1836); dputado por Almería; member of the Cortes Generales with the Partido Progresista (1842)
in Paris: In 1830, where he participated in the Revolution.
In 1841-1842, at least 27 Dec-18 Jan (he meets Carderera) (Lanzarote Guiral 2016, pp.91-93).
nodes.political views: liberal
nodes.portrayed by: José María Esquivel, oil painting, 1842, Prado
nodes.bibliography: Lanzarote Guiral 2016

nodes.label: Houssaye
nodes.profession: homme de lettres, writer, journalist, literary critic, poet, art collector
nodes.literary salon or tertulia: 'mardis' (Tuesdays) at Av. de Friedland, attended by Zola among others.
nodes.curiosities: he leaves his parents home in 1832 to leave the 'Bohemian life' in Paris (with Gautier, Nerval, Jules Janin and Alphones Esquiros)
nodes.writes in: L'Artiste (director in 1843): with Champfleury, Baudelaire and others; La Presse (director); La Revue des Deux Mondes; La Revue de Paris; Revue du XIXe siècle (director in 1866); La Gazette de Paris (1870)
nodes.founder of: La Gazette de Paris (1870); La Revue de Paris et de Saint-Pétersbourg (1887)
nodes.children: Edmée Houssaye; Henry Houssaye; Albert Houssaye
nodes.works as: Administrateur général de la Comédie-Française (1849-56); inspecteur des musées de province (1857); inspecteur général des beaux-arts (1863); Président de la Société des gens de lettres (1884-85)
nodes.portrayed by: Gill, caricature, 28 June 1868; Étienne Carjat, photograph, c.1878

nodes.label: Mallarmé
nodes.children: Geneviève Mallarmé-Bonniot; Anatole Mallarmé
nodes.influenced by: Théophile Gautier; Victor Hugo; Théodore de Banville; Charles Baudelaire (Les fleurs du mal)
curiosities: His L'Après-midi d'un faune (1865-76) would inspire Claude Debussy for his symphonic piece (1894). Maurice Ravel was also inspired by Mallarmé (Trois poèmes de Mallarmé (1913).
He meets Oscar Wilde and Paul Valéry in 1891 in pont de Valvins
nodes.works as: teacher at Lycée Condorcet, Lycée Janson-de-Sailly, Lycée Jacques-Decour, Lycée Rollin (1885-93)
nodes.decorations/awards: he gives conferences at Cambridge and Oxford in 1894. Then holds the Taylorian Lecture.
nodes.portrayed by: Manuel Luque, caricature as a faun in Les hommes d'aujourd'hui, 1887; Nadar, photograph, c.1890 and 1896
nodes.author of: first poems published in 1862; a translation of Edgar A. Poe's 1845 The Raven (Corbeau) in 1875, illustrated by Édouard Manet; 1888 translation of Poe's poems
nodes.archives: Archives départementales des Yvelines (166J, Ms 11890-11891, 13238, 3s, 1890-1890); Bibliothèque littéraire Jacques-Doucet

nodes.label: Balzac
nodes.author of: La Comédie humaine (1831-50), including La peau du chagrin (1831), which mentions Murillo and Velázquez; Le Chef-d'œuvre inconnu (1831); Les Cent Contes drolatiques (1832-37); Eugénie Grandet (1834); Le Père Goriot (1835).
nodes.participates in: Les français peints par eux-mêmes (1840) (ed. Léon Curmer), alongside Théophile Gautier, Alexandre Dumas, J. J. Grandville, Honoré Daumier and Paul Gavarni; J. J. Grandville's Scènes de la vie privée et publique des animaux (1842), alongside Charles Nodier and George Sand.
nodes.member of: Société des gens de lettres (founded by Louis Desnoyer), of which were also members Victor Hugo, Alexandre Dumas and George Sand
works as: New owner of La Chronique de Paris, journal politique et littéraire in 1835, published from January to July 1836, with important names like Hugo and Gautier. Illustrations by Henry Monnier, Grandville and Daumier.
President of the Société des gens de lettres (1839-1840)
nodes.masters: François Guizot; Abel-François Villemain; Victor Cousin
nodes.political views: ambiguous. A legitimist during the July Revolution (1830). He declares himself a liberal. Defends the working class. While expressing some conservative ideas, his work was admired by Marx and Engels, and reflects some elements close to Anarchism. Inspired by Saint-Simon.
nodes.writes in: Revue des Deux Mondes, La Presse, Le Constitutionnel, Le Siècle, La Caricature
nodes.studies in: Lycée Charlemagne (1814-18); Sorbonne Université (from 1816); Faculté de Droit (1816-19)
nodes.pseudonyms: Horace de Saint-Aubin, Lord R’Hoone, Viellerglé, Saint Aubin
nodes.portrayed by: Achille Devéria (attributed), c.1825, wash drawing, [Maison de Balzac](https://www.parismuseescollections.paris.fr/fr/maison-de-balzac/oeuvres/portrait-de-balzac-17#infos-principales) BAL 780; Achille Devéria, c.1829, [drawing](https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Honor%C3%A9_de_Balzac#/media/Fichier:Achille_Dev%C3%A9ria_-_Portrait_de_Balzac.jpg); Louis Boulanger, 1836, oil painting, [Louvre-Tours](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Balzac_(par_Boulanger).jpg); Louis-Auguste Bisson, 1842, daguerrotype; Nadar, drawing, 1850, [BnF](https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Honor%C3%A9_de_Balzac#/media/Fichier:Dessin_de_Nadar_1850.jpg); Eugène Giraud, 1850, Balzac in his death bed, Besançon.
nodes.partners/lovers: Henirette de Maillé de La Tour-Landry; Laure de Berny (1823-1833); Olympe Pélissier; Maria du Fresnay (desde 1833); Caroline Marbouty (1833-1839)
nodes.parents: Bernard-François Balzac and Anne-Charlotte-Laure Sallambier
nodes.children: Marie-Caroline du Fresnay
nodes.decorations/awards: Chevalier de la Légion d'Honneur (1845)

nodes.label: Dumas
nodes.author of: Henri III et sa cour (1829) (play); Les Trois Mousquetaires (1844) (novel); Le Comte de Monte-Cristo (1844-46) (novel); La Reine Margot (1845), Impressions de voyage : de Paris à Cádiz (1846).
nodes.participates in: Les Français peints par eux-mêmes (1840)
mentions of Goya: 1837-V-28 28 ‘[…] Goya, ce fantaisiaque [sic] élève de Tiepolo le Vénitien, avec lequel est mort la grande peinture espagnole, et qui dans ses compositions, dont la vérité a fait des satires, a tout attaqué: moines, nobles et rois’ (p. 2). About the Galerie espagnole: ‘[…] doté la France d’un trésor qui allait être perdu pour le monde, et rapporté pour 800,000 francs, quatre cents tableaux qui valent trois millions’ (p. 2) ‘Feuilleton: M. le Baron Taylor en Espagne’, La Presse, 1–2 [digitised in Gallica]
