1845-I-16 'C’était un spectacle à la fois lugubre et bizarre, que tous ces élégans [sic] seigneurs et toutes ces belles dames défilant comme une procession, peinte par Goya, au milieu de ces squelettes noircis et de ces gibets aux longs bras décharnés’ (‘Feuilleton: La Reine Margot, second volume’, La Presse, pp.1–3) [digitised in Gallica]

1849-V-3 ‘On dirait une de ces gravures de Goya, où, dans la demi-teinte, des arracheurs de dents font la chasse aux pendus’ (‘Feuilleton: Les mille et un fantomes’, Le Constitutionnel, p.1) [digitised in Gallica] (see Fayos Pérez 2024).
nodes.in Spain: October 1846 to January 1847, accompanied by his son Alexandre and his collaborator Auguste Maquet. He writes Impressions de voyage : de Paris à Cádiz (1846), illustrated by Nanteuil. In the same trip he goes to Algeria
nodes.portrayed by: Joseph Guichard, 1828 (Louvre); Achille Devéria, c.1829; Achille Devéria, c.1832 (lithography published by Charles Motte); Josef Danhauser, Liszt am Klavier, 1840, oil painting, group portrait with George Sand, Hugo, Marie d'Agoult, Liszt, Paganini and Rossini (with Beethoven's bust and Byron's portrait), Alte Nationalgalerie, F.V.42; Cham, 1846 (caricature); Gouin, 1852 (photograph); Nadar, 1855 (photograph); William Henry Powell, 1855 (oil); Gustave Le Gray, c.1859 (photograph); Cham, 1860 (caricature); André Gill, 2 Dec 1866 (caricature); Alphonse Liébert, 1867 (photograph).
nodes.parents: Marie-Louise Labouret and Thomas Alexandre Davy de La Pailleterie
nodes.children: Alexandre Dumas fils; Henry Bauër
nodes.curiosities: despite having all the merits for it, Dumas père was never accepted as a member of the Académie française, most likely due to racism. Only his son Alexandre Dumas (fils) was accepted in 1874
nodes.bibliography: Dumas-Schopp 2014

nodes.label: Nodier
nodes.writes in: La Quotidienne (1821-1830): he presents the work of Walter Scott, Rabelais, Marot, Lamartine, Byron and Victor Hugo; Revue des Deux Mondes; Revue de Paris (from 1829)
nodes.participates in: J. J. Grandville's 'Scènes de la vie privée et publique des animaux' (1842), alongside Honoré de Balzac and George Sand
nodes.political views: favourable to the French Revolution (Société des amis de la Constitution; Club des Jacobins), but also Royalist. Essentially against despotic power.
nodes.works as: librarian of the comte d'Artois, future Charles X. He lives at the Arsenal (Bibliothèque de l'Arsenal), where he holds a literary salon known as a 'cénacle' (mentioned by Dumas as a place where all the big names of Romantic literature were present). Dismissed by Polignac in July 1830, then reinstated by Louis-Philippe when the Library passed to the state in August.
nodes.portrayed by: Paulin Guérin; lithograph in Cénacle de la Muse française (1827)
nodes.author of: Smarra ou les Démons de la nuit (1821): of massive influence in the Romantic generation; Infernalia (1822); Trillby ou le lutin d'Argail (1822); Examen critique des dictionnaires de la langue française (1828); Le Vieux Marinier (1832).
nodes.editor of: Adèle, Mélanges de littérature et de critique and Lord Ruthwen ou les Vampires by Cyprien Bérard
nodes.founder of: the Bulletin du bibliophile, with the bookseller Techener (whose collection included a set of Goya's Caprichos in the 1841 sale)
nodes.children: Marie Antoinette Mennessier-Nodier
nodes.parents: Antoine-Melchior Nodier (speaker: oratorien)
nodes.member of: Académie française (1833-44); Académie des sciences, belles-lettres et arts de Besançon et de Franche-Comté; Société nationale des antiquaires de France
nodes.masters: Justin Girod de Chantrans (botanique, entomologie, minéralogie); Euloge Schneider (Greek); Joseph Droz
nodes.decorations/awards: Chevalier de la Légion d'honneur (1822)
nodes.address: 4, rue de Provence (from 1822)
nodes.curiosities: in 1797 he was member of a secret society called the Philadelphes. Later, he was a member of the 4th society of Caveau (1834-39) ('société bachique'), dedicated to drinking, singing and literature.

nodes.label: Custine
nodes.author of: 1838, 17 June (Le Temps) essay on Goya's works (signed as 'A. de C.')
nodes.mentions of Goya: Letter to Miss Bowles (13 April 1831): 'Un peintre espagnol moderne, Goya, mérite d’être cité, surtout pour ses portraits. En mourant il a emporté la gloire et le secret de l’école de son pays. Sa manière tenait à la fois de celle de Velasquez et de celle de Murillo'; 1838 essay ('A. de C.'): Goya's Caprichos, Disasters of War, Bulls of Bordeaux, Familia Carlos IV, frescoes and Black paintings.
nodes.bibliography: Fayos Pérez 2025-2026 (upcoming)

nodes.label: Montgolfier
nodes.knows Goya's works: by April 1831, through Fontaney (after his return from Spain in Jan 1831)
nodes.writes about Goya: In April 1831: signed as 'Ad. M' (Revue encyclopédique no.50, pp.316-331). Parts of her essay are plagiarised by male writers such as Gustave Brunet (1855, Revue Universelle des Arts) and Théophile Thoré (10 Sept 1842)
nodes.author of: she co-authored with Louise Swanton Belloc a number of children's books (Buell Hale 1874, p.583-84)
nodes.founder of: La Ruche, journal d'études familière (with Louise Swanton Belloc), a monthly magazine dedicated to the education of young women (Buell Hale 1874, p.583-84)
curiosities: Her father was the famous aeronaut Jacques-Etienne Montgolfier.
She was buried alongside her close friend Louise Swanton Belloc (and her son, Louis Belloc) at La Celle-Saint-Cloud.
nodes.bibliography: Sarah Josepha Buell Hale, Woman's Record: Or, Sketches of All Distinguished Women, 1874. [Google books](https://books.google.es/books?id=X7ZiAAAAMAAJ&vq=belloc+la+ruche&hl=es&source=gbs_navlinks_s)

nodes.label: Delphine Gay
nodes.profession: femme de lettres, writer, poet, novelist, playwright, salonnière, journalist
nodes.literary salon or tertulia: at Hôtel Marbeuf. Attendants: Théophile Gautier, Honoré de Balzac, Alfred de Musset, Victor Hugo, George Sand, Alphonse de Lamartine, Alexandre Dumas, Franz Liszt, Jules Janin, Fortunée Hamelin, Frédéric Soulié, Eugène Sue, Chateaubriand, Méry, Mlles Mars and Rachel (Challamel 1885). Circle of Charles Nodier
nodes.author of: Essais poétiques (1824), Nouveaux Essais poétiques (1825), Napoline (1833); Lettres parisiennes (1843). Fiction: Le Lorgnon (1832), Le Marquis de Pontanges (1835), Contes d'une vieille fille à ses neveux (1832), La Canne de Monsieur Balzac (1836), Il ne faut pas jouer avec la douleur (1853). Drames en prose: L'Ecole des journalists (1840), Judith (1843), Lady Tartuffe (1853). Comedies: C'est la faute du mari (1851), La joie fait peur (1854), Une femme qui déteste son mari (posthumous)
nodes.in Italy: in 1827, where she is enthusiastically welcomed in the Roman literary circle and crowned in the Capitol
nodes.pseudonyms: Vicomte Charles Delaunay, Charles de Launay, Vicomte de Launay, Léo Lespès, Léa Sepsel, Émile de Girardin
nodes.parents: Sophie Gay and Jean Sigismond Gay
nodes.portrayed by: Louis Hersent, 1824, château de Versailles (oil painting); LD, 'Une muse en 1848', Le Charivari, 15 December 1848 (caricature); anonymous, 1855 (photograph)
nodes.curiosities: her mother named her Delphine because of the homonymous novel by Madame de Staël
nodes.bibliography: Challamel 1885

nodes.label: Desbordes-V.
nodes.author of: Poésies; Les Pleurs (poems; 1833); Violette (novel); L'Atelier d'un peintre (1833; autobiography)
nodes.member of: Académie des sciences, belles-lettres et arts de Lyon (1835)
nodes.works in: théâtre de l'Odéon; Opéra-Comique; théâtre de la Monnaie (Brussels), where she plays Rosina in Le Barbier de Séville (1815)
nodes.decorations/awards: Prix Lambert (1859)
nodes.portrayed by: Constant Joseph Desbordes, Douai, Musée de la Chartreuse, c.1811 (oil painting); Baugé, 1833 (lithograph); Nadar, 1854 (photograph)
nodes.parents: Catherine Lucas and Félix Desbordes
nodes.children: Louisa Desbordes, Marie-Eugène Desbordes, Junie Valmore, Hippolyte Valmore, Ondine Valmore, Inès Valmore
nodes.bibliography: Aimée Boutin & Catherine Witt, upcoming article in J'écris pourtant, 2025; Michel Suffran, Un chemin jusqu'à toi: Rencontre entre Goya et Marceline Desbordes-Valmore (1823-1827), 2013.

nodes.label: H. Allart
nodes.works as: governess in the household of General Bertrand
nodes.political views: enthusiastic supporter of Napoleon. She offered to travel to Saint Helena to nurse the former emperor
nodes.author of: Essai sur la religion intérieure (1824); Lettres sur les ouvrages de Madame de Staël (1824); Jerome (1829; novel): about her relations with Sampayo; Settimia (novel; 1836); La femme et la démocratie de nos temps (1836); Les enchantements de Prudence, Avec George Sand (1873): it had a 'succès de scandale'
nodes.partners/lovers: Comte de Sampayo; Gino Capponi?; George Sand?; François-René de Chateaubriand; Henry Bulwer Lytton (Lord Dalling)
nodes.married to: Napoléon Louis Frédéric Corneille de Méritens de Malvézie (1843: only one year)
nodes.children: Marcus
nodes.parents: Nicolas-Jean-Gabriel Allart and Marie-Françoise Gay
nodes.portrayed by: Sophie Allart (her sister), Rome, 1829, Châtenay-Malabry, Maison de chateaubriand (oil painting)
nodes.curiosities: her mother translated the works of English gothic author Ann Radcliffe.

nodes.label: A. Tastu
nodes.profession: femme de lettres, writer, poet, libretist
nodes.author of: poetry; pedagogical works; translations; Cours d'histoire de France (1837); a volume about German literature; a volume about Italian literature
nodes.works as: libretist for musicians such as Saint-Saëns (La Feuille de peuplier, Plainte, 1853)
nodes.member of: Société linnéenne de Paris (1822)
nodes.married to: Joseph Tastu (1816): works in the liberal publisher of the brothers Beaudouin, 36, rue de Vaugirard
nodes.parents: Jacques-Philippe Voïart and Jeanne-Amable Bouchotte; Anne Élisabeth Élise Petitpain (stepmother): femme de lettres at Nancy
nodes.children: Eugène
nodes.portrayed by: Constance Mayer, 1817, Metz, Musée de la Cour d'Or (oil on canvas)
curiosities: She was considered the Romantic muse par excelence.
After her husband's death, she follows her son to his diplomatic missions in Cyprus and Bagdad.
The rose 'Amable Tastu' was created in 1851 in her honour; with the initiative of the 'Amis d'Amable Tastu', a new 'Rose Amable' was created in 2018.

nodes.label: V. Ancelot
nodes.profession: femme de lettres, novelist, playwright, author, painter and salonnière
nodes.literary salon or tertulia: Hôtel de La Rochefoucauld-Liancourt, rue de Seine (from 1824 until her death): she hosts Victor Hugo, Sophie Gay, Delphine Gay, Mélanie Waldor, Rachel, Mme Récamier, Saint-Simon, Alfred de Musset, Stendhal, Chateaubriand, Lamartine, Alfred de Vigny, Mérimée, Delacroix
nodes.parents: Thomas Chardon and Barbe Edmée Chardon
nodes.children: three
nodes.curiosities: her great-grandson Jean Sangnier (1912-2011) was a member of the Résistance
nodes.portrayed by: Jean Gigoux, 1839, lithograph (Galerie de la presse); François-Joseph Heim, Andrieux faisant une lecture dans le foyer à la Comédie Française en 1828, 1847, Château de Versailles (detail)
nodes.studies in: Convent of the Ursulines, Paris (1802-1806)
nodes.participates in: the Salon: 1814 (début) La Veuve du Roi Ban and some portrait; 1819 Henri IV et Catherine de Médicies; 1828 Une lecture de M. Ancelot (portraying many writers of the time)
author of: Painting: La Veuve du Roi Ban (1814); Portrait de Jacques-François Ancelot (1819); Henri IV et Catherine de Médicies (1819); Une lecture de M. Ancelot (1828)

Theatre: Mariage raisonnable (1835); Marie, ou Trois Époques (1836, Théâtre-Français: her biggest success); Juana, ou le Projet de vengeance (1838, Théâtre du Vaudeville); Pierre le millionnaire (1844, Th. Vaudeville); Un jour de liberté (1844, Th. Vaudeville); Les Femmes de Paris, ou l'Homme de loisira (1848, Th. de la Gaîté), among others
Novels: Gabrielle (1839: reprinted and translated); Émerance (1843); Renée de Varville (1853); La Nièce du banquier (1853); Les Deux Sœurs (1866), among others
Essays: Les Salons de Paris, foyers étients (1858); Un salon de Paris: 1824 à 1864 (1866)

nodes.label: M. Nodier
nodes.profession: femme de lettres, writer, novelist, composer, poet
nodes.author of: Sonnet à Mélanie Gaume (1830); Mélodies romantiques (1831); 'Lettres d'une hirondelle à une serine élevée au Couvent des oiseaux', in J. J. Grandville's Scènes de la vie privée et publique des animaux (1842); Charles Nodier, épisodes et souvenirs de sa vie (1867)
nodes.correspondence: vol. 1 (1821-1848), II (1849-1892), III (Lettres à Marie), in 2019, 2020 and 2021 respectively
nodes.portrayed by: Jean Gigoux, Musée de Besançon, 902.6.1 (oil painting); Hyppolyte Masson, 1838, coll. Mennessier-Nodier (drawing)
nodes.children: Georgette, Emmanuel, Thècle, Marie-Victoire
nodes.parents: Charles Nodier and Désirée Charve
nodes.curiosities: a royal order allows them in 1844 to name their children 'Mennessier-Nodier'

nodes.label: G. Sand
nodes.profession: writer, novelist, journalist, salonnière, art critic, playwright, libretist, composer
nodes.works in: Revue des Deux Mondes, La Revue indépendante, Revue de Paris, Le Figaro, La Mode, Le Temps
nodes.in Spain: 1808-1809 her family lived in Spain at the palace of Manuel Godoy when this one was exiled in Paris
nodes.mentions of Goya: Journal intime, 25 Nov 1834 (jealousy over Goya's women regarding Alfred de Musset)
nodes.author of: Voyage chez Mr. Blaise (1829); Voyage en Auvergne (1829); Voyage en Espagne (1829); Un hiver en Majorque (1841); La Petite Fadette (1849); Histoire de ma vie (1855). Album of drawings. Clumsy copy of Velázquez’s Infanta Margarita. Collection Lovenjoul Chantily [now at Institut de France? (Lipschutz 1972, p.117)
nodes.participates in: J. J. Grandville's 'Scènes de la vie privée et publique des animaux' (1842), alongside Charles Nodier and Honoré de Balzac.
nodes.member of: Société des gens de lettres (founded by Louis Desnoyer), of which were also members Victor Hugo, Alexandre Dumas and Honoré de Balzac.
nodes.parents: Maurice Dupin de Francueil and Sophie Victoire Delaborde
nodes.partners/lovers: Prosper Mérimée; Jules Sandeau; Alfred de Musset (1833-35); Félicien Mallefille; Hortense Allart?; Marie Dorval?; Frédéric Chopin; Victor Borie (1848-49); Alexandre Manceau (1849-64)
nodes.children: Maurice Sand; Solange Sand
nodes.portrayed by: Marie-Aurore de Saxe (her grandmother), pastel drawing, 1810, Musée de la vie romantique; François-Auguste Biard, Portrait de Goerge Sand et de son époux, le baron François Casimir Dudevant, c.1823, oil on canvas, Musée George Sand; Thomas Sully, oil on canvas?, 1826, Johnson Collection, Spartanburg, South Caroline; self-portrait, c.1830, Musée Carnavalet; Alfred de Musset, 1833, drawings, Bibliotèque de l'Institut de France (MsE956-fol.4, fol.7, fol.14, fol.16, fol.17, fol.20); Delacroix, 1834, oil on panel, Musée Delacroix; Jean-Baptiste Isabey, c.1835; Charles Louis Gratia, pastel drawing, c.1835, private collection; François Théodore Rochard, c.1835; Auguste Charpentier, oil painting, 1838, Musée de la Vie romantique; Delacroix, oil sketch, 1838, Copenhague; Josef Danhauser, Liszt am Klavier, 1840, oil painting, group portrait with Dumas, Hugo, Marie d'Agoult, Liszt, Paganini and Rossini (with Beethoven's bust and Byron's portrait), Alte Nationalgalerie, F.V.42; Thomas Couture, 1850, drawing; Nadar, photograph, c.1864, [Getty](https://www.getty.edu/art/collection/object/1098NS)

nodes.label: Burty
nodes.profession: art critic, art collector, artist, lithographer, draughtsman
nodes.works as: art critic in different journals; inspector at the Académie des Beaux-Arts (1881); art dealer and advisor for art dealers such as Frederick Keppel
member of: Société des aquafortistes (founded in 1862), directed by Alfred Cadart
Société japonaise du Jinglar (1867)
Union centrale des beaux-arts appliqués à l’industrie
nodes.parents: father: Marin Burty, silk merchant and owner of fashion business during the Restoration
nodes.masters: Chabal Dussurgey, painter of flowers at the Gobelins manufactory
nodes.children: Madeleine (who marries the porcelain maker Charles Edward Haviland)
editor of: Illustrated albums: Sonnets et eaux-fortes (1869), edited by Alphonse Lemerre, gathering 42 painters-engravers and 42 poets; L'Eau-forte en... (1874-1881, ed. Alfred Cadart) [Gallica](https://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/btv1b8527609t); Japonisme (1883), a series of prints by Félix Buhot, from the Burty collection (Paris, Edmond Sagot); L'Âge du romantisme, illustrated album edited with Maurice Tourneux (Monnier, 1887)

Art criticism: La Photographie au Palais des beaux-arts (1859); Catalogue de tableaux et dessins de l'école française, principalement du XVIIIe siècle, tirés de collections d'amateurs (1860); Chefs-d'œuvre des arts industriels (1866); Notice des études peintes par M. Théodore Rousseau exposées au Cercle des arts (1867); Les émaux cloisonnés anciens et modernes (1868); Eaux-fortes de Jules de Goncourt : notice et catalogue (1876); Maîtres et petits maîtres (1877). He writes, among many other artists, about Degas, Gustave Moreau, Puvis de Chavannes, Jules Bastien-Lepage, Camille Pissarro, Théodore Rousseau, Pierre Paul Prud'hon, Millet
The correspondence of Eugène Delacroix: 1st edition, 1878 [Gallica](https://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k205063z); 2nd edition, revised and expanded, 1880
nodes.author of: Les Émaux cloisonnés anciens et modernes (1868); Maîtres et Petits Maîtres (1872); essay on Edgar Degas exhibition, 'Fine Art: The Exhibition of the Intransigeants', Academy, 15 April 1876; Grave Imprudence (1880, novel)
nodes.writes in: Gazette des Beaux-arts (since 1859); Le Rappel (in 1871 during the Paris Commune)
nodes.political views: 'Dedicated Republican and networker'; 'herald of modernity and stimulated reflections on the renewal of the arts in France' (AGORHA). During the Paris Commune in 1871, he wrote in Le Rappel and supported Gustave Courbet's Fédération des artistes
nodes.portrayed by: Étienne Carjat, 1873, photograph; Carolus-Duran, 1874, oil painting, Allen Memorial Art Museum (Ohio); Marcellin-Gilbert Desboutin, 1875, drawing, BNF, Dép. Estampes, FOL-EF-415 (I, 1)
sales: Burty II: 27 March 1874 (lot 14: 2 black pencil drawings by Delacroix after Goya, 13 fr.)

Burty III: 27 April 1876 (Sotheby's London; 56 lots of Goya (nos.444-465, 684-719), which included Caprichos, Tauromaquia, Proverbios (Disparates), and a working-proof edition of Disasters of War as lot 465 (British Museum [1876,1111.335](https://www.britishmuseum.org/collection/object/P_1876-1111-335). In 1877, Théophile Gautier asked to see Burty's working-proof set of the Disasters (Delesalle 1983, p.104), but this set was acquired the year before, in 1876
Burty V (2-3 March 1891): lot 83 4 pen drawings by Delacroix after Goya
Burty VI (4-5 March 1891): Tauromaquia, Desastres, Proverbios, Agarrotado, drawing
nodes.collection: Charles Meryon, Goya, Théophile Chauvel, Michel Manzi, Félix Bracquemond, Eugène Delacroix, Decamps, Édouard Manet, Gericault, (school of) Rembrandt (drawing Landscape with Two Mills, Met 41.21.1), Millet, Jacquemart
collector of Goya's works: Burty acquired 11 sheets of drawings by Delacroix after Goya at the Delacroix sale in 1864: lot 640 'Études d'après Goya: onze feuilles de croquis' (Robaut 1885, p.476, no.1962). Those that have been located are catalogued in Fayos Pérez 2024, Appendix III

The Metropolitan Museum holds several prints by Goya that belonged to the Burty collection: from Disparates, 'Funereal Folly' (private printing c.1854) [31.79.2](https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/333961), 'Flying Folly' (private printing c.1854) [32.78.3](https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/333981), 'Dancing Giant' (private printing c.1854) [31.79.1](https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/397761), another 'Dancing Giant' (published 1854-63) [21.54.1](https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/333833), 'Folly of Fear' (published c.1848) [21.54.2](https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/333834); A Maja standing against a dark background with figures, 1859 [23.37.6](https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/333866), The cloaked man (1859) [23.37.5](https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/333865); La Tauromaquia (1816) [21.19.1-34](https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/333828); a former attribution to Goya, Portrait of a Young Man (c.1820) (British Museum; another impression at the Metropolitan, ex-Villot

The British Museum holds [29 prints and drawings](https://www.britishmuseum.org/collection/search?keyword=Goya&keyword=Burty) by or after Goya from the Burty collection (Burty sales II and III), including a drawing by Delacroix after Goya (see Fayos Pérez 2024, Appendix III, D34, p.464)
curiosities: Burty coined the term 'japonisme' in 1872.
He was the grandfather of the photographer Paul Haviland and of the painter Frank Burty Haviland.
nodes.decorations/awards: medal of the Order of the Rising Sun (1884): a rare honor for a non-Japanese person (INHA)
nodes.bibliography: Fayos Pérez 2024; P. Weisberg, The Independent Critic: Philippe Burty and the Visual Arts of Mid-Nineteenth-Century France, 1993; Delesalle 1983; P. Weisberg, The Early Years of Philippe Burty: Art Critic, Amateur and Japoniste, 1855-1875, 1967; Robaut 1885

nodes.label: Bracquemond
nodes.considered as: promoter of the study of Japanese art in France, from 1856; also of the interest in printmaking, encouraging artists such as Édouard Manet, Edgar Degas and Camille Pissarro to use this technique (Monneret 1987, p.74)
nodes.registered in: the Cabinet des estampes (BNF) as reader in 1849, alongside Henri Fantin-Latour and Gustave Doré (Lethève 1968, p.109)
member of: Société des aquafortistes: from 1862 (founding member). Established by Alfred Cadart and Félix Chevalier; also joined by Fantin-Latour, Édouard Manet, Johan Jongkind and Alphonse Legros (Wolohojian & Dunn 2023, p.277).
Société japonaise du Jinglar (from 1867): with Fantin-Latour, Carolus Duran, Marc-Louis Solon, Alphonse Hirsch, Jules Jacquemart, Zacharie Astruc, Philippe Burty.
Société nationale des beaux-arts (1890): he encourages foreign artists (particularly Japanese) to exhibit at the Salon des beaux-arts
Société anonyme des artistes peintres, sculpteurs et graveurs: from 1874
Société des peintres-graveurs français: honorary president (1890)
Société des peintres-lithographes: honorary president (with his friend Auguste Rodin)
participates in: The Salon: 1852 with Portrait de ma grand-mère (compared to Hans Holbein the Younger by Théophile Gautier); 1853 with Autoportrait with his printmaking tools

The 1st Salon des Beaux-arts in 1864 (26 boulevard des Italiens): works by Édouard Manet, Charles-François Daubigny, Félix Bracquemond, Gustave Doré, Jean-Baptiste-Camille Corot and Pierre Puvis de Chavannes

Première exposition des peintres impressionnistes (1874): at Nadar's workshop. He presents a drawing portrait, etching portraits of Auguste Comte, Baudelaire and Théophile Gautier, etchings after Turner (The Locomotive, 1873), Ingres and Manet, and original etchings like Les Saules and Le Mur. He exhibits again with the Impressionists in 1879 and 1880 (Portrait d'Edmond de Goncourt)
nodes.founder of: L'Estampe originale with Auguste Lepère, Daniel Vierge and Tony Beltrand (in 1888). From the 1870s he was thinking of creating a journal focused on printmaking with Degas, Camille Pissarro and Mary Cassatt
nodes.friends: Edmond de Goncourt (from 1856); Charles Baudelaire; Théodore de Banville; Jules Barbery d'Aurevilly; Félix Nadar; Édouard Manet; James McNeill Whistler; Henri Fantin-Latour: Bracquemond appears in his Hommage à Delacroix (1864, Orsay); Auguste Rodin
nodes.works as: ceramist and designer at the Manufacture nationale de Sèvres (from 1870); artistic director at the workshop of Charles Edward Haviland in Limoges
nodes.parents: César Auguste Bracquemond and Jeanne Girardine Bailly
nodes.married to: Marie Bracquemond, née Marie Quivoron (1869), Impressionist painter
nodes.children: Pierre Bracquemond
nodes.masters: Joseph Guichard (student of Ingres); Théodore Deck
nodes.students: Alexandre Jean-Baptiste Brun; Louis Busière; François Courboin; Léon Coutil; Édouard Dammouse; Lucien Dautrey; Fernand Desmoulin; Jeanne Sisley; Henri Jean Turlin
nodes.decorations/awards: Chevalier (1882) Officier de la Légion d'honneur (1889). Médaille d'honneur du Salon (1884)
nodes.copies after Goya: Don Quixote (F.54), 1860, for Carderera's article in Gazette des Beaux-arts (Fayos Pérez 2024, p.164, fig.II.42)
author of: Portraits: Paul Meurice, Charles Méryon (1853), Alphonse Legros (1861), Zacharie Astruc (c.1865), Édouard Manet (1864, pastel; 1867 etching), Edmond de Goncourt (1882); Woman's head (1897-99, L'Estampe moderne).

After other artists: Jean-Louis-Ernest Meissonier, Gustave Moreau, Jean-Baptiste Camille Corot, Eugène Delacroix (Les Natchez, 1835, Met), Moreau (Le roi David, 1884: awarded at the Salon). Also after Titian and Diego Velázquez (Infanta Margarita, 1872)

Original compositions: Broderie (c.1855), L'Inconnu (1862), L'éclipse (1869), La Terrasse de la villa Brancas (1876), Le grand lapin (1891), Roseaux et sarcelles (1882), Les Hirondelles (1882), Landscape (colour lithograph, 1885); The Monkey and the Cat, from the Fables of La Fontaine (1886); Les Mouettes (1888)
Essays: Du dessin et de la couleur (1886), very appreciated by Vincent van Gogh (Monneret 1987, p.76); Étude sur la gravure sur bois et la lithographie
nodes.portrayed by: Paul Adolphe Rajon, 1852, etching; Nadar, 1865, photograph; Paul Adolphe Rajon (etcher), etching, 1878 (after Bracquemond) (Met 63.625.15).
nodes.bibliography: Jean-Paul Bouillon, Félix Bracquemond et les arts décoratifs, 2005; Monneret, L'Impressionnisme et son époque, 1987; Lethève 1968; Henri Beraldi, 'Félix Bracquemont', in Les Graveurs du XIXe siècle. Guide de l'amateur d'estampes modernes, volume III, Paris, Librairie L. Conquet, 1885
nodes.curiosities: Bracquemond learnt most of his technical knowledge from the Encyclopédie by Diderot and d'Alembert

nodes.label: Mantz
nodes.parents: Godefroy Mantz and Mathilde Vignes
nodes.children: Marguerite-Mathilde Mantz (1853-1933)
nodes.studies in: Paris: Law (1839)
nodes.writes in: L'Artiste (from 1844; chief editor 1849-52), L'Événement (founded by Victor Hugo; from 1848), La Vraie République (founded by Théophile Thoré; from 1848); Gazette des Beaux-Arts (founded by Charles Blanc; from 1859); Le Temps (from 1873); La Revue française
nodes.friends: Théophile Thoré, Charles Blanc (and his brother Louis Blanc), Philippe de Chennevières. 'Il se lie ainsi à un groupe d'homme de lettres qui partagent les mêmes convictions et joueront un rôle capital dans sa carrière' (INHA)
nodes.writes about Goya: 'Francisco Goya', Archives de l’art français, I, 1851-1852, pp.319-320

nodes.author of: 'Catalogue raisonné de l’œuvre gravé de Fran(co) Goya y Lucientes', Le Cabinet de l’Amateur, 1842 (pp.346-366): Caprichos (80), Tauromaquia (33), Disasters of War (‘Scènes d’invasion’) (20/82), prints after Velázquez (14), Pièces diverses (Garrotted Man), Lithographs (Bulls of Bordeaux) (6); L'Italie monumentale (1851): photographic album (for which he receives an award at the Exposition universelle 1855)
nodes.editor of: Le Cabinet de l'amateur et de l'antiquaire (1842-1846)
nodes.sales: 12 April 1847: Caprichos (bought by 'Bauzonnet'?), Tauromaquia (lots 29-30); 1848; 1850; 1857 and 1858 (dedicated to Egyptian, Greek and Roman antiquities); 1864; 1870; 1876; 1885, 22 rare proofs of Caprichos with handwritten inscriptions, acquired by BNF [Fayos Pérez 2024, p.55]; 1890 (posthumous)
nodes.mentions of the Prado commentaries: On his catalogue raisonné 1842 (Capricho 50):  Carderera’s diary (2 August 1861) shows he lent them to Piot, but he must have known them by 1842, having copied them in Madrid, or during one of Madrazo’s trips to Paris?
nodes.founder of: Le Cabinet de l'Amateur, illustrated by artists such as Eugène Delacroix and Ernest Meissonnier
nodes.member of: Société de l’histoire de France (1843); Société de l’histoire de Paris et de l’Île-de-France (1874-1881); Société nationale des antiquaires de France (1843); l’Institut archéologique de Rome (1865); Académie de Saint-Ferdinand [RABASF?] (1873)
nodes.address: Impasse du Doyenné, from 1835-36 (sharing an apartment with Théophile Gautier); 20, rue Saint-Fiacre; 64, rue de Courcelles (after 1860)
nodes.decorations/awards: he receives an award (médaille de première classe) at the Exposition universelle 1855 for the photographic album entitled L'Italie monumentale (1851)
curiosities: In his 1840 trip to Spain, Piot took photographs of the Burgos cathedral.
There was a Prix Eugène Piot at the Académie des Beaux-Arts (established in his will in 1889) until 1984.
nodes.bibliography: Garnery 2023; Bonnafé 1890; Piot 1999; Courajod 1890

Navarro in 'Arte compacto', episode on José de Madrazo, 27 April 2025).

nodes.label: Brunet
nodes.author of: Fantaisies bibliographiques (1864)
writes about Goya: 1855 Review of Charles Le Blanc’s Manuel de l’amateur d’estampes (Paris, P. Jannet), where Brunet laments the absence of Goya’s Tauromaquia (33 plates) and Scènes d’invasion (i.e. Disasters of War; 20 known plates). ‘Les Caprichos, ces étincelantes caricatures, en disent plus sur l’Espagne que tous les voyageurs; elles sont bien ce qu’aurait fait Rabelais s’il avait manié le crayon, un Rabelais espagnol bien entendu, sérieux et dont la plaisanterie fait frémir […]. On pourrait ajouter qu’à Paris ils se sont payés 150 et 130 francs, aux ventes Sampayo et Saint-Morys’ (p.385). In the footnote, Brunet mentions some key publications on the Caprichos: Gintrac’s lithography of ‘un des plus charmants caprices de Goya’ in L’Artiste, Gautier’s essays in L’Artiste (1845), the article in Le Revue Encyclopédique [1831, Adélaïde de Montgolfier], and Viardot’s Musées d’Espagne (‘Bulletin bibliographique’, Revue Universelle des Arts, vol.1, pp.384–86). Brunet here is plagiarising Adélaïde de Montgolfier (1831), whose article on Goya he quotes on the footnote but without mentioning her name or indicating that is was a quotation
1865 Étude sur Francisco Goya sa vie et ses travaux : notice biographique et artistique

nodes.label: Yriarte
nodes.works as: inspector of government buildings (by 1856); reporter for Le Monde Illustré during the Spanish campaign in Morocco ('Guerra de África'); editor of Le Monde Illustré in 1862

It mentions, among other works, the Caprichos, the Proverbes (Disparates), and Album A-B (p.93). It mentions Count of Floridablanca, Count of Aranda, and Manuel Godoy (Prince de la Paix)

nodes.id: José de Salamanca y Mayol (I Marqués de Salamanca)
nodes.label: Salamanca
nodes.studies in: Universidad de Granada
nodes.political views: worked as a politician for the Partido Moderado
in Paris: In 1841: a trip to look for support with the Spanish external debt. He meets with María Cristina de Borbón, who was there in exile, and Narváez (Partido Moderado)
In 1849: he goes into exile for 16 months, until amnesty is given by Narváez
In 1854: he goes into exile for the second time
In 1867: he celebrates his first art sale
nodes.works as: politician, senator, businessman (railway and banking)
nodes.art collection: it included 19 paintings attributed to Velázquez, also to Goya, from the Flemish, Dutch and Italian schools. He has acquired some of these works from the sales of the collections of the Marquis of Leganés and of the Infante Luis de Borbón
nodes.aristocratic titles: I Marquis of Salamanca; I Count of Los Llanos; Grandee of Spain (Grande de España)
nodes.portrayed by: anonymous, drawing; anonymous, photograph
sales: 1867-VI-5 (Paris): more than 200 paintings, artworks and furniture. It included a work by Goya (Femme à l'éventail) (1806-07), and El Greco's La Purificación del Templo, now at the Washington National Gallery of Art
1869 (Sotheby's): pieces acquired by the British Museum; Pieces by José Madrazo
nodes.collector of Goya's works: Femme à l'éventail (1806-07) (1867 sale, lot 177): Musée du Louvre, RF 1132 [https://collections.louvre.fr/ark:/53355/cl010064756]
curiosities: His residence in Madrid, the Palace of the Marquis of Salamanca, now belongs to the BBVA Foundation, where there are two works by Goya: a portrait of Carlos III as a hunter (c.1786), and the portrait of Don Pantaleón Pérez de Nenín (1808).
He gives his name to the Neighbourhood of Salamanca (Barrio de Salamanca) in Madrid, where he refurbished 14 blocks.

Berlioz considers her music 'virile, forte et neuve'.

nodes.label: Baudelaire
nodes.friends: Charles Asselineau
nodes.author of: Salons (1845, 1846, 1859); Les Fleurs du mal (1857)
writes about Goya: 'Quelques caricaturistes étrangers. Hogarth, Cruikshank, Goya, Pinelli, Brueghel’, Le Présent, vol.2, pp.185–94. This essay also appeared in L’Artiste (26 September 1858, 55–59), in Curiosités Esthétiques (1868) and in Œuvres complètes (1869). Transcribed in Fayos-Pérez 2024, Appendix II, p.344

‘Quelques caricaturistes français’, in Curiosités Esthétiques (1868): ‘Goya, lui aussi, s’est attaqué à la gent monastique. Je présume qu’il n’aimait pas les moines, car il les a faits bien laids; mais qu’ils sont beaux dans leur laideur et triomphants dans leur crasse et leur crapule monacales! [...]' (Fayos Pérez 2024, p.342; Baudelaire – Le Dantec & Pichois 1961, p.997)
nodes.mentions of Goya: letter of 22 Feb 1864 (probably to Charles Yriarte), where he discusses a prospective publication and his previous writings on Goya, and mentions the publications on this artist by Théophile Gautier and Eugène Piot (letter sold in [Autographes des siècles](https://www.autographes-des-siecles.com/produit/charles-baudelaire-revient-a-ses-travaux-sur-francisco-de-goya/))
nodes.curiosities: he dedicated his Fleurs du mal (published in 1857) to Gautier ('au poète impeccable'). However, when he was condemned for this work, Gautier remained silent and did not defend him publicly (Les Fleurs du mal, ed. Livre de poche, p.345). Baudelaire was helped, though, by Empress Eugenia de Montijo, to reduce the fee he was sentenced to pay.
nodes.bibliography: Fayos Pérez 2024; Chagniot 2016; Baudelaire – Le Dantec & Pichois 1961

nodes.label: Regnault
nodes.address: rue de Rome
nodes.in Madrid: in 1868, with his colleague Auguste Laguillermie. He witnesses the Carlist War, General Prim's victory, and Isabel II's exile
nodes.in Spain: he visits the Alhambra of Granada, which makes a profound impact on him. He also visits Morocco with his friend Georges Clarin

Franco-Prussian War in 1870-71, where he dies
nodes.decorations/awards: Prix de Rome (1866): for Thétis apportant à Achille les armes forgées par Vulcain
nodes.parents: father: Henri Victor Regnault
curiosities: He was represented by the famous art dealer Paul Durand-Ruel.
Camille Saint-Saëns dedicates him a Marche héroïque (1871).
author of: Thétis apporte à Achille les armes forgées par Vulcain, 1866; Portrait de Madame Mazois sur son lit de mort , 1866; Automédon ramenant les coursiers d'Achille des bords du Scamandre, 1868, Boston

Spain-related: Berger des montagnes de la Castille, 1868, Musée de Pau; Juan Prim. 8 octobre 1868, 1869, Orsay; Salomé, 1870, Metropolitan; Exécution sans jugement sous les rois maures de Grenade, 1870, Orsay; Head of a Moor, 1870. Gautier states (Salon of 1870): 'Prim c'est toute l'Espagne, Salomé c'est tout l'Orient'
nodes.portrayed by: Self-portrait, c.1863, Clevelant Museum; Thomas Couture, c.1865, pierre noire et craie sur papier bleu; Michel Berthaud, c.1865, photograph; Nicolas Escalier; Carolus-Duran, Henri Regnault mort au champ de bataille, oil painting sketch (1871, Lille); Bocourt, 1874, drawing after a photograph (Le Magasin pittoresque); F. Levé, Mort d'Henri Regnault (Salon des artistes français de 1910). Bust of Henri Regnault at the Lycée Henri-IV

nodes.label: Manet
studies in: 1858, 25 Nov, he requests a carte de travail for the Bibliothèque Impériale (BnF), where many artists had copied Goya's Caprichos since the acquisition of the first set in 1827. By 1858 the Bibliothèque also had the other print series by Goya, acquired by Achille Devéria probably via Carderera (Fayos Pérez 2024, p...).
nodes.curiosities: Manet contracted syphilis
nodes.military activity: 1870 Franco-Prussian war: Manet (38), alongside Degas (36), is drafted into the Garde Nationale Sédentaire. They are both under the orders of Ernest Meissonier. November: he joins the artillery, following Degas. They have a conflict about the defence strategy of Paris.
nodes.literary salon or tertulia: attended by the Morisots and Degas, among others.
member of: Cénacle des Batignolles, from which emerges the Impressionist movement

Founding member of the Société des Aquafortistes, established by Alfred Cadart and Félix Chevalier; also joined by Fantin-Latour, Félix Bracquemond, Johan Jongkind and Alphonse Legros (Wolohojian & Dunn 2023, p.277).
trips: 1848 Rio de Janeiro. In the boat he draws caricatures of the crew, including his earliest surviving drawing Pierrot (Wolohojian & Dunn 2023, p.276).
1853 European tour to see the Old Masters: Kassel, Dresden, Prague, Vienna, Munich.
1872 Netherlands. Frans Hals Museum (Harlem) and the Rijksmuseum (Amsterdam).
nodes.in Spain: 1865, Aug-Sept: following an itinerary provided by his friend Zacharie Astruc. He was able to take the new train Paris-Madrid (via Irún), open on 15 Aug 1864. Manet visits the Prado (with Théodore Duret on 1 Sept) and the RABASF (to see Goya's works), and also goes to Toledo, Valladolid (where he sees San Pablo de Valladolid), Burgos and Hendaya. See Hansen 2021, [Bremen Kunsthalle](https://www.kunsthalle-bremen.de/en/view/exhibitions/exb-page/manet-and-astruc), and the related digital tool [Manets Spanienreise 1865](https://uploads.knightlab.com/storymapjs/60057410242989e7510095c3abd187e2/edouard-manets-spanienreise-1865/index.html) to follow Manet's itinerary in Spain.
nodes.visits the Prado Museum: Manet visits the Prado with Théodore Duret on 1 Sept 1865. He mentions it in a letter to Fantin-Latour (3 Sept 1865): 'Mon cher ami, que je vous regrette ici et quelle joie c'eût pour vous de voir ce Vélasquez qui à lui tout seul vaut le voyage... C'est le peintre des peintres; il ne m'a pas étonné mais m'a ravi. Le portrait en pied que nous avons au Louvre n'est pas de lui. L'infante seule ne peut être contestée [...]. les fileuses, le beau portrait d'Alonzo Cano, las Meninas (les nains), tableaux extraordinaire auxxi, ses philosophes, étonnants morceaux--tous les nains, un srutout assis de face les poings sur les hanches, peinture de choix pour un vrai connaisseur, ses magnifiques portrait, il faudrait tout énumérer, il n'y a que des chefs-d'œuvre... Et Goya, le plus curieux après le maître, qu'il a trop imité dans le sens le plus servile d'imitation. Une grande verve cependant. Il y a de lui au musée deux beaux portraits équestres dans la manière de Vélasquez, bien inférieurs toutefois. Ce que j'ai vu de lui jusqu'ici ne m'a pas plu énormément; je dois en voir ces jours-ci une magnifique collection chez le duc d'Ossuna... Je vais demain faire une excursion à Tolède. Là je verrai Gréco et Goya très représentés, m'a-t-on dit' (Tinterow 2003, p.293).
nodes.patrons: Paul Durand-Ruel: acquires artworks by Manet for the first time in 1872 (24 paintings for 35,000 fr.)
exhibitions: Paris Salon: 1859 rejection of Le Buveur d'absinthe; Chanteur espagnol (1860; Salon 1861: honorable mention); Olympe (1863; Salon 1865): vilified by the critics and public, defended by Zola, who loses his job; 1866 rejection of The Fifer (Orsay) and The Tragic Actor (Rouvière as Hamlet) (NGA); 1869 rejection of The Execution of Maximilian and prohibition of distributing his related lithograph (defended by Zola); The Balcony, The Luncheaon and 5 etchings (Salon 1869); Music Lesson and Eva Gonzalès (Salon 1870); The Battle of the US 'Kearsarge' and the CSS 'Alabama' (Salon 1872); Repose and Le Bon Bock (with unprecedented success) (Salon 1873); The Railway and Polichinelle (watercolor), rejection of The Swallows (Bührle) and Masked Ball at the Opera (NGA) (Manet is defended by Mallarmé); Argenteuil (Salon 1875); rejection of Laundry and The Artist (Marcellin Desboutin) (Salon 1876); Portrait of Faure as Hamlet (Salon 1877), rejection of Nana; Boating and In the Conservatory (Berlin) (Salon 1879); Antonin Proust and Chez le Père Lathuille (Salon 1880); M. Eugène Pertuiset, the Lion Hunter (2nd-class medal) and Portrait of M. Henri Rochefort (Salon 1881); Jeanne (Getty) and A Bar at the Folies-Bergère (Salon 1881). In 1870, he joins a committee that aims to reform the process by which the Salon jury is selected.
1863, 1 March, Galerie Martinet: 14 paintings, including Music in the Tuileries Gardens, Boy with a sword and Lola de Valence

1863, 15 May, opening of Salon des Refusés: Déjeneur sur l'herbe (Orsay), Mademoiselle V... in the Costume of an Espada, Young Man in the Costume of a Majo (Met), and 3 etchings, including an impression of Lola de Valence (Wolohojian & Dunn 2023, p.278).
1867 Manet organises a Salon des Refusés, without success.
1867 he opens a solo exhibition with 53 canvases and 3 etchings.
1872 Durand-Ruel exhibition in London: includes Young Lady in 1866, and works by Degas.
1880 Galerie La Vie Moderne: private exhibition of Manet's work, including 10 paintings, 15 pastels.
1884 retrospective exhibition, École des Beaux-Arts. Degas expressed regret that it was presented in these 'official galleries' (Blanche 1925, p.61).
1886 Durand-Ruel NY exhibition Works in Oil and Pastel by the Impressionists of Paris: 17 works by Manet.
1889 Exposition Centennale de l'Art Français, organised by Proust: 14 paintings, 1 watercolor, 2 pastels, 1 drawing and 5 prints by Manet.
1894 Galerie Vollard: Dessins et croquis de Manet, provenant de son atelier.
1900 Exposition Universelle and Exposition Centennale de l'Art Français: 12 paintings by Manet.
1905 Durand-Ruel, Grafton Galleries, London: 19 works by Manet.

Recent years: New York 2023, Manet/Degas; 2021-2022 Bremen, Goya and Manet: Revolutionary Etchings; Bremen 2021, Manet and Astruc: Friendship and Inspiration, [Bremen Kunsthalle](https://www.kunsthalle-bremen.de/en/view/exhibitions/exb-page/manet-and-astruc), curated by Dorothee Hansen; New York-Paris 2002-2003, Manet/Velázquez; Paris 1983, Manet, 1832-1883.
participates in: The Société Nationales de Beaux-Arts is founded by Théophile Gautier and Louis Martinet in 1862. The committee includes Eugène Delacroix, Carrier-Belleuse and Puvis de Chavannes. Among the exhibitors were Léon Bonnat, Jean-Baptiste Carpeaux, Charles-François Daubigny, Gustave Doré and Édouard Manet

The 1st Salon des Beaux-arts in 1864 (26 boulevard des Italiens): also participate Charles-François Daubigny, Félix Bracquemond, Gustave Doré, Jean-Baptiste-Camille Corot and Pierre Puvis de Chavannes
nodes.parents: Eugénie-Désirée Fournier and Auguste Manet
nodes.children: Léon Koelin-Leenhoff
nodes.friends: Edgar Degas; Fantin-Latour; Émile Zola; Edmond Duranty; Legros; Zacharie Astruc; Charles Baudelaire.
nodes.address: 4 rue Lavoisier (1856-58); 52 rue de la Victoire (from 1858); rue de l'Hôtel de Ville (from 1860; now rue des Batignolles), with workshop on rue de Douai; workshop on 81 rue Guyot (in 1861; now 8 rue Médéric); 34 Bv des Batignolles (from 1864); 49 rue de Saint-Pétersbourg (from 1866); huge atelier on 4 rue de Saint-Pétersbourg (1872); atelier on 77 rue d'Amsterdam.
nodes.collector of Goya's works: La tauromaquia (Cachin, Moffett & Wilson-Bareau 1983, p.239)
author of: PAINTINGS:Le Buveur d'absinthe (1859: rejected at the Salon; Copenhague, Ny Carlsberg Glyptotek); Monsieur and Madame Auguste Manet (painting, 1860); Monsieur Manet (The Artist's Father) (print, 1860); Chanteur espagnol (1860; Salon 1861: honorable mention) (Metropolitan); Portrait de M. et Mme Auguste Manet (1860, Orsay); Boy with a Sword (1861); Le Déjeuner su l'herbe (1862); Music in the Tuileries (NG/Hugh Lane Gallery Dublin); Lola de Valence (painting: 1862; Orsay); The Dead Toreador (c.1864); Le Christ mort et les anges (1864, Metropolitan); L'Homme mort (1864-65, Washington, National Gallery of Art): badly criticized by Théophile Thoré; Combat de taureaux (1865); Jesus Mocked by the Soldiers (Salon 1865; Chicago); Olympe (1863; Salon 1865); Reading (c.1866-73); Le Joueur de fifre (1866); Le Matador saluant (1866-67); L'Exécution de Maximilien (1867); Émile Zola (1868); The Balcony (1868-69); Eva Gonzalès (1869-70, London NG); Music Lesson (1870); Repose (c.1871); Berthe Morisot with a Bouquet of Violets (painting and print, 1872); Boating (1874); The Artist (Marcellin Desboutin) (1875); The Ham (c.1875-80); Stéphane Mallarmé (1876); Nana (1877); Woman with a Cigarette (c.1878-80, acquired by Degas in 1896), probably inspired by Mérimée's Carmen and the 1875 homonymous opera by Georges Bizet.
PRINTS:

ILLUSTRATIONS: Lola de Valence (1862 painting and 1863 print), to illustrate a poem by Zacharie Astruc; 1868 Fleur exotique, inspired by Goya, to illustrate a sonnet by Armand Renaud, published by Philippe Burty; 1875 illustrations for Poe's 1845 The Raven, translated by Mallarmé (Le Corbeau).
influences: Francisco de Goya. Example are On the Prado II (1863, etching and aquatint) (Tinterow 2003, p.393) and Fleur exotique (1868, etching and aquatint), an illustration for a sonnet by Armand Renaud, published by Philippe Burty, [Metropolitan 64.649.1](https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/337433)].

Diego Velázquez: to Fantin-Latour (3 Sept 1865): 'ce Vélasquez qui à lui tout seul vaut le voyage... C'est le peintre des peintres'. 'J'ai, dit-il essayé de faire un type de Paris en mettant dans l'exécution la naïveté du métier que j'ai trouvée chez Vélasquez' (Monneret 1987, p.478)
Italian painters such as Titian (copy after The Madonna of the Rabbit, c.1850-60), Filippino Lippi (copy after Portrait of the Artist, c.1857), Andrea del Sarto (copy after Standing Man, c.1853-57)
nodes.mentions: Edmond de Goncourt says about him that he was 'le distributeur de gloire aux génies de brasserie'.
link to Goya's work: 1863 Philippe Burty wrote in the Gazette des Beaux-arts that Manet's print Gitanos (Gipsies) (1862) gave the impression of 'seeking out Goya, at least in its general appearance' (Fayos Pérez 2024, p.188).
1863 Manet produces the Goyaesque print On the Prado II (1863, etching and aquatint) (Tinterow 2003, p.393).
1863 Paul Mantz called Manet 'a Spaniard in Paris' linked by 'a mysterious kinship [...] to the Goya tradition' (Fayos Pérez 2024, p.188).

1865, 3 Sept, letter to Fantin-Latour: '[...] Et Goya, le plus curieux après le maître, qu'il a trop imité dans le sens le plus servile d'imitation. Une grande verve cependant. Il y a de lui au musée deux beaux portraits équestres dans la manière de Vélasquez, bien inférieurs toutefois. Ce que j'ai vu de lui jusqu'ici ne m'a pas plu énormément; je dois en voir ces jours-ci une magnifique collection chez le duc d'Ossuna... Je vais demain faire une excursion à Tolède. Là je verrai Gréco et Goya très représentés, m'a-t-on dit' (Tinterow 2003, p.293).

1865, 17 Sept, letter from Manet to Astruc, after his Spanish trip: 'Deux hommes seulement, après le Maître (Velázquez), m'ont séduit là-bas : Greco dont l’œuvre est bizarre, des portraits fort beaux cependant (je n'ai pas été content du tout de son Christ de Burgos) et Goya dont le chef-d'œuvre se trouve, selon moi, à l'Académie (La Duchesse d'Albe, quelle saisissante fantaisie)' (Tinterow 2003, p.393; Cabañas Bravo 2003, p.495). Here, Manet wrongly assumes the Clothed Maja is the Duchess of Alba, one of many fabricated stories in 19th-century France about Goya.

1865, 13 Oct, letter from Manet to Théodore Duret: '[...] Ah mais j'espère bien que vos articles vont avoir une suite et que vous allez parler de l'Espagne au point de vue artistique et politique, Vélasquez, Goya, Greco à la rescousse !' (Tinterow 2003, p.393).
1867 Manet's L'Exécution de Maximilien are inspired by Goya's El 3 de mayo de 1808 en Madrid (Los fusilamientos) (1814) (Wilson-Bareau 1992).

1868 Manet's etching Fleur exotique, made to illustrate Armand Renaud's Sonnets et eaux-fortes seems to be a combination of Goya's Caprichos no. 5 and 15, both in style and technique (Fayos Pérez 2024, p.189).
1868-69 Manet's The Balcony is also probably inspired by Goya and Murillo.
interest in Spanish art: VELÁZQUEZ: upon his 1865 trip to Spain, Manet writes about Velázquez: 'ce Vélasquez qui à lui tout seul vaut le voyage... C'est le peintre des peintres' (letter to Fantin-Latour, 3 Sept 1865). Copies after Velázquez: Spanish Cavaliers (1859, Lyon), [Met](https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/892130); Spanish Studio Scene (Velázquez Painting) (c.1860, private coll.); The Infanta Margarita (1861-62) [Nationalmuseum Stockholm NMG 310/1924](https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/851751), whose copperplate is at the INHA (EM Manet 22).(Wolohojian & Dunn 2023, p.277; Tinterow 2003).

Manet produced many paintings and prints with Spanish-related topics: Le Chanteur espagnol (1860 painting; Salon 1861; 1861-62 print); Gitanos (1863 print); Lola de Valence (1862 painting and 1863 print), to illustrate a poem by Zacharie Astruc; An Incident in the Bullring (Salon 1864): later divided into The Dead Toreador and The Bullfight (Frick); Plainte Moresque: Portrait of Jaime Bosch (c.1866, lithograph); Le Matador saluant (1866-67); Woman with a Cigarette (c.1878-80, Princeton) [Met](https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/844738): probably inspired by Mérimée's Carmen and the 1875 homonymous opera by Georges Bizet.

Manet's portrait of Zacharie Astruc (1866, Bremen Kunsthalle), seems to follow the model established by Velázquez and the Flemish painters, with a clear division into two parts, and a double scene potraying a scene on the foreground (Astruc) and one on the background (showing a woman). It particularly reminds of Velázquez's Christ in the house of Martha and Mary (c.1618) at the London National Gallery.
Manet is also an admirer of El Greco.
knows Goya's works: Manet very likely knew Goya's print series before his trip to Spain in 1865 (at least Los Caprichos).

From his's correspondence we know that in 1865 he saw the Goya works at the Prado (equestrian potraits), which he did not particularly like, the Clothed Maja at the RABASF (wrongly identified as the Duchess of Alba), the religious painting in Toledo, and probably also the artworks at the Dukes of Osuna collection (Alameda de Osuna), following Astruc's itinerary.
nodes.decorations/awards: chevalier de la Légion d'honneur (1882)
nodes.portrayed by: Nadar, photographs, from c.1867 to c.1870-80 [Wikipedia](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/Category:Photographs_of_%C3%89douard_Manet_by_Nadar); Edgar Degas, drawings and prints c.1868-69 and Monsieur and Madame Édouard Manet (1869) (disliked by Manet); Fantin-Latour, 1870 (Un atelier aux Batignolles); Carolus-Duran, 1876, Rhode Island School of Design Museum (oil painting)
nodes.bibliography: Fayos-Pérez 2024; Wolohojian & Dunn 2023 (Manet/Degas); Tinterow 2003 (Manet/Velázquez); Cabañas Bravo 2003; Wilson-Bareau 1992; Monneret 1987; Cachin, Moffett & Wilson-Bareau 1983; Adhémar 1935; Blanche 1925, Manet; Proust 1897, Edouard Manet (Souvenirs).

nodes.label: Degas
nodes.profession: painter (from c.1855), engraver, draughtsman (from 1880), sculptor (from 1890), photographer (from 1890)
nodes.friends: Henri Rouart; Paul Valpinçon, Ludovic Halévy; Gustave Moreau (from 1858); Édouard Manet; Mary Cassatt; Louise Catherine Breslau; Madeleine Zillhardt; Pissarro; Caillebotte; Claude Monet; Suzanne Valadon
nodes.founder of: 1873 co-founder of the Société anonyme coopérative des artistes peintres, suclpteurs et graveurs (with Monet, Renoir, Sisley, Pissarro, Lepic and Morisot)
nodes.military activity: 1870 Franco-Prussian War: Degas (36), alongside Manet (38), is drafted into the Garde Nationale Sédentaire. They are both under the orders of Ernest Meissonier. Sept-Oct: he joins the artillery, followed by Manet. They have a conflict about the defence strategy of Paris.
nodes.address: 4 rue de Mondovi (1859, with his father); 13 rue Laval (from 1859; now rue Victor-Massé); Quartier Latin; workshop at 13, rue de Laval (from 1859);77, rue Blanche (from 1873); rue Lepic (from 1875); 21 rue Pigalle (1882); 6, Boulevard de Clichy (1912)
nodes.parents: Auguste de Gas and Célestine Musson
nodes.siblings: René
studies in: École des beaux-arts de Paris. In 1855, Fantin-Latour and him study under Louis Lamothe.

From 1853 he registers to make copies in the Cabinet des Estampes of the Bibliothèque Impériale (BnF), where many artists had been copying Goya's Caprichos since the acquisition of the first set in 1827.
1861, 1862 and 1868 he registers as copyist at the Louvre.
nodes.masters: Félix-Joseph Barrias; Louis Lamothe, disciple of Ingres (from 1855 to 1859); Paul and Hippolyte Flandrin; Léon Cogniet; Louis Lamothe
nodes.students: Ernest Rouart; Walter Sickert; Suzanne Valadon
nodes.patrons: Gustave Caillebotte; Paul Durand-Ruel: he acquires artworks by Degas for the first time in 1872 (3 paintings).
nodes.influenced by: Dominique Ingres; Eugène Delacroix. At the BnF he copies works by Dürer,  Mantegna, Veronese, Francisco de Goya and Rembrandt. He is also a copyist at the Louvre from 1853.
member of: Cénacle des Batignolles, from which emerges the Impressionist movement
Ligue de la patrie française (moderate, anti-Dreyfus)
nodes.political views: antisemitic (he broke up with his Jewish friends during the Dreyfus affair)
trips: 1856-59 Italy: Naples, Rome (1856-57), Florence, where he copies works by Michelangelo, Raphael and Titian. In Rome (Villa Medici) in 1858, he befriends Gustave Moreau.
1871 United Kingdom: he makes an exhibition, where Durand-Ruel acquired 3 artworks (1872).
1886 New York: 1st retrospective exhibition organised by Durand-Ruel.
1889, 8 Sept: Madrid. With Italian painter Giovanni Boldini (Reff 2020, letter 374, vol.1, pp.474-75, vol.3, p.125).
1889, 18 Sept: Tangier (following the steps of Delacroix). He returns to Paris via Cádiz and Granada.
1890 Brussels, The Hague, Antwerp, Haarlem, Rotterdam.
nodes.portrayed by: self-portrait, oil on paper, 1854-55, Orsay; self-portrait, c.1855, drawing (NGA Washington); Self-portrait, oil on paper, 1857-58, Clark; self-portrait, oil on canvas, c.1863 (Calouste Gulbenkian Museum, Lisbon); Apothéose de Degas, photograph (group portrait), 1885, (Orsay); Giuseppe Primoli, Edgar Degas sortant d'une vespasienne en 1889, photograph, 1889; self-portrait, photograph, 1895 (Harvard); Albert Bartholomé, photograph, 1915
author of: PAINTING: Autoportrait (1854-55, Orsay); Portrait de Mme Fèvre (1858-60, Orsay); La Famille Bellelli (1858-69, Orsay); At the Races: The Start (c.1860-62); Young Woman with Ibis (1857-58, 60-62); Femme assise à côté d'un vase de fleurs (Mme Valpinçon) (1865, Met); The Amateur (1866, Met); The Collector of Prints (1866); Mlle Marie Dihau (1867-68, Met); James-Jacques Joseph Tissot (c.1867-68); Interior (1868-69); La Repasseuse (c.1869, Neue Pinakothek Munich); L'Orchestre de l'Opéra (c.1870, Orsay); Les Blanchisseuses (c.1870-72, Le Havre); Hortense Valpinçon (1871, Minneapolis); Lorenzo Pagans and Auguste De Gas (1871-72); La Salle de ballet de l'Opéra, rue Le Pelletier (1872, Orsay); Trois Danseuses (1873, private coll.); La Classe de danse (1874, Orsay); L'Absinthe (1875-76, Orsay); Woman with Field Glasses (c.1877); Swaying Dancer (Dancer in Green) (1877-79, Thyssen, Madrid); The Singer with the Glove (1878, Fogg); Visit to a Museum (c.1879-80, Boston)

DRAWING: self-portrait, c.1855, drawing (NGA Washington); Self-portrait, oil on paper, 1857-58, Clark; Paysage de plage (1869, Albertina); Danseuse ajustant son chausson (1873, Met); The Singer (c.1877-78); Edmond Duranty (1879); L'Attente (1880-82, Getty); The Singer in Green (c.1884); Après le bain, femme s'essuyant (c.1884-86, Le Havre); Le Tub (1886, Orsay); Blue Dancers (1897, Pushkin). Caricatures of Napoleon III and Otto von Bismarck (Notebook no.21)

PRINTS: Self-portrait (1857); Marguerite De Gas, the Artist’s Sister (1860-62); Degas/Cassatt, Mary Cassatt at the Louvre: The Etruscan Gallery (1879-80). He starts experimenting with monotype in 1876. In 1879 he works on the project Le jour et la nuit, with works by Bracquemond, Caillebotte, Mary Cassatt, Forain, Pissarro, Raffaëlli, Rouart and Degas (which wouldn't come to fruition) (Wolohojian & Dunn 2023, p.284).

SCULPTURE: La Petite Danseuse de 14 ans (1879-81, Orsay); Grande Arabesque (1885-90, LACMA); Cheval à l'arrêt (Orsay); Le Tub (1888-89, Norton Simon Museum); La Danse espagnole (1885-1921), Ackland Art Museum, North Carolina.

PHOTOGRAPHY: Stéphane Mallarmé and Paule Gobillard in front of ‘Young Women in a Garden’ by Manet (1895); Self-portrait with Paul-Albert Bartholomé (c.1895-97); Après le bain, femme nue s'essuyant la nuque (1895-98, Orsay); Jeune femme se séchant après le bain (1896, Getty)
collector of: Manet: 3 prints in 1881 at the Duranty sale (likely 2 versions of The Little Cavaliers after Velázquez and Polichinelle); 3 artworks acquired in 1884 in the Manet sale (Portrait of Henri Vigneau, After the Bath and an impression of Civil War); in 1886 he acquires The Pear, which he hangs next to Ingres's Jupiter; he acquires The Ham from Michel Manzi; 1891 at the Burty sale he acquires 60 items by Manet (43 etchings, 13 lithographs, 4 transfer prints); 1894 he acquires Woman wiht a Cat from Vollard; 1894 acquires central portion of Execution of Maximilian from Vollard (he already had the right portion, and located a fragment of the left one); 1894 acquires drawing Gazaine before the War Council; 1895 acquires Gauguin's copy of Manet's Olympe; 1895 acquires from Vollard Portrait of M. Burn; 1896 acquires from Durand-Ruel Woman with a Cigarette (c.1878-80); 1897 acquires from Vollard Berthe Morisot in Mourning. The Degas sale included 8 paintings, >12 drawings and an almost complete set of prints.

Ingres; Delacroix (including drawings after Goya); Cézanne; Daumier (1,800 lithographs); Paul Gavarni; Corot; Sisley; Pissarro; Suzanne Valadon; Japanese printmakers (Kiyonaga, Sukenobu, Itamaro, Hokusai).
nodes.sales: 3. The first on 26-27 March 1918, Galerie Georges Petit. The other two, at Hôtel Drouot: 6-7 and 15-16 Nov.
interest in Spanish art: He copies works by Goya and Velázquez, such as The Infanta Margarita (c.1861-62, etching, Met 1997.240). This painting by Velázquez was also copied by Manet (who he meets, allegedly, in front of this painting at the Louvre), Renoir, Bracquemond and George Sand. See also Memory of Velázquez (c.1858, Neue Pinakothek Munich), [Met](https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/844730) (Wolohojian & Dunn 2023, p.277).
He also collects works by El Greco.
He produced the painting Lorenzo Pagans and Auguste De Gas (1871-72) and the sculpture La Danse espagnole (1885-1921, Ackland Art Museum, North Carolina).
nodes.link to Goya's work: the Degas collection included a Delacroix drawing after Goya (D21 and possibly D38 in Fayos Pérez 2024, pp.433 and 467)
curiosities: Degas allegedly met Manet for the first time in 1864 when they were both copying Velázquez's Infanta Margarita at the Louvre (Gordon and Forge 1988, p.23).
There is a rose 'Edgar Degas' from 1994, an asteroid (6673) and a crater in Mercury named Degas.
exhibitions: PARIS SALON: Scene of War in the Middle Ages (Salon 1865); Scene from the Steeplechase: The Fallen Jockey (Salon 1866); Family Portrait (The Bellelli Family) and The Bellelli Sisters (Salon 1867); Mme Camus (NGA) and Mme Théodore Gobillard (Yves Morisot) (Salon 1870). In 1867 he sends an anonymous letter to Le Figaro calling for a complete overhaul of the system of admission to the Salon. In 1870 he publishes a letter in Paris-Journal calling for the jurty to reconsider they way works of art are exhibited at the Salon (Wolohojian & Dunn 2023, pp.279, 280).
1872 Durand-Ruel exhibition in London: includes At the Races in the Countryside, and works by Manet.

IMPRESSIONIST EXHIBITIONS 1874-1886. 1st exhibition (1874): 10 works (receives favorable notices but exhibition is a failure of critics and public). 2nd exhibition (1876): 22 works including Le Bureau de boton à La Nouvelle-Orléans (1873, Pau); criticsed by Zola as too close to an illustration for an illustrated journal. 3rd exhibition (1877): 3 groups of monotypes and 23 paintings and pastels including Café-Concert at Les Ambassadeurs and In a Café (The Absinthe Drinker) (praised by critics). 4th exhibition (1879): 20 paintings and pastels, 5 fans. 5th exhibition (1880): 8 paintings (plus the portrait of Edmond Duranty, recently deceased) and pastels, 2 groups of drawings, a group of prints. 6th exhibition 1881 (disagreement with Caillebotte): 4 portraits and the sculpture La Petite Danseuse de 14 ans (1879-81). 7th exhibition 1881 (disagreement with Gauguin): doesn't participate. 8th exhibition 1886: 10 works, including a suite of pastel drawings of nudes.
1878 first work exhibited in North America: Rehearsal of the Ballet (11th Annual exh. of the American Water Color Society, NY).
1883 Degas refuses to have a solo exhibition at the Galerie Durand-Ruel, unlike Monet, Pissarro, Renoir and Sisley.
1886 Durand-Ruel NY exhibition Works in Oil and Pastel by the Impressionists of Paris: 23 works by Degas.
1892 Galerie Durand-Ruel: Degas's first solo exhibition. 26 landscapes and monotypes.
1896 his work enters for the first time a public collection through the Caillebotte donation.
1900 Exposition Universelle and Exposition Centennale de l'Art Français: 2 paintings by Degas.
1905 Durand-Ruel, Grafton Galleries, London: 35 works by Degas.

Recent years: Retrospective exh., 1988, Grand Palais & Ottawa; Degas, Sickert and Toulouse-Lautrec, 2005-06, London (Tate Britain) and Paris; Degas: Drawings and Sketchbooks, 2010, Morgan Library; Degas and the Nude (2011, Boston); exh. for the centenary of Degas's death, Orsay, 2018; Degas: A passion for perfection, 2018, Cambridge, Fitzwilliam Museum; Degas à l'Opéra, 2019, Orsay / NGA Washington; Manet/Degas, 2023, Orsay/Metropolitan
nodes.bibliography: Fayos Pérez 2024; Wolohojian & Dunn 2023; Dumas et al. 1997; Gordon and Forge, Degas, 1988; Werner, Degas Pastels, 1969.

nodes.label: Morisot
nodes.parents: Edmé Tiburce Morisot and Marie Joséphine Cornélie Thomas
nodes.siblings: Yves Elisabeth Morisot; Edma Morisot (painter)
nodes.children: Julie Manet
nodes.literary salon or tertulia: Morisot held soirées at her villa at 40, Rue de Villejust, attended by Caillebotte, Degas, Monet, Pissarro, Renoir, Duret, Malalrmé, Puvis de Chavannes, Fantin-Latour, Astruc, Corot, Manet, Whistler and Jules Ferry.
nodes.masters: Joseph Benoît Guichard, Édouard Manet, Camille Corot, Achille Oudinot
member of: Cénacle des Batignolles, from which emerges the Impressionist movement
Société anonyme des artistes peintres, sculpteurs et graveurs, founded in 1873 by Claude Monet, Auguste Renoir, Alfred Sisley, Camille Pissarro and Edgar Degas.
curiosities: Auguste Renoir recounted that a detractor of Morisot had called her a prostitute and that Camille Pissarro had punched him in the face, sparking a brawl.
Despite her prolific artistic output, her death certificate stated: ‘no occupation’.
Paul Valéry would marry her niece Jeanne Gobillard.
nodes.friends: Édouard Manet; Émile Zola; Stéphane Mallarmé; Camille Pissarro; Claude Monet; Auguste Renoir
nodes.author of: 416 oil paintings, 191 pastels, 240 watercolours, 8 engravings, 2 sculptures and 200 à 300 drawings. Edma Morisot lisant (1867, Clevelant); Jeune femme à sa fenêtre (Madame Pontillon) (portrait of Edma Morisot) (1869); La lecture or Madame Morisot et sa fille, Madame Pontillon (1869-70, NGA); Intérieur (1871); Femme et enfant au balcon (her sister and niece) (1872); Le Berceau (1872); Chasse aux papillons (1874, Orsay); Femme à sa toilette (1875); Eugène Manet à l'île de Wight (1875 Musée Marmottan-Monet); Femme en noir (Avant le théâtre) (1875, Tokyo); La Psyché (1876, Thyssen); Le Port de Nice (1881, Dallas); Bords de Seine (1883, Oslo); Dans la salle à manger (1886, NGA); Paule Gobillard (1886, Marmottan); bronze sculpture of Julie Manet's head (c.1886); Enfants à la vasque (1886, Marmottan); Le Flageolet (1890); Bergère nue couchée (1891); Julie et son lévrier (1893); Julie rêveuse (1894)
nodes.patrons: Paul Durand-Ruel: 1872 acquired works by Morisot via Manet; c.1875 Femme à sa toilette was sold to Hoschedé via Durand-Ruel
exhibitions: Paris Salon: Souvenir des bords de l'Oise and Un vieux chemin à Auvers (Salon 1864); Vue de Paris prise des hauteurs du Trocadéro (Salon 1867, Santa Barbara Museum); Vue de la rivière de Pont-Aven à Rozbras (Salon 1868): rejected by critics except by Zola; Jeune femme à sa fenêtre (Madame Pontillon) (portrait of Edma Morisot) and La lecture or Madame Morisot et sa fille, Madame Pontillon (Salon 1870); rejection of Intérieur (Salon 1872) (which enraged Puvis de Chavannes); Le Berceau (Salon 1872); Blanche (Blanche Pontillon) (1873)

Impresionnist exhibitions. 1st exhibition 1874: she is the only woman to participate, with Le Berceau, Le Port de Cherbourg, La Lecture, Cache-cache, and several pastels. 2nd exhibition 1876: Jeune fille au bal and La Psyché. She participated in all of them except in the 4th (1879) because she had recently given birth; Marie Bracquemond and Mary Cassatt did participate. 5th exhibition 1880: Jours d'été (1879, NG). 6th exhibition 1881: Morisot and Mary Cassatt emerged as the leaders of the new Impressionist trend in the eyes of critics; for the first time in the history of art, women were considered the undisputed masters of an avant-garde movement (Stuckey, Lindsay et al. 1987, p.88)
1883  Dowdeswell & Dowdeswell, London: she joins the exhibition of the Société des impressionnistes.
1886 New York by Durand-Ruel: Works in Oil and Pastel by the Impressionists of Paris.
1887 Brussels (Groupe des XX): she is invited to exhibit with a group of avant-garde artists. It also included Georges Seurat and Pissarro.
1887 Georges Petit: Exposition International de peinture et de sculpture.
1892 Galerie Boussod et Valladon (founded by Adolphe Goupil): first solo exhibition. Very successful.
1893 Anvers (probably the 2nd exhibition of the Association pour l'art).
1894 La Libre Esthétique (Brussels).
1896 Durand-Ruel: retrospective exhibition with >400 paintings, organised by Edgar Degas, Henri Rouart and Julie Manet.
1900 Centennial exhibition at Exposition Universelle: 3 figure paintings, 1 watercolor.
1907 Salon d'Automne: retrospective exhibition. 121 artworks from Ernest Rouart collection, and 53 from other collections.

Recent years: Paris 1961, Musée Jacquemart-André; New York / Paris 1987, Berthe Morisot : rétrospective au Mount Holyoke College Art Museum et National Gallery of art Washington (cur. by Elizabeth Kennan); Lausanne 1997; Lille 2002; Lodève 2006; Madrid, Museo Thyssen-Bornemisza, 2011-2012, [Berthe Morisot: The woman impressionist](https://www.museothyssen.org/en/exhibitions/berthe-morisot-woman-impressionist); Musée Marmottan 2012; Québec-Dallas-Paris (Orsay) 2018-19.
mentions: 1874 upon her participation in the 1st Impressionist exhibition, Le Figaro denounced them as 'alienated' (deranged), and as having revolutionary and dangerous tendencies, and Albert Wolff wrote about Morisot: 'Il y a aussi une femme dans le groupe comme dans toutes les bandes fameuses ; elle s'appelle Berthe Morisot et est curieuse à observer. Chez elle, la grâce féminine se maintient au milieu des débordements d'un esprit en délire'.

c.1875 the critic Arthur Baignières writes: 'Elle pousse le système impressionniste à l'extrême et nous le regrettons d'autant plus qu'elle possède des qualités rares comme coloriste. […] Mademoiselle Morisot est une impressionniste si convaincue qu'elle peut peindre jusqu'au mouvement de chaque chose inanimée'.
1877 Paul Mantz: 'Il n'y a, dans tout le groupe révolutionnaire, qu'une impressionniste, c'est Madame Berthe Morisot['.
Théodore Duret classified her within 'Le groupe primordial des impressionnistes'.
Huysmans criticised her style as morbid and hysterical sketches (Rey 1982, p.55).

c.1881 Paul Mantz: 'Madame Morisot ended up exaggerating her style to the point of blurring forms that were already imprecise. She only makes the beginnings of beginnings; the result is curious, but increasingly metaphysical. It obviously takes talent as a colourist to draw such delicacy out of nothingness' (Stuckey, Lindsay et al. 1987, p.88).
c.1881 Charles Ephrussi: 'One more step and it will become impossible to distinguish or understand anything'.

Gustave Geffroy: 'Les formes sont toujours vagues dans les tableaux de Mme Berthe Morisot, mais une vie étrange les anime. L’artiste a trouvé le moyen de fixer les chatoiements, les lueurs produites sur les choses et l’air qui les enveloppe… le rose, le vert pâle, la lumière vaguement dorée, chantent avec une harmonie inexprimable. Nul ne représente l’impressionnisme avec un talent plus raffiné, avec plus d’autorité que Mme Morisot'.

Paul Valéry wrote: 'La singularité de Berthe Morisot fut de vivre sa peinture et de peindre sa vie, comme si ce lui fut une fonction naturelle et nécessaire, liée à son régime vital, que cet échange d'observation contre action, de volonté créatrice contre lumière'.
Paul Valéry: 'Berthe Morisot’s uniqueness lies in the fact that she lived her painting and painted her life' (Madrid 2011-2012 exhibition, Thyssen).
nodes.trips: 1872 Spain; 1875 Isle of Wight; 1881 Italy; 1885 Belgium and Holland; 1886 Jersey
nodes.mentions of Goya: c.1872-73: 'We are going to Madrid, at least we think we are. I have written to Manet asking him for the address of Astruc who, I know, has been there for a fairly long time. He will be of great help to me, since he speaks Spanish aknows Madrid throughly, and he certainly will be able to point out to us the things worth seeing. He must feel about the Museum pretty much as I do. [...] We should give ourselves plenty of time to admire Velasquez and the Goyas. That is for me about the only interest in going...' [...] 'So far we have seen only the museum, which is magnificente, as you know. The city has no character [...] I have found the handsome Astruc; he has put himself entirely at our disposal for visiting the city, which he knows well. [...] I have no intention of exerting myself to see anything but paintings. Perhaps we'll go to Toledo, and come back here to see the bullfights, if we feel stouthearted enough' (Rouart 1959, pp.76-77).
nodes.portrayed by: Édouard Manet, Berthe Morisot (1872); Berthe Morisot au chapeau noir (1872, private coll.); anonymous, photograph, c.1877

Stuckey, Suzanne G. Lindsay et al., Berthe Morisot: rétrospective au Mount Holyoke College Art Museum et National Gallery of art Washington, 1987; The diary of Julie Manet 1987/1990; Sophie Monneret, L'Impressionnisme et son époque, 1987; Jean Dominique Rey 1982, Berthe Morisot; Marie-Louise Bataille & Guy Wildenstein 1961, Berthe Morisot, Catalogue des peintures, pastels et aquarelles; Denis Rouart 1959, The Correspondence of Berthe Morisot.

nodes.curiosities: he was deeply interested in music (Berlioz, Schumann, Wagner), and sought to transcribe it into painting and lithography.

author of: Paintings: Verre, gobelet en argent et coupe de champagne (1860, private coll.); La Liseuse (1861); Hommage à Delacroix (1864, Orsay); Asters et fruits (1868, Met); Un atelier aux Batignolles (1870, Orsay); Un coin de table (1872); Mr et Mrs Edwin Edwards (1875); La Lecture (1877, Lyon); Trois filles du Rhin (1876): transcribing music; Hommage à Hector Berlioz (1878, Grenoble); Portrait de Charlotte Dubourg (1882, Orsay); La Nuit (1897, Orsay).
Prints: >150 images of fantasy/oneiric nature, influenced by Symbolism.
member of: Cénacle des Batignolles (from 1863), from which emerges the Impressionist movement
Société japonaise du Jinglar (from 1867): with Carolus-Duran, Bracquemond and Solon.
Société des peintres-lithographes (from 1896).

nodes.masters: Louis-Alexandre Péron, Horace Lecoq de Boisbaudran; Théodore Fantin-Latour, Horace Lecoq de Boisbaudran
nodes.decorations/awards: Officier de l'ordre de Léopold (Belgium), 1894
exhibitions: Paris Salon: 1859 rejection of a self-portrait; 1861 La Liseuse; 1864 Hommage à Delacroix; 1866 still life; 1872 Un coin de table; 1880-87: portraits; 1897 La Nuit: success, acquired by the State.
1862 Royal Academy London: a still life.
1899 Exposition des maîtres vivants (Amsterdam).
nodes.mentions: Gustave Geffroy: 'La Nuit : jamais corps de femme ne reposa plus doucement dans un ciel de peinture sur les nuées souples et enroulées comme des vagues'.
nodes.portrayed by: self-portraits: 1859, Grenoble Museum; 1859, Lyon Museum; 1860, Fondation Bemberg, Toulouse; c.1860, drawing, Louvre; 1861, NGA; 1883 (Florence). Carolus-Duran, 1861, Met; Dornac, c.1890, photograph

nodes.label: Astruc
nodes.profession: art critic, poet, painter (from late 1860s), sculptor, art collector
nodes.copies after Goya: on his first visit to Spain in 1864, Astruc makes a small copy of The Clothed Maja at the RABASF (the Naked Maja was not on public display) (Maurer 2021, p.37).
in Spain: 1864 (3 months): influenced by the writings of Théophile Gautier and Victor Hugo ('forgèrent dans son esprit l’image d’une Espagne aux allures romantiques' [...] 'cette vision fantasmée, entre pittoresque et romantique, ne le quitta jamais'). On his first trip, 'il fut un peu déçu de constater le décalage entre la réalité et le songe hispanique qu’il avait à l’esprit. Il ne se démoralisa pas pour autant et visita minutieusement l’Espagne pendant trois mois. Il prit durant son séjour, et pendant tous les autres à la suite, quantité de notes et de dessins qui devaient servir un jour à écrire un livre sur l’Espagne' (Cantenot 2017, abstract). He visits the Prado, the RABASF, and probably the Alameda de Osuna (with Goya paintings), as he recommended Manet to visit it.
He helped Manet with his trip to Spain in 1865 (recommending him to go to Toledo, Segovia, El Escorial and the Alameda de Osuna among other places).

After the 1870 war, he spends long stays in Spain, accompanied by his family (in Madrid 1872-1873). He founds the journal L'Espagne nouvelle (1872) and makes a bronze copy of the sculpture of St. Francis of Assisi at the Toledo Cathedral (attributed to Pedro de Mena).
He meets Berthe Morisot during her 1872-73 trip to Madrid.

His 1878 sale catalogue (by Ernest Chesneau) says that his collection was formed not only in Paris but also during his frequent trips to England and Flanders, and during his long stays in Spain' (p.57).
author of: Painting and drawing: Scène de rue à Cuenca, watercolor (1873, Pau); Intérieur parisien (1874, Évreux); Fleurs dans un vase, watercolor (1884-1904, Met); Roses négligemment jetées sur un vase.

Sculpture: bronze copy of the St. Francis of Assisi at the Toledo Cathedral (1872), attributed to Pedro de Mena; Isabelle Astruc (bronze, 1877); François Rabelais; Madame Astruc en espagnole (c.1878, Salon des artistes français); Buste de Manet (1881); Portrait en buste de Manet (c.1883); Le Marchand de masques (1883, Jardin Luxenbourg): representing the faces-masks of Victor Hugo, Corot, Dumas, Berlioz, Carpeaux, Faure, Delacroix, Balzac and Barbey d'Aurevilly; sculpture of Blanca de Castilla (Musée Chartreuse).

Writing: Les Quatorze Stations du Salon (1859), with a preface by George Sand and an epilogue by Victor Hugo; Le Salon intime : Exposition au boulevard des italiens, Paris, 1860; a census of Japanese art collectors: Stevens, Villot (Louvre), Favard, Legros, Chesneau, Chempfleury, Solon, Bracquemond, Fantin-Latour, Burty, the Goncourt brothers, Manet, Lambron, Monet (26 May 1868); an essay on the artworks by female artists, titled 'Décaméron féminin' (L'Écho des Beaux-Arts, 26 June 1870, p.1-3); Romancero de l'Escorial (1883-84); Le Généralife, sérénades et songes (1897); Les Alhambras (poems) (1908).
nodes.friends: Carolus-Duran; Édouard Manet; Henri Fantin-Latour; Alphonse Legros
nodes.member of: Cénacle des Batignolles, from which emerges the Impressionist movement
exhibitions: Paris Salon: from 1869
Impressionist exhibitions: 1st one 1874
nodes.art collection: he acquires artworks since the 1850s. French (Oudry, Fragonard, Millet, Rousseau, Corot, Troyon, Prud'hon, Géricault, Monet), Spanish, English, Flemish and Dutch schools; contemporary pieces, Japanese art, sculpture, furniture.
interest in Spanish art: He wrote a song dedicated to the Spanish dancer Lola de Valence in 1863, printed with a reproduction of a painting by Édouard Manet (1862).
In 1873 he copies the St. Francis of Assisi at the Toledo Cathedral (attributed to Pedro de Mena).

His 1878 sale included several works from the Spanish school: 4 artworks attributed to Goya, 4 to El Greco (Le Rier, La Vierge et l'Enfant-Jésus, Adoration des bergers and Saint François d'Assise recevant les stigmates), a sketch attributed to Velázquez (Procession de la Vierge d'Atocha), and 3 Spanish earthenware vases.
He made Spanish-related artworks such as Toilette du toréro (1880, Musée des Beaux-Arts de la ville de Paris).
He also writes Spanish-related essays and poems: Romancero de l'Escorial (1883-84), Le Généralife, sérénades et songes (1897), and Les Alhambras (1908).
He contributed to a revival of El Greco (Russel 1982)
nodes.collector of Goya's works: works attributed to Goya in his 1878 sale: Enfant jouant au moine, Enfant jouant au soldat, Petite-fille de l'auteur and Nature morte. The latter is [Still Life with Golden Bream](https://emuseum.mfah.org/objects/26077/still-life-with-golden-bream) (1808-12), Houston MFA 94.245.
nodes.sale: Hôtel Drouot, 11-12 April 1878 (catalogue by Ernest Chesneau).
founder of: Société japonaise du Jinglar (1867), with 9 other artists.
nodes.portrayed by: Bracquemond, etching, c.1865; Édouard Manet, 1866 (Bremen Kunsthalle), which follows the model established by Velázquez and the Flemish painters; Manet, in Music Lesson, 1870s, as the music teacher; Fantin-Latour, 1870 (Un atelier aux Batignolles, where Manet is making Astruc's portrait).
nodes.decorations/awards: Chevalier de la Légion d'honneur (1890)
nodes.newspaper archive: John Russel, 'Seeing The Art of El Greco as Never Before', The New York Times, 18 July 1982 (a review of the NGA exhibition).
nodes.bibliography: Hansen 2021; Maurer 2021 (in Hansen 2021); Mathilde Cantenot 2017, Zacharie Astruc (1833-1907) et l'Espagne : à la rencontre d'un idéal, à l'épreuve du réel, École du Louvre, thèse; Agnès Juvanon du Vachat, 'Les relations entre jardins et paysages, dans les récits des voyageurs français en Espagne', Projets de Paysage, 6, 2011.
