nodes.interest in Spanish art: Renoir considered that in Velázquez's Infanta Margarita (1653, Louvre), her ribbons reconciled ‘all of painting’ (tout l'art de la peinture est là) (Tinterow 2003, p.457; quoted from García Felguera 1991, p.143)
nodes.address: workshops: rue Notre-Dame-des-Champs; rue Saint-Georges (from 1873)
nodes.in Spain: 1892 (with his friend Paul Gallimard)
mentions of Goya: 'Et en laissant ses personnages tel qu’ils sont, on peut encore donner à une peinture un agrément indéfinissable, si l’on n’a pas soi-même une âme de croque-mort. Ainsi, la Famille Royale de Goya, qui, à elle seule, vaut le voyage de Madrid ! Quand on est devant ça, est-ce qu’on remarque seulement que le roi a l’air d’un marchand de cochons ; et que la reine semble échappée de chez un mastroquet, pour ne pas dire plus ! Les diamants dont elle est couverte ! Personne n’a rendu les diamants comme Goya !' [reference of his (1892) trip to Spain] (Fayos-Pérez c.2025 forthcoming; Vollard 1919, p.141)

'J’ai vu une chose inouïe de lui, en Espagne, dans une petite église: un plafond qui représente des gens regardant en bas [Goya's frescoes in San Antonio de la Florida]. Gallimard et moi, nous étions en extase, lorsque le guide nous apprit que deux peintres de Paris, ajouta-t-il, avaient passé là récemment et qu’après avoir levé les yeux au plafond, ils étaient sortis de l’église en haussant les épaules!' (Vollard 1919, p.141).
nodes.author of: Lise (Tréhot) cousant (1866, Dallas); Lise à l'ombrelle (1867); Femme à la perruche (1871, Guggenheim NY); Nature morte au bouquet (1871, Houston)): on the wall, it shows a print by Manet after a painting formerly attributed to Velázquez (Petits Cavaliers); Portrait de Claude Monet (1872, NGA); Bal du moulin de la Galette (1876); Portrait de Victor Chocquet (1876, Cambridge MA, Fogg Art Museum); Madame Georges Charpentier et ses enfants (1878, Met): Mme Charpentier also frequented Flaubert, the Goncourt and Zola; La Fin du déjeuner (1879, Städel); Rose et bleu (Alice et Élisabeth Cahen d'Anvers) (1881, Sao Paulo); Jeune Fille algérienne (1881, Boston); Le Déjenuner des canotiers (1881, Washingotn, Phillips Collection); Les Grandes Baidneuses (1887, Philadelphia); Jeunes filles au piano (1892)

Histoire des peintres de toutes les écoles. Tome 2. École espagnole by Charles Blanc, W. Bürger (Thoré), Paul Mantz, Louis Viardot and Paul Lefort (Paris, Vve Jules Renouard), with illustrations by Bocourt. Goya is discussed on pp. 1–12 (Lefort) and 17 (Blanc)
nodes.writes in: Before 1848: le Siècle, l’Artiste, le Réformateur, le Journal du peuple, la Revue de Paris, le Constitutionnel; Gazette des Beaux-arts (1866, on Vermeer: 'Van der Meer de Delft')
writes about Goya: 1835: 'Un Nain de Felipe IV, eau-forte, par don Francisco Goya’ and ‘l’œuvre comique du vieux Goya’ (p. 57); ‘Après Mengs, l’Espagne ne cite que le vieux Goya, mort en ces dernières années, Goya homme de verve et d’imagination, plus connu par ses études des maîtres et par ses eaux fortes hardies que par sa peinture' (p.64) (‘Études sur la peinture espagnole, Galerie du Maréchal Soult (II)’, Revue de Paris, XXI–XXII, pp.44–64
1838: ‘[…] composition très fantastique, comme l’Enterrement de Goya, cette fougueuse esquisse du musée espagnol' (p.278) (Salon de 1838. Troisième article’, Revue de Paris, 52, 267–279)

1842 (with Paul Lacroix): 'Francesco Goya. Il fut le Callot, le Hogarth de l’Espagne, et il fut aussi un peintre d’un rang fort distingué. […] L’étude de Rembrandt a surtout influé sur le style de la seconde manière de notre artiste' [...] Goya a laissé au moins autant de dessins que de tableaux; même verve, même originalité. Une collection précieuse, qu’au moment de sa mort il recommandait à son fils, c’est une suite de soixante-dix dessins représentant l’histoire de Saragosse pendant l’invasion de l’Empire [...] C’est un Rabelais le crayon à la main, mais un Rabelais espagnol, […] sa gaieté fait parfois frémir celui qui le comprend. Un dessin de Goya en dit plus sur l’Espagne d’il y a quarante ans, que tous les volumes des historiens et toutes les relations des touristes [...] Les Caprichos sont extrêmement rares en France; nous avons eu sous les yeux l’exemplaire de la Bibliothèque du Roi, et nous en recommandons l’étude à nos artistes' (‘Francesco Goya’, Bulletin de l’Alliance des Arts, 6, 94–96)

1846, 2-3 June: 'Aux [Théâtre des] Variétés, M. Roqueplan, qui a tant d’esprit, se propose aussi, dit-on, d’exhiber la série des caricatures de Daumier, à côté des fantaisies de Hogarth et de Goya’ (Le Constitutionnel, p.1)
1847, 15 April: ‘Ce chien là ressemble à un fier mendiant espagnol, peint par Velasquez ou par Goya’ (‘Feuilleton: Salon de 1847’, Le Constitutionnel, p.1–2)

1847, 12 December: 'Au xviiie siècle, l’Espagne ne compte plus qu’un seul vrai peintre, Goya, le caricaturiste, que l’Italie sans doute ne réclamera point’. Before this passage, Thoré makes a summary of the best known Old Master Spanish artists, including Morales, Zurbarán, Velázquez, Murillo and Ribera, quoting Ceán Bermúdez’s Diccionario histórico (‘Beaux-Arts. Abolition de l’école française a Rome’, Le Constitutionnel, p.3)

1857: 'Depuis eux, un seul homme en Espagne fut un véritable artiste: c’est Goya. On voit de lui à Manchester quatre pochades d’enfants, non cataloguées* et égarées dans la Clock Gallery, ce refugium peccatorum. Goya vécut bien vieux, et, de la France où il mourut, il put voir les Aparicio, les Madrazo et bien d’autres livrer au triste style de Louis David – sa patrie, la patrie de Velasquez! *Le nouveau tirage du catalogue les enregistre au nom de Goya: quatre esquisses d’Enfants qui jouent' (Trésors d’art exposés à Manchester en 1857 [...], Paris, Renouard)
1862, 18 July: ‘Et quel nom de peintre espagnol a passé les Pyrénées, depuis Goya? [Federico] Madrazo, peut-être, le nom se rattachant au Musée de Madrid’ (‘Beaux-Arts’, Le Temps, p.3)

1862, 9 August: 'En France, on placerait volontiers Hogarth en pendant de Goya. Ce n’est pas juste. Goya est un véritable artiste, tout spontané, jetant, de verve, sa caricature légère, très expressive, une fois même l’improvisant sur un mur, du bout de son doigt trempé dans la bourbe d’un ruisseau' (‘Beaux-Arts: Exposition internationale de 1862 à Londres (III)’, Le Temps, pp.2–3)
nodes.political views: participated in the Revolution of 1830. Disappointed at Louis-Philippe's government; he promotes the 1848 Revolution; he runs for the Assemblée constituante in 1848, against Louis Bonaparte (future Napoleon III); on 15 May 1849, he encourages the popular movement to take the Assemblée and Hôtel de Ville, which leads to Thoré being condemned to death and he flees into exile in Brussels (where he takes the pseudonym William Bürger). In exile 1849-1860 (amnesty)
nodes.mentions: Émile de Girardin stated: 'Je ne connais guère en France que deux hommes qui soient restés incorruptibles : Proudhon et Thoré'
nodes.bibliography: Fayos Pérez 2024, Appendix II; Magali Charreire, 'Vermeer à l’Arsenal: la bibliothèque-musée de Paul Lacroix', Littératures, vol.75, 2016, pp.45–56; Frances Suzman Jowell, 'Thoré-Bürger's Art Collection: A Rather Unusual Gallery of Bric-à-Brac', Simiolus: Netherlands Quarterly for the History of Art, vol.30, no.1/2, 2003, pp.54–119
nodes.portrayed by: Nadar, 1865, caricature; Nadar, 1865, photograph; Léopold Flameng, 1870, lithography

nodes.label: Hamelin
nodes.profession: socialite, salonnière, 'Merveilleuse' during the Directoire, real state agent, secret agent
nodes.political views: fervent Bonapartist (surveilled by Louis XVIII's Police). Enthusiastic about the Revolution of 1848
nodes.works as: secret agent for Napoléon Bonaparte. Elle 'fit placarder sur les murs de Paris des affiches portant le texte des trois proclamations adressées par l’Empereur à son armée et au peuple français' (Wikipedia).
nodes.portrayed by: Andrea Appiani, 1798 (in Milano)
nodes.friends: Chateaubriand; Benjamin Constant; Victor Hugo; Sophie Gay; V Duke of Richelieu
nodes.married to: Romain Hamelin (in 1792, when she was 14 years old)
nodes.children: Léontine; Édouard
nodes.partners/lovers: François Fournier-Sarlovèze (until 1814); Comte de Montrond (Casimir de Montrond, 1769-1843), a French diplomat
nodes.address: rue Blanche (from 1817); rue de Clichy (ancienne Folie-Richelieu) (from 1821); 37 rue de la Tour-d'Auvergne (after 1846)
nodes.mentions: 5 years after her death, Salvandy wrote in Le Journal des débats (18 July 1856): 'Une étrangère, une Américaine (nom donné aux colons des Antilles), arriva sur la terre de France, jeune, belle, éprise de notre littérature, de nos arts, de notre société (...) Elle avait retenu autour d'elle les esprits les plus diverses, les éléments qu'on aurait pu croire étrangers entre eux, l'Empire et la Royauté, l'Institut et le grand monde (...) un des rares salons où se maintenait la conversation à travers tout le mouvement de la société d'aujourd'hui'.
curiosities: Around rue Balzac, it was known as 'quartier de l'Avenue Fortunée' in her honour.
The Comtesse de Bassanville said about her: 'C'est surtout par l'esprit que brillait Madame Hamelin ; elle n'était pas simplement spirituelle, elle était l'esprit même'.

Mademoiselle Cochelet in her 'Mémoires' wrote 'Ce furent selon les bruits du temps, les complots de Madame Hamelin et de la reine (Hortense) qui amenèrent ce merveilleux débarquement de l'île d'Elbe'.
nodes.bibliography: Lescure 1995
nodes.image source: portrait by Andrea Appiani, 1798, Musée Carnavalet P1685

nodes.label: Swanton-Belloc
nodes.author of: the translations of Uncle Tom's Cabin (1852) by Harriet Beecher Stowe, the memoirs of Lord Byron, the works of Walter Scott, and four works by Charles Dickens, among others. She also authored over forty books, including a life of Byron, published with an introduction by Stendhal. She co-authored with Adélaïde de Montgolfier a number of children's books (Buell Hale 1874, p.583-84)
nodes.participated in: a project after the 1830 Revolution to help General Lafayette establish public libraries in France, but it did not succeed (Buell Hale 1874, p.583-84)
nodes.founder of: La Ruche, journal d'études familière (with Adélaïde de Montgolfier), a monthly magazine dedicated to the education of young women (Buell Hale 1874, p.583-84)
curiosities: She was buried alongside her close friend Adélaïde de Montgolfier (and her son, Louis Belloc) at La Celle-Saint-Cloud.
She was friends with Charles Dickens and Harriet Beecher Stowe.

Her son would marry a prominent English feminist, Bessie Rayner Parkes, and they had two children who would become prolific writers: Marie Adelaide Belloc Lowndes (novelist) and Hilaire Belloc (poet and historian).
nodes.bibliography: Sarah Josepha Buell Hale, Woman's Record: Or, Sketches of All Distinguished Women, 1874. [Google books](https://books.google.es/books?id=X7ZiAAAAMAAJ&vq=belloc+la+ruche&hl=es&source=gbs_navlinks_s)

nodes.correspondence: Correspondance générale, ed. Béatrice W. Jasinski and Othenin d'Haussonville, 2008-09
nodes.parents: Suzanne Curchod and Jacques Necker
nodes.married to: Erik Magnus Stael (from 1786 to 1802); Albert de Roca (from 1811)
nodes.partners/lovers: Benjamin Constant (writer and politician) (from 1794); François de Pange (writer and journalist); Charles Maurice de Talleyrand; Louis, comte de Narbonne-Lara
nodes.children: Gustavine, Auguste, Albert, Albertine, Louis-Alphonse Rocca
nodes.portrayed by: Marguerite Gérard, 1805 (portrait with her daughter Albertine); Vigée Lebrun (1808); François Gérard (c.1810)
nodes.curiosities: she was expelled from France by Napoleon I due to her political ideas (advocating for a constitutional monarchy).
nodes.bibliography: Œuvres complètes de Mme la Bonne de Staël, publiées par son fils, précédées d'une notice sur le caractère et les écrits deMme de Staël, par Mme Necker de Saussure, 1820-1821; Roger Paulin, '3. The Years With Madame De Staël (1804-1817)', The Life of August Wilhelm Schlegel, Open Book Publishers, 2016 [online](https://books.openedition.org/obp/2957).

nodes.label: Wellington
nodes.children: Arthur Wellesley; Lord Charles Wellesley
nodes.parents: Garret Wesley and Anne Hill-Trevor
nodes.in Spain: during the Peninsular War: Battle of Corunna (16 January 1808); 2nd Battle of Porto (12 May 1809); Battle of Talavera (27-28 July 1809); Battle of Fuentes de Oñoro (3-5 May 1811); Battle of Albuera (16 May 1811); in 1812 he failed in taking Burgos, with a heavy loss of 2,000 casualties; Battle of Salamanca (22 June 1812); Battle of Vitoria (21 June 1813)
nodes.collection: after the Battle of Vitoria in June 1813, Wellesley took the so-called 'Vitoria paintings' (Equipaje del Rey José), which had been looted by Joseph Bonaparte from the Spanish royal collections, to London, until Ferdinand VII agreed for him to keep them. These are now the basis of the Wellington Museum at Apsley House, London, and the private collection of the Duke of Wellington. The other part of the Wellington collection was acquired during the 1st Duke's lifetime, including painting, sculpture and furniture
nodes.profession: army officer (Field marshal); military member; politician; collector
nodes.aristocratic titles: KG (Order of the Garter), GCB (Order of the Bath), GCH (Royal Guelphic Order), PC (Privy Council), FRS (Fellowship of the Royal Society). Duque de Ciudad Rodrigo; Grandee of Spain (Grande de España).
nodes.works as: British ambassador to France (1814); Prime Minister of the United Kingdom (1818-1830, 1834-1834); Commander-in-Chief of the British Army (1827-1828, 1842-1852); Leader of the House of Lords (1828-1830, 1834-1835, 1841-1846)
nodes.portrayed by: John Hoppner, 1795 (oil painting); Robert Home, 1804 (oil painting); Francisco de Goya, 1812, equestrian portrait, Apsley House (oil painting); Francisco de Goya, c.1812, preparatory drawing (British Museum) and oil painting (London National Gallery); William Say (print) after Thomas Phillips, 1814; Thomas Lawrence, 1815-16 (oil painting); Jan Willem Pieneman, The Battle of Waterloo, 1824; John Jackson, 1830-31 (oil painting)
nodes.curiosities: Beethoven composed Wellington's Victory or The Battle of Vitoria (Opus 91).

nodes.label: Carlos III
nodes.works as: Duke of Parma and Plasencia, King of Naples and Sicily, King of Spain
nodes.patronage: other than individual artists like Goya, Maella and Mengs, Carlos III created several royal manufactures and academies of arts and science, following the French example. As King of Naples: Real Laboratorio de Piedras Duras de Nápoles (1737), Real Fábrica de Tapices de Nápoles (1737), Real Fábrica de Porcelanas de Capodimonte (1743), and Real Fábrica de Mayólicas de Caserta (1753). As King of Spain: Real Laboratorio de Mosaicos y Piedras Duras del Buen Retiro (1759), Real Fábrica de Porcelana del Buen Retiro (1759), Real Fábrica de Platería Martínez (1778), and Real Fábrica de Relojes (1788)

nodes.label: Carlos IV
nodes.full name: Carlos Antonio Pascual Francisco Javier Juan Nepomuceno José Januario Serafín Diego de Borbón
nodes.patronage: Luis Meléndez, Claude Joseph Vernet, Luis Paret, Francisco de Goya (named Pintor de Cámara in 1789)
nodes.art collection: he gathered his own art collection since he was Príncipe de Asturias, with works by artists such as Robert Campin (Tríptico Werl) and Rafael (Sagrada Familia del cordero, Retrato de cardenal). During his exile in Rome, an inventory of his collection was made by his Chamber Painters, José Madrazo and Juan Antonio Ribera Fernández. His collection returns to Spain in 1819, part of which would become part of the Prado Museum (the rest being spread among his heirs)
nodes.portrayed by: Anton Raphael Mengs, c.1765, Prado; Goya, 1789, Prado; Francisco Bayeu, 1790-91, RABASF; José Aparicio, 1796, RABASF; Goya, La familia de Carlos IV, 1800, Prado; Vicente López, Carlos IV y su familia homenajeados por la Universidad de Valencia, 1802, Prado; José Madrazo, 1824, Palacio Real de Aranjuez
nodes.parents: Carlos III and María Amalia de Sajonia
nodes.works as: King of Spain, until abdication in 1808 (after the Motín de Aranjuez). After Joseph Bonaparte's reign, he abdicates again in his son Fernando
nodes.in France: from 1808, exiled in Compiègne, close to Paris; then Marseille, until 1812
nodes.in Italy: Palazzo Borghese in Rome, from 1812. After Napoleon's fall in 1814, the move to the Palazzo Barberini. He visits his brother Fernando in Naples, where he would die
nodes.children: out of 24 pregnancies, 14 children were born, of which 7 survived, including Carlota Joaquina, María Amalia, María Luisa Josefina, Carlos María Isidro (founder of carlismo), María Isabel, Francisco de Paula Antonio (Duke of Cádiz), Fernando (future Ferdinand VII)

nodes.married to: Francisco de Asís, Duke of Cádiz (1846)
nodes.children: out of 12 pregnancies, 5 children survived: Infanta María Isabel, Alfonso XII, Infanta María del Pilar, Infanta María de la Paz, Infanta María Eulalia. Some of the children were allegedly born from extramarital relationships
nodes.portrayed by: Carlos Luis de Ribera, La reina niña Isabel II de España, 1835, Museo del Romanticismo; Antonio María Esquivel, 1843, Museo de Bellas Artes de Sevilla; José Castelaro y Perea, 1844, Isabel II jurando la Constitución de 1837; Federico Madrazo, 1844, RABASF; Jean Laurent, c.1860, photograph; L. Mouton, c.1868, photograph; Francisco Ortego, '¡A Francia!', caricature in Gil Blas, 4 Oct 1868; anonymous, c.1870, photograph (in exile in Paris); 1875, photograph (Queen Doña Isabel II of Spain with her three youngest daughters: Pilar, Paz and Eulalia); portrait of Isabel II and the King consort, photograph, before 1902
nodes.curiosities: an anonymous album of 107 drawings, Los Borbones en pelota, appeared showing sexually explicit images of the Queen with different men. Possible authors are the brothers Gustavo Adolfo and Valeriano Bécquer, or the draughtsman Francisco Ortego. It was in an unknown location until 1986 and is now held at the BNE. It was not officially published until 1991.

nodes.label: Mª Cristina
nodes.full name: María Cristina Fernanda de Borbón y Borbón
nodes.parents: Francisco I de las Dos Sicilias and María Isabel de Borbón
works as: Queen consort of Spain (1829-1833); Regent of the Kingdom (1833-1840).

Businesswoman: salt, stock market, railroad, real state, slavery. She and her husband had commercial businesses in Madrid, Paris, London and La Habana, from 1835 to 1873, through the firm 'Agustín Sánchez & Cia' (created in 1844). Their involvment in the slave trade 1845-1849, through Julián Zulueta, continued even after it was declared illegal (1837); they owned two large ships for the trans-Atlantic transport of slaves.
nodes.in Paris: 1840-1844. From Paris, she conspired until her reestablishment as Queen Regent.
nodes.in France: she was in 3 exiles: 1840-44, 1854-56 (with the 1854 Revolution) and 1868-1878 (with the 1868 Revolution; her grandson Alfonso XII became King in 1874).
nodes.married to: Fernando VII (1829-1833); Fernando Muñoz, I Duke of Riánsares (1833-1873)
children: With Fernando II (2): Isabel II and Infanta María Luisa.

With Fernando Muñoz (8): María Amparo, condesa de Vista Alegre; Milagros, marquesa de Castillejo; Agustín, duque de Tarancón; Fernando, duque de Riansares; María Cristina, marquesa de la Isabela; Juan, conde del Recuerdo; Antonio Muñoz; José, conde de Gracia.
nodes.address: Palace de la Malmaison, former residence of Napoleon and Josephine (acquired in 1842); Palacio de las Rejas, Madrid (destroyed in 1854). Real Quinta de Quitapesares, Segovia. Real Posesión de Vista Alegre (Carabanchel). Other residences in Tarancón, Riánsares and Señorío de Castillejo
nodes.decorations/awards: Dama de la Orden de las Damas Nobles de la Reina María Luisa (Spain 1833); Gran Maestre de la Orden de las Damas Nobles de la Reina María Luisa (Spain 1829-1833); Dama gran cruz de la Orden de Nuestra Señora de la Concepción de Villaviciosa (Portugal, 1833); Dama de la Orden de la Reina Santa Isabel (Portugal); Dama gran cruz de la Orden de Nuestra Señora de la Concepción de Villaviciosa (Portugal); Dama de primera clase de la Orden de la Cruz Estrellada (Austrian Empire 1830); Dama gran cruz de la Orden de Santa Catalina (Russian Empire).
nodes.portrayed by: Luis Carlos Legrand (lithography) after José Madrazo (original painting, lost), 1829-1832, Prado; Vicente López, oil painting, 1830, Prado P000865; Federico Madrazo, drawing, 1832, Prado D005367; Vicente López, oil painting, c.1832, Prado P007115; Luis de la Cruz, oil painting, 1833, Prado P008206; José Madrazo, La reina gobernadora María Cristina de Borbón, 1838, Madrazo collection Madrid; Franz Xaver Winterhalter, oil painting, 1841 (Paris); Mayer & Pierson, photograph, c.1870
nodes.curiosities: she was expelled from Spain in 1854 due to the massive corruption she was involved in, receiving bribes from Ministers and businessmen, and because of the looting of the royal heritage. Her lifetime pension was revoked.
nodes.bibliography: Miguel Á. López-Morell 2022, 'La estrategia de la corrupción. El patrimonio y los negocios de la reina María Cristina y Fernando Muñoz'; Paula Cifuentes 2020, María Cristina. Isabel II. Los Espejos de la reina, Madrid, Marcial Pons Historia, pp.91-110; Ángel Bahamonde Magro 1992, 'Entre España y el mercado mundial, el clan de los Zulueta (1823-1885)', in Hacer las Américas: las élites coloniales españolas en el siglo XIX, pp.242-55; Ángel Bahamonde & José G. Cayuela 1988, 'Entre La Habana, París y Madrid: Intereses antillanos y trasvase de capitales de María Cristina de Borbón y el duqe de Riansares (1835-1873)', in Estudios de Historia Social, pp.44-47.

nodes.label: Joseph I
nodes.rivals: Manuel Godoy; Carlos IV; ; X Duke of Osuna; Duke of Wellington
nodes.founder of: Museo Josefino, which would later become the Prado Museo
nodes.art collection: he looted a great number of artworks from the Spanish royal collections, including paintings by Velázquez, Ribera, Correggio and Titian. When the French army started to lose the war, he fled towards France with several wagons carrying the looted artworks. During the Battle of Vitoria (1813), he abandoned all his luggage and fled to France. The vast collection, known as the 'Vitoria Paintings' or 'Equipaje del Rey José', abandoned by Joseph, was then taken by the Duke of Wellington to London, and eventually would form his own collection. The public side of this collection can be seen at the Wellington Museum at Apsley House, London

nodes.id: Eugenio Eulalio Palafox, VII Count of Montijo
nodes.label: Montijo VII
nodes.aristocratic titles: XVII Count of Teba; VII Count of Montijo (from 1808)
nodes.portrayed by: Goya, c.1804, Frick Collection
nodes.military activity: After 1794, in Granada: Regimiento de Milicias Provinciales, teniente-coronel; Primera Divisón de Granaderos de Cádiz. 1808 in Madrid: general en jefe de las fuerzas de Aragón (he makes a call to Spanish civilians to end the French occupation in Zaragoza). In 1809 imprisoned in Badajoz, then escaped. 1811 brigadier; in charge of the Primera División del III Ejército (Murcia). 1812 Field Marshal. 1814 Captain-General. 1819 Capitán del reino y costa de Granada. 1820 Captain-General of Castilla la Vieja (when imprisoned by the Inquisition in Santiago).
member of: Honorary academic of the Real Academia de la Lengua and Real Academia de Historia (1794)
Freemasonry: Gran Maestre del Grande Oriente español
nodes.curiosities: he participated in the Motín de Aranjuez (1808) agasint Manuel Godoy disguised as a farmer under the pseudonym 'Tío Pedro' (Uncle Peter).
nodes.political views: against Absolutist Monarchy. After reading his Discurso sobre la autoridad de los ricos hombres sobre el rey (1794), Manuel Godoy exiled him to Toledo and then Granada. He blamed Godoy for the ruin of his family and the exile of his mother.
author of: Discurso sobre la autoridad de los ricos hombres sobre el rey (1794)
Translation of Voltaire's Brute (1805)
Manifiesto de lo que no ha hecho el Conde del Montijo, escrito para desengaño ú confusión de los que de buena ó mala fé le dicen autor de sediciones que no ha hecho ni podido hacer (1810)

nodes.siblings: María Tomasa Palafox, Marchioness of Villafranca; María Gabriela de Palafox, Marchioness of Lazán; Cipriano Palafox, VIII Count of Montijo

nodes.id: Cipriano Portocarrero, VIII Count of Montijo
nodes.label: Montijo VIII
nodes.aristocratic titles: XVIII Count of Teba; VIII Count of Montijo (from 1838); Duke of Peñaranda de Duero; Count of Miranda y Baños
nodes.military activity: 1805 subteniente; 1807 teniente coronel. 1813 in France he joins the Imperial Army
nodes.studies in: Academia de Artillería
nodes.works as: in 1834 he inherits the titles from his brother. He becomes prócer del Reino nato (unelected) and elected senator in Badajoz (1837-38)
nodes.political views: liberal, afrancesado, Freemason. He fought in the Peninsular War in the Napoleonic side. Supporter of José Bonaparte. After the Bourbon Restoration, he was imprisoned and then he lived in Paris under Police surveillance. When back in Spain, he supports the Pronunciamiento de Riego (1820) for a liberal government. After the fall of the Trienio Liberal (1820-23) he is imprisoned and then put under home arrest in Santiago. c.1830 he was imprisoned again for conspiracy agasint Ferdinand VII.
nodes.participates in: Peninsular War (Napoleonic side); Pronunciamiento de Riego (1820)
curiosities: In the Battle of Salamanca (1812) he lost his right eye and movility of a leg
nodes.lives in: Spain; France (Paris) from 1813; back to Spain in 1817 (Málaga, Santiago, Granada, Madrid, Badajoz).
nodes.portrayed by: Vicente López, c.1820, oil painting
nodes.decorations/awards: Légion d'honneur (1814): awarded by Napoleon.
nodes.parents: Felipe de Palafox y Cröy and María Francisca de Sales Portocarrero, VI Countess of Montijo
nodes.siblings: María Tomasa Palafox, Marchioness of Villafranca; María Gabriela de Palafox, Marchioness of Lazán; Cipriano Palafox, VIII Count of Montijo
nodes.children: María Francisca de Sales Portocarrero Palafox y Kirkpatrick, IX Countess of Montijo, known as Paca Alba, (married to the Duke of Alba), and María Eugenia de Guzmán, known as Eugenia de Montijo, Countess of Teba, Empress of the French (married to Napoleon III)

nodes.id: María Francisca de Sales Portocarrero, VI Countess of Montijo
nodes.label: Montijo VI
nodes.full name: María Francisca de Sales Portocarrero de Guzmán y Zúñig
nodes.aristocratic titles: VI condesa de Montijo y IX de Baños, dos veces grande de España; XI marquesa de Villanueva del Fresno, X de la Algaba, VII de Valderrábano, V de Castañeda y VI de Osera; XVI condesa de Teba, V de Fuentidueña, X de Casarrubios del Monte y VI de Ablitas; XVII vizcondesa de los Palacios de la Valduerna y VII de la Calzada.
nodes.political views: reformist and enlightened (ilustrada); accused of Jansenism and therefore exiled (because she translated the work of Nicolas Letourneux).
nodes.correspondence: she had correspondence with writers from all over Europe (Franco Rubio 2011; Pérez Cantó & Mó Romero 2007)
nodes.founder of: co-founder of the Junta de Damas de Honor y Mérito (1787), adscribed to the Sociedad Económica Matritense de Amigos del País (1775); co-founder of an Asociación de Presas de la Galera, to teach skills to female prisoners
nodes.member of: Comisión de Educación Moral (founded in 1794)
nodes.curiosities: when the Count of Floridablanca tried to impose a national dress for women to control the expenses of female fashion, it was her to rejected the proposition (from the Junta de Damas), arguing that the only answer was education (Trueba 2003).
nodes.works as: Director of the Escuela Patriótica de San Andrés, with 96 students; she reforms the Inclusa of Madrid (institution for abandoned babies), reducing the death rate from 80% to 46% in one year.
nodes.works for: Queen María Luisa de Parma as dama noble
nodes.portrayed by: Andrés de la Calleja (attributed), 1765, Dukes of Alba collection; anonymous, c.1785, private collection
nodes.parents: Christophe de Portocarrero y Fernández de Córdova, VI Marquis of Valderrábano and Maria-Josepha López de Zúñiga y Téllez-Girón, XVI Viscountess of la Valduerna
nodes.children: 6 children, including Eugenio Eulalio Palafox Portocarrero (VII Count of Montijo; no heirs); María Ramona Palafox y Portocarrero (married to the VI Count of Parcent); María Gabriela Palafox y Portocarrero (married to his cousin the IV Marquis of Lazán; portrayed by Goya); María Tomasa Palafox, Marchioness of Villafranca (married to the XII Marquis of Villafranca); María Benita de los Dolores Palafox y Portocarrero (married to the XVI Marquis of Mondéjar); Cipriano Portocarrero (VIII Count of Montijo)
nodes.married to: Felipe de Palafox y Croy; Estanislao de Lugo y Molina
nodes.patronage: she was a protector of the journal El Censor
nodes.friends: Marchioness of Fuerte Híjar, who was also a salonnière
bibliography: Gloria Ángeles Franco Rubio, 'Una vida poco convencional en la España de las Luces: la Condesa de Montijo (1754-1808)', in J. Álvarez Barrientos & J. Herrera Navarro, Para Emilio Palacios Fernández: 26 estudios sobre el siglo XVIII español, 2011, pp.79-98.
Pilar Pérez Cantó & Esperanza Mó Romero, 'Las mujeres en los espacios ilustrados madrileños', El Madrid de las mujeres. Aproximación a una presencia invisible, 2007, pp.145-172.

nodes.founder of: Revue Indépendante with Pierre Leroux and George Sand (1841), a journal 'démocratique à tendance socialisante et républicaine'
mentions of Goya: According to Pierre Géal: 'His opinion of Goya remains ambivalent, between praise for the strength and boldness of his brushstroke and reticence about the imperfections of the drawing'.

1834: 'Il y a […] un bon ouvrage du vieux Goya, mort depuis quelques années, et dont l’œuvre fantasque est fort appréciée de nos romantiques; c’est le portrait équestre de Charles IV, que le peintre semble avoir monté plutôt sur un cochon que sur un cheval, mais qui offre de singulières beautés dans la tête et le buste. Goya, c’est toute la liste des peintres contemporains, le reste ne vaut pas l’honneur d’être nommé’ (‘Le Musée de Madrid’, Revue Républicaine, pp.303–47; p.307)
1835, May: mention of Goya in Etudes sur l'histoire des institutions, de la littérature, du théâtre et des ­beaux-arts en Espagne.

1839: 'Après Mengs, il n’y eut plus que Francisco Goya, talent tout personnel, bizarre et fantasque, ne tenant rien du passé et ne pouvant rien donner à l’avenir’ (p.13). ‘Il ne prit de leçon que des morts, et fut à lui-même son maître unique. De cette éducation bizarre sortit un talent incorrect, sauvage, dépourvu de méthode et de style, mais plein de sève, d’audace et d’originalité' (p.306) 'Goya est le dernier héritier, mais à un degré très-distant, du grand Velazquez. C’est la même manière, plus lâche, plus fougueuse, plus déréglée. Ne s’abusant point sur la portée de son talent, Goya ne s’est jamais essayé dans les choses de haut style; ses compositions se bornent à des processions de village, à des chantres au lutrin, à des scènes de courses de taureaux, à des farces de polissons, enfin à des sortes de caricatures peintes' (p.307). '[The Caprichos] sont, comme la plupart de ses tableaux, des caricatures sur les usages, les mœurs, les personnages de son pays et de son temps. Il y en a de fort malignes, et qui s’attaquent, par des allusions assez claires, au gens de la cour de Charles IV, surtout à la reine Maria- Luisa et au favori Godoy. Ces caricatures sont de charmants caprices, rendus avec une vigueur peu commune, qui rappellent Hogarth par l’humour et Rembrandt par l’exécution’ (pp.307-8) (‘Goya’, in Notices sur les principaux peintres de l’Espagne, Paris, Paulin, pp.305–8).

1843 Les Musées d’Espagne, d’Angleterre et de Belgique, Paris, Paulin: Goya is mentioned on pp. 155–56, 167–69 and 178. 'ces Toros fantastiques de Goya, non moins que ses autres Caprices, nous rappellent Callot par l’imagination, Hogarth par l’humour, et Rembrandt par la vigueur d’exécution’ (pp.168-69).

1860 Les Musées d'Espagne: ‘Le Musée national n’a de lui qu’une seule peinture, une Loge au cirque des taureaux (un Palco en los toros)’ (p. 163). Wrong basic data such as Goya’s name and date of death: ‘Goya, mort en 1832’; ‘Antonio Goya’ (p. 163).
nodes.portrayed by: Benjamin Roubaud, c.1837-39, caricature in Panthéon charivarique, no.11; Léon Viardot (his brother), Oct 1847, drawing, Musée de la vie romantique; Étienne Carjat, 1850, photograph
nodes.curiosities: he was a close friend of the composer Gioachino Rossini

nodes.label: A. Dutuit
nodes.siblings: Eugène and Héloïse
nodes.art collection: the brothers' collection was bequeathed to the City of Paris and is now the core of the (Petit Palais) [https://www.petitpalais.paris.fr/en/content/dutuit-bequest].
nodes.collector of Goya's works: the Dutuit collection includes a trial-proof set of the Caprichos (Petit Palais LDUT182) (Fayos Pérez 2024, fig.I.14); the provenance is uncertain although the cover seems to read 'de Don Mariano Gil y Alcayde', a collector from Aragon (Los Llanos & Assante di Panzillo 2008, p.157). The binding is identical to the Ceán Bermúdez copy at the BM. It's possible that the purchase took place through Carderera since he was the foremost owner of Goya works dealing in Paris at that time, and the Dutuits didn't buy any artworks in Spain. Another possibility is that this was the Caprichos set from the Tiepolo collection (Fayos Pérez 2024). The Caprichos match Auguste's anticlerical taste, who was in contact with Piot, himself connected to Carderera.
nodes.portrayed by: Pasquale Fosca, 1884, sculpture, Petit Palais (SDUT1339); unknown, 'Auguste Dutuit, French painter and collector, with his wife', photograph, L'Illustrazione Italiana, XXX, no.2, 11 Jan 1903 (Biblioteca Ambrosiana)
nodes.bibliography: Joëlle Raineau-Lehuédé 2025; Fayos Pérez 2024; Griffits 2009; Los Llanos & Assante di Panzillo 2008

nodes.label: Meissonier
nodes.military activity: capitaine d'artillerie in the Garde Nationale during the 1848 Revolution (which spurs the creation of Barricade or Souvenir de la guerre civile).
nodes.children: Charles Meissonier
nodes.member of: Société héliographique; Société nationale des beaux-arts; Académie royale suédoise des Beaux-Arts; Royal Academy; Académie des beaux-arts
nodes.students: Édouard Detaille, Alphonse Moutte, Daniel Ridgway Knight, Louis Monziès, Charles Meissonier, Lucien Gros, Eduardo Zamacois
link to Goya's work: The print Un cauchemar (A nightmare) (1834), ridiculing King Louis-Philippe, possibly made by Meissonier, is clearly inspired by Goya's Capricho 43, 'El sueño de la razón produce monstruos' (Fayos Pérez 2024, pp.217-218).

Meissonier was inscribed as a reader at the Cabinet de Estampes of the Bibliothèque Royale (future BnF), where many artists of his generation were examining and copying the set of Goya's Caprichos (Fayos Pérez 2024, p.133; Lethève 1968, p.109).

1879 22 March, F.B. writes in L'Univers Illustré ('Le Malandrin, aquarelle de Fortuny'): 'Tout le tempérament du fougueux coloriste se retrouve ici. C'est bien là l'œuvre de celui dont notre maître Théophile Gautier a pu dire que chacune de ses toile 'semblait une ébauche de Goya, reprise et retouchée par Meissonier'' (p.189) (Fayos Pérez 2024, Appendix II).
nodes.decorations/awards: Chevalier de la Légion d'honneur (1846); Officier de la Légion d'honneur (1856); Commandeur de la Légion d'honneur (1867); Grand officier de la Légion d'honneur (1880); Grand-croix de la Légion d'honneur (1889).
nodes.author of: Partie de piquet (1845, Cardiff); (Souvenir de la guerre civile) (1850, Louvre); Man Reading (1851, Clark); Polichinelle (1860, Wallace); La Campagne de France, 1814 (1864); Cuirassier sabre au clair (c.1872, sculpture, Chicago AI); Étude de cheval (c.1880, Musée Bonnat-Helleu); Le Siège de Paris (c.1884, Orsay RF 1249).
nodes.portrayed by: Robert Jefferson Bingham, photograph, 1865; self-portrait, c.1865, Orsay; self-portrait, painting, 1889, Orsay.
nodes.bibliography: Fayos Pérez 2024; Lethève 1968
exhibitions: Salon: 1834 (Un sujet, aquarelle; Bourgeois flamands) until 1865 (Portrait de M. Charles Meissonnier; Suites d'une querelle de jeu.
Exposition Universelle 1867: several artworks.

Recent years: Zamacois, Fortuny, Meissonier, 2006-07, [Museo de Bellas Artes de Bilbao](https://bilbaomuseoa.eus/exposiciones/zamacois-fortuny-meissonier/); Ernest Meissonier. rétrospective, 1993, Musée des beaux-arts de Lyon.

nodes.label: Zamacois
nodes.studies in: RABASF, from 1865, with Federico Madrazo. He makes copies after Velázquez, Ribera and Murillo at the Prado.
nodes.friends: Jehan Georges Vibert
nodes.political views: anticlerical (author of many anticlerical paintings).
nodes.trips: Rome 1868 (as suggested by the painter Eduardo Rosales).
in Paris: He travels to Paris in 1860, funded by the Señorío de Vizcaya.
He becomes a student of Meissonier, and studies at the Imperial School.
He produces works such as El autor y sus amigos (Málaga Museum).
He meets there his close friend Jehan Georges Vibert and his future wife.
nodes.parents: Miguel de Zamacois and Ruperta María del Pilar de Zabala y Arauco
nodes.children: Miguel Louis Pascual Zamacois (journalist and playwright); Marie Hélène (married to painter Jean Alfred Marioton).
nodes.portrayed by: Raimundo Madrazo, oil painting, 1863, Prado; Mariano Fortuny, etching, 1869, Met
nodes.author of: decorative works in the Madrid Royal Palace, 1861; El autor y sus amigos (1862, Prado deposit at Málaga Museum); Los limosneros (1864, Prado deposit in Museo de Málaga; El favorito del rey (1865-67, Frankel Family Trust, Dallas); Escena de la ocupación francesa (1866, Walters Art Museum, Baltimore); El guarda campestre (1867, M. Bilbao); Trop de sang (1868, Philadelphia); El monje y el burro rebelde, o Regreso al convento (1868, Thyssen Málaga); Bautizo de pobre (1868, Museo San Telmo); El refectorio de los Trinitarios en Roma (1868, Salon); La visita inoportuna (c.1868, M. Bilbao); Amor platónico (1870, Clark); Saludo al rey (1870, Prado); La educación de un príncipe (1870).
nodes.curiosities: Charles Dickens acquired a painting by Zamacois in 1868, El guarda campestre (recently acquired by the Bilbao Museum after being lost for decades). [Bilbao Museum](https://bilbaomuseoa.eus/actividad/sobre-dickens-y-zamacois-retratos-de-infancia/).
exhibitions: Exposiciones Nacionales: 3rd-class medals in 1862 and 1864.
Paris Salon: gold medal in 1870 (La educación de un príncipe).
Exposition Universelle de Paris 1878: posthumous diploma and homage.

Recent years: Zamacois, Fortuny, Meissonier, 2006-07, [Museo de Bellas Artes de Bilbao](https://bilbaomuseoa.eus/exposiciones/zamacois-fortuny-meissonier/); Ernest Meissonier. rétrospective, 1993, Musée des beaux-arts de Lyon.
nodes.bibliography: Iñaki Moreno Ruiz de Eguino, Artistas vascos en Roma (1865-1915), San Sebastián, 1995; Manuel Ossorio y Bernard, Galería biográfica de artistas españoles del siglo xix [1883-1884], Madrid, 1975; J. Nombrela, «Eduardo Zamacois», La Ilustración Española y Americana, Madrid, 25 Jan 1871.
nodes.archives: a large part of his documental collection was recently acquired by the Bilbao Museum (formerly in Paris), including correspondence (with Meissonier, Fortuny, J. G. Vibert, Édouard Detaille, Jules Worms), and drawings.
nodes.podcasts: Cualquier tiempo pasado fue anterior, 'Anticlericalismo y pederastia' (29 Oct 2023).

nodes.label: E. Dutuit
nodes.siblings: Auguste and Héloïse
art collection: He donates 600 prints to the Rouen Library in 1845.
His collection includes La Fontaine's Tales illustrated by Fragonard, Corot's Marietta, Delacroix's Combat du Giaour et du Pacha (1835), and Fragonard's Portrait of Jérôme de La Lande.
The brothers' collection was bequeathed to the City of Paris and is now the core of the (Petit Palais) [https://www.petitpalais.paris.fr/en/content/dutuit-bequest].
collector of Goya's works: The Dutuit collection includes a trial-proof set of the Caprichos (LDUT182) (Fayos Pérez 2024, fig.I.14). The provenance is uncertain although the cover seems to read 'de Don Mariano Gil y Alcayde', a collector from Aragon (Los Llanos & Assante di Panzillo 2008, p.157). The binding is identical to the Ceán Bermúdez copy at the BM. It's possible that the purchase took place through Carderera since he was the foremost owner of Goya works dealing in Paris at that time, and the Dutuits didn't buy any artworks in Spain. Another possibility is that this was the Caprichos set from the Tiepolo collection (Fayos Pérez 2024).

Dutuit also acquired 9 state proofs of the Tauromaquia from the collection of Emile Galichon (Griffiths 2009, p.188), although they do not appear in either of the sale catalogues (1864 and 1875) (Los Llanos & Assante di Panzillo 2008, p.154).
Dutuit might also have acquired a 1st-edition Tauromaquia from the Lefort sale (28-29 Jan 1869, lot 411) (Fayos Pérez 2024).
nodes.member of: Académie des sciences, belles-lettres et arts de Rouen (1846); Société des amis des arts de Rouen; Société française de gravure
nodes.works as: deputy mayor of Rouen 1846-1874
nodes.author of: Manuel de l'amateur de d'estampes (started in 1877; unfinished); Œuvre complet de Rembrandt
nodes.bibliography: Joëlle Raineau-Lehuédé 2025; Fayos Pérez 2024; Los Llanos & Assante di Panzillo 2008; Chazal 2008
nodes.portrayed by: Fix-Masseau, 1904, sculpture, Petit Palais (SDUT1340)

nodes.label: Galos
nodes.in Spain: he lived in Pamplona (before 1804)
nodes.founder of: Caja de Ahorros de Burdeos (1819)
nodes.works as: Director of the Banco de Burdeos (after 1819); member of the Chamber of Commerce (1827); Parliament member (1830)
nodes.political views: liberal: elected member of Parliament with the 1830 Revolution
nodes.collector of Goya's works: Bulls of Bordeaux
nodes.portrayed by: Goya, 1826, oil painting (Barnes Foundation)

nodes.label: Altamira
nodes.full name: Vicente Joaquín Osorio de Moscoso y Guzmán
nodes.considered as: part of the group of Spanish 'ilustrados'
nodes.works as: director and co-founder of the Banco de España; Gentilhombre de Cámra; Presidente de la Junta Suprema Gubernativa del Reino; Alférez mayor; Caballerizo mayor
nodes.member of: RABASF
nodes.portrayed by: Francisco de Goya, 1787 (Banco de España collection)
nodes.aristocratic titles: Count of Altamira; grande España
nodes.decorations/awards: Orden del Toisón de Oro
nodes.parents: Ventura Antonio Osorio de Moscoso y Fernández de Córdoba and María de la Concepción de Guzmán y de la Cerda
curiosities: After his father's death in 1776, he inherited a massive fortune and became one of the most powerful and richest men of his time.
He catalogued his large family library in 1789 with the librarian Pablo Recio.
Altamira was particularly short, as commented by Lord Holland.
nodes.websites: Real Academia de Historia (Adriano Gutiérrez Alonso) [https://historia-hispanica.rah.es/biografias/33463-vicente-joaquin-osorio-de-moscoso-y-guzman]

nodes.label: Jovellanos
nodes.considered as: part of the group of Spanish 'ilustrados'
nodes.political views: liberal. He was a key agent in the so-called 'reformismo ilustrado', especially regarding economic and cultural development. However, with the French Revolution he paralised the liberal ideas and removed from office any liberal thinkers. With the fall of his friend Francisco Cabarrús, Jovellanos left the Court and went into exile in 1790. He returned to politics in 1797 as Ministro de Gracia y Justicia and tried to reform the Justice system and decrease the influence of the Inquisition, but he resigned after 9 months. He went back to Asturias in 1798 and worked on the study of the Asturian language. In 1800 Manuel Godoy orders his arrest and he is exiled in Mallorca, imprisoned at the Real Cartuja de Jesús de Nazaret, then at the Castle of Bellver. Liberated in 1808, he refused to take part in José Bonaparte's government. He represented Asturias in the Junta Central
nodes.works as: Ministro de Gracia y Justicia (1797-98); contributed to the creation of Banco de San Carlos (1782)
author of: Politics: Informe sobre la ley agraria (1784); Memoria sobre la educación pública; Memoria en defensa de la Junta Central; Representación al Rey sobre el tribunal de la Inquisición (1797), quoting Juan Antonio Llorente's report on the Inquisition
Plays: El delincuente honrado (1773), Pelayo (1769)
Translations: Milton's Paradise Lost

Diary and memoirs: facsimile (Biblioteca Digital Hispánica), transcribed in Obras completas, II, 1857, 4th ed. (Biblioteca de Autores Españoles; Cervantes Virtual); travel diary from Bellver to Guadalajara (April-June 1808)
nodes.founder of: Real Instituto Asturiano de Náutica y Mineralogía in Gijón (1794), applying Enlightenment ideas
nodes.member of: RABASF (1780), Real Academia de la Historia (1779), Real Academia Española (1781)
nodes.portrayed by: Francisco de Goya, 1798 (Prado P003255); attribution to Antonio Carnicero, c.1797 (Museo Lázaro Galdiano)
nodes.studies in: Real Monasterio de Santo Tomás (University of Ávila)
nodes.correspondence: Obras completas, ed. José Miguel Caso González, 1985, 1986, 1988, 1990

nodes.label: Floridablanca
nodes.considered as: part of the group of Spanish 'ilustrados'
nodes.political views: he was a key agent in the so-called reformismo ilustrado, encouraging improvements in infraestructures, administration and economy (such as the creation of the Dirección General de Caminos, 1785). However, he opposed the ideas of the French Revolution and became more conservative; he implemented censorship and reinforced the Inquisition, controlling the border to avoid the spread of revolutionary ideas. External politics: he made Spain participate in the Independence War at the US against Great Britain, getting back the territories of Menorca and Florida. His rivals were Count of Aranda (more liberal and pro-Revolution) and Manuel Godoy (his successor)
nodes.works as: Primer Secretario de Estado (1777-92); Secretario de Gracia y Justicia (1782-90)
nodes.member of: Real Academia de Jurisprudencia y Legislación; Real Academia de Ciencias y Artes de Barcelona
nodes.portrayed by: Pompeo Batoni, c.1776 (Art Institute of Chicago); Francisco de Goya, 1783 (Prado P003255)
nodes.aristocratic titles: I Count of Floridablanca (from 1773)
nodes.decorations/awards: Caballero de la Orden del Toisón de Oro; Orden de Carlos III
nodes.studies in: University of Salamanca
nodes.curiosities: Carlos III awards him with the title of Count of Floridablanca (1773) for his work as ambassador at the Holy See, contributing to the abolition of the Jesuit order.

nodes.label: Cabarrús
nodes.profession: economist, banker, diplomat, politician, civil servant
nodes.considered as: part of the group of Spanish 'ilustrados' and 'afrancesado'
nodes.works as: Ministro plenipotenciario; Ministro de Hacienda (1808-10); Ministro de Finanzas with Joseph Bonaparte
nodes.political views: liberal and 'afrancesado'. Political feuds. Imprisoned in 1790 for an alleged fraud. Afterwards he returns to politics with Carlos IV. Afrancesado during the Napoleonic invasion (named caballero Gran Banda de la Orden Real de España by Joseph Bonaparte); he is arrested in June 1808 in Zaragoza alongside Jovellanos; he then works for Joseph Bonaparte until his death in 1810
nodes.founder of: contributed to the creation of Banco de San Carlos in 1782; Real Compañía de Filipinas; Canal de Cobarrús (now Canal de Isabel II)
nodes.member of: Sociedad económica de amigos del país
nodes.portrayed by: Francisco de Goya, 1788 (Banco de España)
nodes.aristocratic titles: Count of Cabarrús (1789, Carlos IV); Grande de España
nodes.studies in: Collège de l'Esquile
nodes.parents: Dominique Cabarrus; Marie-Anne Lalanne
nodes.children: Teresa Cabarrús; Domingo Cabarrús Galabert
nodes.curiosities: he was buried in the Capilla de la Concepción at the Sevilla cathedral (during the Napoleonic War). After the war, his remains were exhumed and allegedly thrown in the common grave at the Patio de los Naranjos (with the victims of death penalty), or to the Guadalquivir river.

nodes.label: Meléndez Valdés
nodes.studies in: Reales Estudios de San Isidro (moral philosophy and Greek); Universidad de Salamanca: from 1772 (Law), and later obtains a PhD in Law (1783)
nodes.works as: professor of Greek and Humanities (Salamanca); prosecuting attorney (1789); Court Judge in Zaragoza (1789); Chancellor in Valladolid (1791); prosecuting attorney, Sala de Alcaldes de la Casa y Corte, Madrid (1797); supervisor for the Juna Suprema in Oviedo 1808 (where he almost gets executed); at the Consejo de Estado for Joseph Bonaparte
nodes.author of: Batilo (1780); Las enamoradas anacreónticas, Los besos de amor (c.1783); Las bodas de Camacho el rico (1784); volume of poems edited by Joaquín Ibarra (1785); Discursos forenses (published c.1820)
nodes.political views: in 1808 he is commissioned by the Junta Suprema to supervise the uprising in Oviedo, where he is imprisoned and later almost executed by the mob, accused of wanting to punish the patriots. Afracesado: he works for Joseph Bonaparte
nodes.in France: exiled after the French occupation in Toulouse, Montpellier, Nîmes, Alès and Montauban
nodes.participates in: the tertulias of fray Juan Fernández de Roja (portrayed by Goya), known as Liseno, and that of José Cadalso in 1773), who introduces him to French culture
nodes.portrayed by: Francisco de Goya, 1797, Bowes Museum
nodes.member of: Real Academia Española
nodes.decorations/awards: poetry award of the Real Academia Española for his work Batilo (1780); award to the best play by the city of Madrid, for Las bodas de Camacho el rico (1784). Knight of the Orden Real de España (by Joseph Bonaparte)
nodes.parents: Juan Antonio Meléndez Valdés and María de los Ángeles Díaz Cacho
nodes.curiosities: his remains were taken back to Madrid in 1900, after a brief stay at the Panteón de Hombres Ilustres (Madrid), and are now in the collective mausoleum with Goya, Moratín and Donoso Cortés at the Cemetery of San Isidro

nodes.label: Ingres
nodes.author of: Napoléon I (1806); Vœu de Louis XIII (Salon 1824); Portrait de Monsieur Bertin (Salon 1832)
nodes.in Italy: 1806-1824 (1801 Grand prix de Rome en peinture)
nodes.works as: directeur de l'Académie de France à Rome (1835-1842)
nodes.masters: Joseph Roques, Jean Suau, Jacques-Louis David (1796)
nodes.students: Amaury-Duval, Théodore Chassériau, Hippolyte Flandrin, Antoine Étex, Émile Hirsch, Romain Cazes, Louis Janmot, Alexandre Mauvernay, Charles Nègre, Clément Pruche, Henri Lehmann
nodes.curiosities: he was a violin player at the Orchestre de Toulouse

nodes.label: Ricourt
nodes.works as: lithographic editor of Daumier (after 1837)
nodes.address: rue de-La-Tour-d'Auvergne

nodes.label: Daumier
nodes.address: Île de Saint-Louis (1846-1863); Montmartre (from 1863)
nodes.friends: Baudelaire, Corot, Courbet, Delacroix
nodes.profession: lithographer, printmaker, caricaturist, painter, sculptor, draughtsman
nodes.participates in: the Salon: first time in 1849 (The Miller, his Son and the Ass)
nodes.author of: 4,000 lithographs, 1,000 woodcuts, 1,000 drawings, 500 paintings and 100 sculptures. From 1850 and then in c.1867 he portrayed the recurring theme of Don Quixote (Don Quijote).
nodes.works in: La Silhouette (from 1829, for Charles Philipon), La Caricature (from 1830), Le Charivari (from 1832)
nodes.parents: Jean-Baptiste Louis Daumier and Cécile-Catherine Philip
nodes.studies in: Académie Suisse (from 1823)
nodes.political views: strongly anti-monarchist and anticlerical. In 1832 he was detained in the prison of Sainte-Pélagie (Paris) for the caricature 'Gargantua' (1831), which depicted King Louis-Philippe as the Rabelaisian monster sitting in a chaise percée while eating the civilians' contributions and defecating decorations and public jobs.
nodes.decorations/awards: the Second Empire and the Third Republic intended to award him the Légion d'Honneur, but he declined as it was inconsistent with his political ideals and oeuvre.
link to Goya's work: Daumier's pl.9 from Imagination, 'Headache', 1833, is probably inspired by Cruikshank's The head Ache (1819), but also resembles Goya's Capricho 43, 'El sueño de la razón produce monstruos' (Fayos Pérez 2024, p. 133)

Daumier's 'Que de fois... n'a-t-il pas arraché... Un perroquet humain' in Némésis médicale illustrée (vol.1, 1840), might have been inspired by Goya's Capricho 53, 'Qué pico de oro!' (Fayos Pérez, 2024, p.249-50).

Many anticlerical prints by Daumier might remind of Goya's. Examples are the depiction of Jesuits in Basile a peur (1872) and En Espagne, charité chrétienne (1872), which might remind of Goya's A Scene from 'The Forcibly Bewitched' (1798, NG), or the Inquisition scene in Auto-da-fé au XIXe siècle (1851) (Fayos Pérez 2024, pp.231-36).
nodes.portrayed by: Victor Laisné, photograph, c.1850; Nadar, photograph, 1856-58 (BnF); self-portrait, bronze scultpure (Chicago); Albert-Ernest Carrier-Belleuse, bust, 1862 (Versailles)
nodes.bibliography: Fayos-Pérez 2024; Le Men 2008; Delteil 1904 [Gallica](https://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k63555863)

nodes.id: J. J. Grandville (Jean Ignace Isidore Gérard)
nodes.label: Grandville
nodes.author of: Les Métamorphoses du jour (1829); the illustrations for the article on Goya in Le Magasin pittoresque (1834); Fables de La Fontaine (1838-40); Scènes de la vie privée et publique des animaux (1842), with contributions by Honoré de Balzac, Charles Nodier and George Sand; Un autre monde (1844); Don Quichotte (1848)
nodes.bibliography: Fayos Pérez 2019-B; Fayos Pérez 2024

nodes.author of: Desordenadas y mal digeridas apuntaciones (memoirs), where he mentions his friend Moratín

nodes.label: Gros
nodes.students: Charles-Philippe Larivière, Paul Huet, Louis Léopold Robert

nodes.label: Chopin
nodes.in Spain: 1838-1839, Mallorca, with George Sand
nodes.curiosities: he stated that in Mallorca 'The three most celebrated doctors on the island have seen me ... The first said I was dead, the second that I am dying, and the third that I'm going to die' (1962, ed. Bronisław Edward Sydow, p.164).

nodes.label: David
nodes.author of: Bonaparte franchissant le Grand-Saint-Bernard (1800, Malmaison); Mme Récamier [Juliette Récamier] (1800, Louvre)
nodes.participates in: Convention National
nodes.students: Jean-Germain Drouais, Antoine-Jean Gros, Jean-Auguste-Dominique , Girodet, François Gérard, Marie-Guillemine Benoist, Jacques-Louis-Michel Grandin, José Madrazo
nodes.curiosities: Bonaparte franchissant le Grand-Saint-Bernard (1800) was commissioned by the Spanish king Charles IV (through the French ambassador Charles-Jean-Marie Alquier).

nodes.label: Hirsch
nodes.parents: Élisabeth Bella Philippe and Salomon Hirsch
nodes.siblings: Gaston Hirsch, Émile Hirsch (peintre-verrier) and Jenny Hirsch
nodes.children: Nina Bella Pauline Louise Hirsch; Marie Jeanne Hirsch
nodes.works as: stockbroker
nodes.curiosities: his brother-in-law was Leopold de Rothschild
nodes.studies in: École nationale supérieure des beaux-arts (ENSBA)
nodes.copies after Goya: he presented a print after Goya at the 1869 Paris Salon, L'amour et la mort: an etching after Capricho 10, 'El amor y la muerte', published in the Gazette des beaux-arts, 1 July 1870 (Fayos Pérez 2024, p.185, fig.II.56).
nodes.friends: Édouart Manet, Edgas Degas, Giuseppe De Nittis, the Camondo family, Edmond de Goncourt, Charles Gounod, Jules Massenet
nodes.exhibitions: Paris Salon: 1869-1884. 1869: 3 prints after Goya, Bonvin and Ribot (published in the Gazette des beaux-arts); 1 drawing. 1876: painting Premier Trouble (edited by Goupil & Cie).
nodes.member of: Société du Jinglar (which included Zacharie Astruc, Philippe Burty, Jules Jacquemart, Henri Fantin-Latour, Félix Bracquemond and Marc-Louis Solon (director of the Sèvres factory)
nodes.author of: La Jeune femme soulevant un rideau, La corde au cou (1873); Le Premier-né (1874); Un dernier regard (1875); Les enfants Camondo dans le jardin d’hiver de leur hôtel particulier (1875) (sold Christie's NY 24 May 1989, lot 39); Les Femmes à la vasque; Le Modèle (1875); Le Premier trouble (1876); Le grand Rabbin de France Isidor (1877); Octave Feuillet (1878); Alfred Naquet, député de Vaucluse (1880).
nodes.masters: Léon Bonnat; Ernest Meissonier; François Flameng
nodes.military activity: Hirsch participated in the Franco-Prussian War (1870) and then in the Commune (1871).
mentions: 'He had made many most powerful enemies, by his ardor in defending what seemed fair and beautiful to him and by openly demolishing false and triumphant art' (Albert Wolff, 1884, p.1).

'No Parisian had more connections than this one; he was in all salons and all worlds; one met him everywhere, in the meetings of painters and in the ministries; yesterday he was seen at all the opening nights, in the summer on the beaches of Normandy; he knew politicians and writers, the premier artists of his time and the ignored ones of the new wave' (Wolff 1884, p.1).
nodes.art collection: modern etchings and engravings, mostly of French authors, including Félix Bracquemond, Charles Meryon, Corot, Millet, Jacquemart, Legros, Delacroix, Meissonier [L.133](https://www.marquesdecollections.fr/FtDetail/d7227dcb-8395-4049-b0fa-c1e0795171d0). Also Japanese art.
nodes.collector of Goya's works: the Caprichos, 1st edition, £ 13 15s (1875 sale)
nodes.sales: 1875, 29-30 July, London Sotheby (acquired by M. Carlin, L.563)
nodes.portrayed by: Edgar Degas, etching, 1875; Giuseppe De Nittis, etching, 1875
nodes.bibliography: Fayos Pérez 2024

nodes.label: Jacquemart

nodes.siblings: Louise Pauline, Marie Louise, Marie Augustine
nodes.friends: Philippe Burty
member of: Société des Aquafortistes: founded in 1862 by Auguste Delâtre and Alfred Cadart
Société du Jinglar (which included Zacharie Astruc, Philippe Burty, Alphonse Hirsch, Henri Fantin-Latour, Félix Bracquemond and Marc-Louis Solon (director of the Sèvres factory)
nodes.founder of: Société d'aquarellistes français in 1879 (with Eugène Lami, Gustave Doré, Eugène Isabey)
exhibitions: Paris Salon: 1st time 1861, with drawings (Canard sauvage and Courlis); 1878; 1879, La Joconde, after da Vinci.
1878 Exposition universelle (honorary medal).
1879 1st exhibition of the Société d'aquarellistes français, at Durand-Ruel: he exhibits 9 artworks, including Les platanes en hiver.
nodes.works for: the Metropolitan Museum of Art (prints of the exhibited paintings, including Le Soldat et la fillette qui rit by Vermeer), 1871; Joseph Florimond, Duke of Loubat (60 prints of medals), 1878.
copies after Goya: 1863 Scène espagnole, published in the Gazette des beaux-arts to illustrate the 2nd article by Valentín Carderera about Goya (Fayos Pérez 2024, fig.II.44); re-printed 1 July 1870. This print is either a pastiche after Capricho 17, 'Bien tirada está<>/i>, or a print after a lost drawing from the Carderera collection; it is mentioned by Gustave Brunet in his 1865 book (p.14).

1873 print Goya's daughter-in-law (Gumersinda Goicoechea) British Museum [1982,U.1280](https://www.britishmuseum.org/collection/object/P_1982-U-1280). The original oil painting (c.1805) is in a private collection (Paris).
nodes.participates in: Histoire de la Bibliophilie (1861-64); L'Histoire artistique industrielle et commerciale de la porcelaine (1862); Gemmes et Joyaux de la Couronne (1865); L'Histoire de la céramique (1873); L'histoire du mobilier (1876).
nodes.art collection: Japanese art; paintings (by Nittis, Vollon), Oriental bronzes, arms, Sèvres porcelain, ivory sculpture, mirrors, furniture, tapestries; prints.
nodes.author of: The Engraver's Instruments (c.1862, Met 1990.1003); Une jeune mène italienne, watercolor, Orsay
nodes.portrayed by: self-portrait, watercolor (Orsay RF 2393); Marcellin Desboutin, drypoint, 1876
nodes.bibliography: Fayos Pérez 2020; Brunet 1865

nodes.literary salon or tertulia: with his brother. Called the Grenier, and located at 67 Bv Montmorency (16e). Attendants are Maurice Barrès, Alphone and Léon Daudet, Gustave Geffroy, Roger Marx, Octave Mirbeau, Auguste Rodin, Émile Zola.
nodes.studies in: Lycée Condorcet
nodes.portrayed by: Nadar, with his brother Jules Goncourt; Victor Collodion, caricature, 1868 (with his brother); Nadar, c.1877; anonymous, photograph, 1885-1895 (Goncourt entre 1885 et 1895 dans son cabinet de travail, Musée Carnavalet).
nodes.knows Goya's works: the brothers estudied the Disasters of War on 4 Jan 1863 at the BnF (Lethève 1968, p.108).
nodes.writes about Goya: About the Disasters of War: 'Avez-vous vu cette planche de Goya, terrible comme une épouvante rencontrée la nuit, par un clair de lune, au coin d'un bois: un homme empalé à une branche d'arbre, nu, saignant, les pieds contractés de souffrance, l'agonie de sa torture sur la face et dans le hérissement des cheveux, le bras coupé net, cassé comme un bras de statue ?... Et puis, tournez la feuille: des bouches qui crachent la vie, des mourants vomissant le sang sur des cadavres, l'Espagne mendiant, les pieds dans la voirie d'une ambulance… Le génie de l'horreur, c'est le génie de l'Espagne. Il y a de la torture, de l'inquisition presque, dans ces planches de son dernier grand peintre. Son eau-forte brûle l'ennemi pour la postérité, comme autrefois l'auto-da-fé brûlait l'hérétique pour l'enfer' (Idées et sensations, 1877, pp.185-86).
nodes.author of: Journal. Mémoires de la vie littéraire (from 1851); Études d'art Le salon de 1852 : La peinture a l'exposition de 1855; Germinie Lacerteux (novel 1865, theatre 1888), Manette Salomon (1867), Madame Gervaisais (1869), Les Frères Zemganno (novel 1879, theatre 1890).
nodes.bibliography: Fayos Pérez 2024; Pierre Ménard 2020, Les infréquentables frères Goncourt; Barbara Giraud 2009, L'Héroïne goncourtienne: entre hystérie et dissidence; Lethève 1968.

edges.collaborations: Frédéric Quilliet started an inventory of the Spanish royal collections in 1810, a selection of which were to be gathered at the Museo Josefino, and others at the Musée Napoleón in Paris. Maella collaborated in two of these inventories: one signed on 25 October 1810, alongside Goya and Napoli (AGP, Gobierno Intruso, caja 29, exp.no.31) (see Antigüedad del Castillo-Olivares 1987, pp.298-301); and another one in November 1810, also with Goya and Napoli (AHN, Consejos, leg.17.787)

edges.relationship type: acquaintance? Quilliet was very well acquainted with Ceán Bermúdez's Diccionario (1800), which he used to locate artworks in palaces and convents. He also used Ceán's book to write his Dictionnaire des peintres espagnols (París, Fain, 1816)

edges.exchanges: Goya's early prints such as Saint Francis of Paola (c.1776-78) were clearly influenced by G.D. Tiepolo's series of Raccolta di Teste (c.1757-70) (McDonald, 2012, p.236).
edges.collector of Goya's works: Tiepolo acquired a set of the Caprichos, among other prints by Goya. His 1845 sale included several lots of Goya's works (see Giandomenico's node)

edges.mentions: Jovellanos was invited to a dinner at Godoy's where both his wife (Chinchón) and his lover (Tudó) were sitting at the table, and he stated: 'A su lado derecho, la princesa; a su izquierdo, Pepita Tudó. Este espectáculo acaba en mi desconcierto. Mi alma no pudo sufrirlo. Ni comí, ni hablé, ni pude sosegar mi espíritu. Huí de allí.'

edges.correspondence: yes. Letters mentioned in Carderera's diary, 1841-1842 (LG 2016).
edges.exchanges: Sureda received the Cruz de caballero de la Real Orden de Isabel la Católica in 1843 thanks to Carderera.
interactions: Many, in Paris, from 1841 to 1843.
1842 Jan 2, 10, 16, Feb 10, 20, 26 (with Viollet-le-Duc), March 19, April 2, 5, 20, May 30, June 2, Aug 24, Dec 4, 7.
1843 Feb 3 (Sureda tells him that Thiers what to buy his drawings and see them at Viollet-le-Duc's), March 23, April 8, June 4, 20.
1845 May 2, 7, July 12, Sept 7, Oct 12, Nov 8, 10, 18, 27, Dec 10
1858 by Carderera's initiative, Sureda plans the restoration of the upper part of the tower of San Isidoro de León.

1863 Sureda asks Carderera to act as intermediary with the XII Duke of Osuna (Mariano Téllez-Girón) --who had been portrayed by Carderera in 1833-- to receive the commission of the restoration of the Palace del Infantado (Guadalajara).

edges.collaborations: restoration of the Belmonte Castle in Cuenca (1857-71)

edges.employment/patronage: Godoy helped Moratín to premiere his comedies and increased his income with other ecclesiastical sinecures: 3,000 ducats from a parish in Montoro and 600 from the mitre of Oviedo. From 1792-1797, Godoy funds Moratín's European tour in England, Belgium, Germany, Switzerland and Italy.

edges.commissions: a portrait (1801) and the two 'Majas': the [Maja desnuda (1795–1800)](https://www.museodelprado.es/coleccion/obra-de-arte/la-maja-desnuda/65953b93-323e-48fe-98cb-9d4b15852b18) and the [Maja vestida (1800–07)](https://www.museodelprado.es/coleccion/obra-de-arte/la-maja-vestida/a3121efc-6924-454c-8a9f-e4320f26d3d0), now at the Prado. Goya was probably accused to the Inquisition because of the Naked Maja. There has been much speculation about the identity of the model of the 'Majas', mostly as part of the alleged (and spurious) love affair of the painter with the Duchess of Alba; others pointed towards Godoy's lover and second wife, Pepita Tudó. The 'Majas', however, are most likely an idealisation created by the artist

interactions: Houssaye left her parents home in 1832 to leave the 'Bohemian life' in Paris, with Gautier, Nerval, Jules Janin and Alphones Esquiros. They also lived close to one another on the impasse du Doyenné (current Place du Carrousel).

edges.they met: in 1864, Eugenia pays a surprise visit to Bonheur and invites her for lunch at Fontainebleau with Napoleon III (this visit is portrayed in a print by Auguste Victor Deroy: L'impératrice Eugenia rendant visite à Rosa Bonheur). The following year, 1865, Eugenia visits Bonheur again to name her Chevalier de la Légion d'honneur, making her the first female artist and the 9th woman to receive it. At this moment, Eugenia is said to have said: 'Enfin, vous voilà chevalier. Je suis tout heureuse d’être la marraine de la première femme artiste qui reçoive cette haute distinction. J’ai voulu que le dernier acte de ma régence fût consacré à montrer qu’à mes yeux le génie n’a pas de sexe
edges.interactions: Eugenia intervened for the award of the Légion d'honneur to painter Rosa Bonheur

edges.mentions: Bonheur discovered through her father Sand's 'countryside novels ' (romans champêtres). Bonheur's Le Labourage nivernais (1849) is reference to Sand's novel La Mare au diable (Lebovici 2007)

edges.mentions: Gautier says: 'Nous avons toujours professé une sincère estime pour le talent de mademoiselle Rosa Bonheur. Avec elle, il n'y a pas besoin de galanterie ; elle fait de l'art sérieusement, et on peut la traiter en homme. La peinture n'est pas pour elle une variété de broderie au petit point' (Les beaux-Arts en Europe, 1855, p.120)

mentions: Zola actively defended Manet's painting, often rejected at the Paris Salon. In 1866, Zola defended him in his critique of the Salon, published in L'Événement, drawing thunderous objections from the paper's readers that prompt him to resign (Wolohojian & Dunn 2023, p.278).
Zola said about Manet: 'Autour du peintre vilipendé par le public s'est créé un front commun de peintres et d'écrivains le revendiquant comme un maître'.

collaborations: Astruc wrote a song dedicated to the Spanish dancer Lola de Valence in 1863, printed with a reproduction of a painting by Édouard Manet (1862).

Astruc often defended Manet's art, including the scandalous Olympe (1863; Salon 1865). Inspired by it, Astruc wrote the poem La Fille des Îles, of which the first verses were hung next to the painting: 'Quand, lasse de songer, Olympia s'éveille / Le printemps entre au bras du doux messager noir ; / C'est l'esclave, à la nuit amoureuse pareille, / Qui vient fleurir le jour délicieux à voir ; / L'auguste jeune fille en qui la flamme veille...'.
portraits: Manet portraying Astruc: portrayed in the crowd of 1862 Music in the Tuileries (NG/Hugh Lane Gallery Dublin); 1866 individual portrait (Bremen Kunsthalle); 1870 Astruc as the music teacher in Music Lesson (Met).
Astruc portraying Manet: Buste de Manet, sculpture, 1881.
In Fantin-Latour, 1870 Un atelier aux Batignolles, Manet is making Astruc's portrait.
exchanges: Astruc dedicated his volume of Salon critique to Manet.
correspondence: 1865 about Olympe at the Salon.

1865 August, Manet writes to Astruc (about his upcoming trip to Spain): 'Je suis extrêmement pressé de voir tant de belles choses et d'aller demander conseil à maître Vélasquez' (Tinterow 2003, p.392).

1865, 17 Sept, about Manet's Spanish trip. Manet writes: 'Deux hommes seulement, après le Maître (Velázquez), m'ont séduit là-bas : Greco dont l’œuvre est bizarre, des portraits fort beaux cependant (je n'ai pas été content du tout de son Christ de Burgos) et Goya dont le chef-d'œuvre se trouve, selon moi, à l'Académie (La Duchesse d'Albe, quelle saisissante fantaisie)' (Tinterow 2003, p.393; Cabañas Bravo 2003, p.495). Here, Manet wrongly assumes the Clothed Maja is the Duchess of Alba, one of many fabricated stories in 19th-century France about Goya.
1868, 2 letters from Manet to Astruc. Exhibition Manet and Astruc, 2021: MS420(25)13.

correspondence: 1865, 3 Sept, from Manet to Fantin-Latour (after visiting the Prado): 'Mon cher ami, que je vous regrette ici et quelle joie c'eût pour vous de voir ce Vélasquez qui à lui tout seul vaut le voyage... C'est le peintre des peintres; il ne m'a pas étonné mais m'a ravi. Le portrait en pied que nous avons au Louvre n'est pas de lui. L'infante seule ne peut être contestée [...]. les fileuses, le beau portrait d'Alonzo Cano, las Meninas (les nains), tableaux extraordinaire auxxi, ses philosophes, étonnants morceaux--tous les nains, un srutout assis de face les poings sur les hanches, peinture de choix pour un vrai connaisseur, ses magnifiques portrait, il faudrait tout énumérer, il n'y a que des chefs-d'œuvre... Et Goya, le plus curieux après le maître, qu'il a trop imité dans le sens le plus servile d'imitation. Une grande verve cependant. Il y a de lui au musée deux beaux portraits équestres dans la manière de Vélasquez, bien inférieurs toutefois. Ce que j'ai vu de lui jusqu'ici ne m'a pas plu énormément; je dois en voir ces jours-ci une magnifique collection chez le duc d'Ossuna... Je vais demain faire une excursion à Tolède. Là je verrai Gréco et Goya très représentés, m'a-t-on dit' (Tinterow 2003, p.292; Wilson Bareau 1991, p.34).
1868, 10 Aug, from Manet to Fantin-Latour: 'De Gas was really silly not to have come with me [to the trip to England]'.

1868, 26 Aug, from Manet to Fantin-Latour: 'I envy your being able to discuss with that famous aesthetician Degas the question of whether or not it is advisable to put art within reach of the lower classes, by turning out pictures for sixpence apiece'. And 'Tell Degas it's about time he wrote to me, I gather form Duranty he's becoming a painter of high life; why not? It's too bad he didn't come to London, those well-trained horses would have inspired a few pictures' (Wolohojian & Dunn 2023, p.279).
