Fantin-Latour's Hommage à Delacroix (1864, Orsay), with Delacroix's portrait and depicting Fantin-Latour himself, Édouard Manet, Louis Edmond Duranty, Champfleury, Charles Baudelaire, Louis Cordier, Alphonse Legros, James Whistler, Félix Bracquemond, and Albert de Balleroy.

Baudelaire is portrayed in Fantin-Latour's Hommage à Delacroix (1864, Orsay), with Delacroix's portrait, depicting Fantin-Latour himself, Édouard Manet, Louis Edmond Duranty, Champfleury, Louis Cordier, Alphonse Legros, James Whistler, Félix Bracquemond, and Albert de Balleroy.

Bracquemond is portrayed in Fantin-Latour's Hommage à Delacroix (1864, Orsay), with Delacroix's portrait, depicting Fantin-Latour himself, Édouard Manet, Louis Edmond Duranty, Champfleury, Louis Cordier, Alphonse Legros, James Whistler, Charles Baudelaire and Albert de Balleroy.

edges.relationship type: friends; master-student; portraitist-sitter; relatives: brother-in-law, sister-in-law
edges.feuds: Morisot decides to join the new association of artists (Société anonyme des artistes peintres, sculptueurs et graveurs) in 1873 and stop sending artworks to the Salon, while Manet remains in the official channels.
edges.mentions: in line with the misogyny of that time, Manet said to Fantin-Latour: 'Je suis de votre avis, les demoiselles Morisot sont charmantes, c'est fâcheux qu'elles ne soient pas des hommes. Cependant, elles pourraient, comme femmes, servir la cause de la peinture en épousant chacune un académicien et en mettant la discorde dans le camp de ces gâteux' (Moreau-Nélaton 1926, vol.2, to.I, p.103).
edges.portraits: Morisot posed for Manet's Le balcon (1869); Berthe Morisot with a Bouquet of Violets (1872, Orsay); Berthe Morisot au soulier rose (1872, Hiroshima Museum)
edges.bibliography: Wolohojian & Dunn 2023; Moreau-Nélaton 1926, Manet raconté par lui-même.

edges.interactions: in Spain, during Morisot's trip in 1872-73
mentions: Astruc favourably mentions Morisot in his 'Décaméron féminin' (L'Écho des Beaux-Arts, 26 June 1870, p.1-3).

Morisot mentions Astruc as their middleman in Madrid (1872-73) because he speaks Spanish and knows Madrid well: 'We are going to Madrid, at least we think we are. I have written to Manet asking him for the address of Astruc who, I know, has been there for a fairly long time. He will be of great help to me, since he speaks Spanish aknows Madrid throughly, and he certainly will be able to point out to us the things worth seeing. He must feel about the Museum pretty much as I do. [...] We should give ourselves plenty of time to admire Velasquez and the Goyas. That is for me about the only interest in going...'.

'[...] So far we have seen only the museum, which is magnificente, as you know. The city has no character [...] I have found the handsome Astruc; he has put himself entirely at our disposal for visiting the city, which he knows well. [...] I have no intention of exerting myself to see anything but paintings. Perhaps we'll go to Toledo, and come back here to see the bullfights, if we feel stouthearted enough' (Rouart 1959, pp.76-77).

edges.mentions: Astruc favourably mentions Bonheur in his 'Décaméron féminin' (L'Écho des Beaux-Arts, 26 June 1870, p.1): 'L'exemple de Rosa Bonheur, sa fortune singulière faisant éclipse même au génie--et je dois dire aussi son talent que les Anglais ont fini par couler--n'ont pa peu contribué à développer chez les femmes le sens et le goût de la peinture. Le Louvre s'est trouvé subitement envahi par nos sœurs'.

edges.they shared: the interest in Japanese art and belonging to the Société du Jinglar; being art critics; interest in Goya.
edges.interactions: c.1866-1877 at Café Gerbois (avenue Clichy): Degas, Manet, Duranty, Zola, Fantin-Latour, A. Proust, Burty, Bazille, Whistler, Renoir.
c.1866-1877 at Café Gerbois (avenue Clichy): Degas, Manet, Duranty, Zola, Fantin-Latour, A. Proust, Burty, Bazille, Whistler, Renoir.

mentions: Mantz remarked Morisot's work at the 1865 Salon in Gazette des Beaux-arts, considering it to have 'beaucoup de franchise et de sentiment dans la couleur et la lumière' (Monneret 1987, vol.2, t.1, p.595).
Mantz wrote again about her work in 1881 (Le Tempas, 23 April 1981).

edges.relationship type: friends; colleagues. Degas admired Morisot's painting (Monneret 1987, p.597).

edges.mentions: Manet criticised one of Meissonier's battle paintings: 'Tout est en acier, excepté les cuirasses' (Perruchot 1965?).
edges.interactions: Manet and Degas served under the orders of Meissonier in the National Guard

mentions: Degas allegedly criticised Meissonier as 'le géant des nains' (the giant of dwarves) (Peduzzi 1988, p.124; Meissonier exhibition catalogue 1993, p.25).
Despite disliking Meissonier and his work, Degas admited: 'ce mauvais peintre était un des hommes les plus renseignés sur le cheval que j’ai jamais connus' (Barbillon et al. 2017, p.28)
edges.interactions: Degas and Manet served under the orders of Meissonier in the National Guard
edges.bibliography: Claire Barbillon et al., Catalogue raisonné des sculptures du XVIIe au XXe siècle du musée des Beaux-Arts de Lyon, 2017; Meissonier exhibition catalogue, Musée des beaux-arts de Lyon, 1993; Richard Peduzzi, Degas. Galeries nationales du Grand Palais, 1988.

mentions: Gautier compares Meissonier with the 17th-century Flemish masters like Gerard ter Borch, Gabriel Metsu, Pieter de Hooch and Vermeer.

1879 22 March, F.B. writes in L'Univers Illustré ('Le Malandrin, aquarelle de Fortuny'): 'Tout le tempérament du fougueux coloriste se retrouve ici. C'est bien là l'œuvre de celui dont notre maître Théophile Gautier a pu dire que chacune de ses toile 'semblait une ébauche de Goya, reprise et retouchée par Meissonier'' (p.189) (Fayos Pérez 2024, Appendix II).

edges.mentions: 1879 22 March, F.B. writes in L'Univers Illustré ('Le Malandrin, aquarelle de Fortuny'): 'Tout le tempérament du fougueux coloriste se retrouve ici. C'est bien là l'œuvre de celui dont notre maître Théophile Gautier a pu dire que chacune de ses toile 'semblait une ébauche de Goya, reprise et retouchée par Meissonier'' (p.189) (Fayos Pérez 2024, Appendix II).
Blanc said about Meissonier that he 'peignait grandement en petit' (he painted greatly in small size).
Meissonier made illustrations for Balzac's La Comédie humaine (LA Maison du chat-qui-pelote, Le Bal de Sceaux, La Bourse, La Femme abandonnée, La Femme de trente ans).
Meissonier made illustrations for Hugo's Notre-Dame de Paris (1876 edition).

edges.collaborations: Bracquemond produced copies after Meissonier.

edges.they met: c.1868 in Morocco

edges.portraits: Madrazo portrays Adrien Dauzats in 1837
correspondence: 1834-IX-29, Dauzats to Madrazo: 'Je m'occupe d'une notice sur la vie et les ouvrages de Goya. C'est un hommage que nous voulons rendre à l'un des peintres les plus célèbres de l'Espagne' (Archivo Madrazo). Quoted in Guinard 1967-B, p.323 (Guinard thinks Dauzats could be the author of the article on Goya in 1834 in Le Magasin pittoresque); Fayos Pérez 2024, p.50.
1835-III-24, Madrazo to Dauzats (INHA). Pending publication. Mentions Taylor, Carderera, Ochoa and Masarnau.
1837-VI-17, Dauzats to Madrazo (Archivo Madriazo) (Guinard 1967-B, p.269).

interactions: 1841, May 4, 7 (with Blanchard and Taylor), 9 (Dauzats saw his drawings), Dec 2, 15 (Carderera gives him the drawing he asked for), 16, 30 (Paris): they meet (LG 2016, pp.10, 11, 12, 87, 92).
1842, 27 Jan (Paris): Carderera goes to Dauzats's and leaves a letter for him (Lanzarote Guiral 2016, p.100).
1856, 1 Oct (Paris): Carderera shows Dauzats hiw own drawings and also Goya's. Dauzats copies or traces some of them (Fayos Pérez 2024, p.51; LG 2016, p.352).

1859, 12 Nov (Paris): Carderera takes single sheets from the Caprichos and gives some of the prints to Dauzats: 'le regalé las estampas de Goya (29). Parece quedó content y quería pagármelas' (Fayos Pérez 2024, p.51; Lanzarote Guiral 2016, p.430).
correspondence: At least from 1842: Carderera receives a letter from Dauzats 17 March 1842 in Paris (LG 2016, p.115).
BNE (MSS/23291/39). Pending publication (Fayos Pérez 2025-2026).
Archivo familiar Carderera: at least two letters. No apparent mentions of Goya.
edges.bibliography: Fayos Pérez 2025-2026 (upcoming); Fayos Pérez 2024; Lanzarote Guiral 2016

edges.correspondence: 1856-VII-8 (Carderera archive): Mérimée answers he doesn't own a set of Goya's 'Toros' and he could buy a set if not too expensive; that he doesn't know the 'Proverbios' (Disparates) nor the 'suppressed Caprichos' (Fayos Pérez 2020; Fayos Pérez 2024 p.65)

edges.know each other since: at least 13 May 1841, in Paris. Carderera's diary: 'Por la mañana estuve a almorzar con Mr. Piot y con Mr. Teófilo Gautier' (Lanzarote Guiral 2016, p.12). Carderera helped Gautier with 1842 article in Le Cabinet de l'amateur (LG 2016, p.550)
edges.they met: Paris, 1859-XI-13: 'Fuime al quai Voltaire, redacción del Monitor (sic) [Le Moniteur universel] y pude entrar en el gabinete de Théophile Gautier, que estuvo amable. Vio la serie de toros, que le regalé y después mis entregas [...]' (Lanzarote Guiral 2016, p.431)
edges.artworks bought/sold/given: on 1859-XI-13, Carderera showed Gautier Goya's Tauromaquia and then gave it to him. This is most likely the Tauromaquia set that was sold in Sotheby's Paris, 14 Dec 2022 (Library of Jorge Ortiz Linares), lot 37, for 132,300€. [Sotheby's](https://www.sothebys.com/en/buy/auction/2022/de-la-precieuse-bibliotheque-jorge-ortiz-linares/madrid-1816-33-eaux-fortes-envoi-de-valentin?locale=en). [YouTube video](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6A2iC0fEZxs) of Jean-Baptiste de Proyart discussing the Tauromaquia set (min 2:10)

edges.discovers Goya's works: Burty probably acquired his working-proof set of Goya's Disasters of War (now at the British Museum), among other Goya prints, through Carderera
edges.collaborations: at the Gazette des Beaux-arts c.1859-1861.
interactions: 1859, 5 Nov (Paris): Carderera shows Burty Goya’s drawings and some prints. He then gives him 5 prints from the Disparates: [le enseñé] 'mis dibujos, los de Goya, y varias estampas. Le regalé cinco de Los Proverbios. Dile las notas y la carta para Blanc' (Lanzarote Guiral 2016, p.425).
1861, 3 July: Carderera meets Burty and other librarians (LG 2016, p.449)
1861, 16 July: Carderera meets Burty (LG 2016, p.455)
1861, 23 July: Carderera meets Burty and helps him with an article (LG 2016, p.458)

1861, 2 Oct (Paris): Carderera asks Blanc for the 'small portrait of Goya'. Blanc and Houssaye gave him the 'entregas' from the Gazette. 'I warned them about the article of Goya given to Burty, etc.' (Lanzarote Guiral 2016, p.508).
edges.correspondence: from at least 1860. BNE: 1860-1861; pending publication (Fayos Pérez 2025-2026).
edges.bibliography: Fayos Pérez 2025-2026 (upcoming); Fayos Pérez 2024; Lanzarote Guiral 2016

collaborations: Delacroix asked Dauzats and Burty (alongside Andrieu, Dutilleux and Schwiter) to catalogue his drawings and albums (which included his copies after Goya's Caprichos)
Burty wrote the catalogue of his 1864 sale; he acquired several artworks from his sale (including drawings after Goya's Caprichos)
He edited Delacroix's correspondence in 1878 and 1880
edges.collection: the Metropolitan holds several prints by Delacroix from the Burty collection, such as A Jewish Bride in Tangier (1833), Lion Standing (1833), Interior of a Military Hospital (1828 or earlier), The Wounded Goetz Taken In by the Gypsies (1836-43), 'Young Clifford Finding the Body of his Father' from L'Artiste (1834), The Natchez (1823-24 and 1835), Turk Mounting His Horse (1824); also the drawing The Triumph of Genius over Envy (c.1849-51), 61.160.1
edges.archives: Papiers relatifs à Eugène Delacroix provenant peut-être de Philippe Burty, [INHA Archives 33/1/4 (1829-1877)](https://calames.abes.fr/Pub/inha.aspx#details?id=Calames-2016101416105892039)

edges.collaborations: Burty and Dauzats catalogued Delacroix's drawings and albums (alongside Andrieu, Dutilleux and Schwiter)
Manet made Fleur exotique (1868), a print inspired by Goya, for a sonnet by Armand Renaud, published by Burty, [Metropolitan 64.649.1](https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/337433)]
edges.collection: the Metropolitan Museum holds several prints by Manet from the Burty collection, such as Dead Christ with Angels (1866-67) [70.588](https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/844693), The Infanta Margarita, after Velázquez (1861-62) [NMG 310/1924](https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/851751), Charles Baudelaire, Full Face, after Nadar, III (1869) [NMG 313/1924](https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/857998), Plainte Moresque (Moorish Lament) (1866), Monsieur Manet (The Artist's Father) I (1860), Hat and Guitar, Frontispiece for an Edition of Fourteen Etchings (1862-63). A substantial part of Burty's collection of Manet's prints was acquired by Edgar Degas (with the help of Michel Manzi)
edges.interactions: 1880 Burty had Japanese artist Watanabe Seitei working at his place, where he was observed by Degas and Manet.
edges.mentions: Burty wrote in the Gazette des Beaux-arts that Manet's print Gitanos (Gipsies) (1862) gave the impression of 'seeking out Goya, at least in its general appearance' (1863) (Fayos Pérez 2024, p.188).

edges.interactions: 1880 Burty had Japanese artist Watanabe Seitei working at his place, where he was observed by Degas and Manet.

edges.relationship type: acquaintances; Degas was influenced by Ingres.
interactions: 1855 Ingres told Degas: 'Draw lines, young man, and still more lines, both from life and from memory, and you will become a good artist' (Werner 1969, p.14)
1864 Degas visits Ingres, who organised 'a small exhibition in his atelier in the manner of the old masters' (Wolohojian & Dunn 2023, p.278).
edges.exchanges: Degas showed his drawings to Ingres in 1855 (depicted in Paul Valéry's Degas, Danse, Dessin, published in 1936 by Ambroise Vollard).

edges.relationship type: Degas was influenced by Delacroix. He admired Delacroix's work at the 1859 Salon. He also made a trip to Tanger to follow his steps.
copies: 1860 Degas made sketches after works b Delacroix, exhibited at the Association des Artistes (26 Bv des Italiens).

Degas made a copy after Entrée des Croisés à Constantinople (1840) (c.1860, Kunsthaus Zürich) [Met](https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/844793), and Bark of Dante (c.1859, Met 29.100.114) [Met](https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/436949).
edges.mentions: Degas makes trip to Tangier in 1889 following the steps of Delacroix. He writes 'Delacroix passed through here' (Reff 2020, letter 375, vol.1, p.476, vol.3, p.126).
edges.collection: Degas had several works by Delacroix in his collection, including some drawings after Goya (see Degas node).

edges.relationship type: Degas gathered 1,800 lithographies by Daumier in his collection
Degas admired Goya and copied his works at the BnF
edges.link to Goya's work: the Degas collection included a Delacroix drawing after Goya (D21 and possibly D38 in Fayos Pérez 2024, pp.433 and 467)

edges.they met: Degas allegedly met Manet for the first time c.1864 when they were both copying (in etching) Velázquez's Infanta Margarita at the Louvre (Wolohojian & Dunn 2023, p.277; Gordon and Forge 1988, p.23)
portraits: Manet by Degas: several prints and drawings c.1868-69, including Édouard Manet, Seated, Holding His Hat (c.1868) (and 1868 print); Édouard Manet, Bust-Length Portrait (c.1868, Met 49.127.7) [Met](https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/358782); Édouard Manet at the Races (c.1868-69). (Wolohojian & Dunn 2023, p.277)
Degar by Manet: he depicts him in the corner of The Races in the Bois de Boulogne (1872).
edges.feuds: among other conflicts, Degas painted Monsieur et Madame Édouard Manet (1869) and Manet disliked how his wife was depicted, so he cut out her face. This enraged Degas, who complained to Ambroise Vollard about it, and returned to Manet a painting by him that he owned. A few months later they 'patched things up', as expressed by Berthe Morisot's mother (Wolohojian & Dunn 2023, p.279).
correspondence: 1868, 29 July, Manet to Degas: he invites Degas to join him in a trip to England. He also asks him to persuade Fantin-Latour to join. Sends regards to Duranty, Fantin-Latour and Zola. Degas would not join.
1869, 27 May: Manet writes to Degas asking about his father's gatherings.
mentions: 1868, 10 Aug, letter from Manet to Fantin-Latour: 'De Gas was really silly not to have come with me [to the trip to England]'.

1868, 26 Aug, letter from Manet to Fantin-Latour: 'I envy your being able to discuss with that famous aesthetician Degas the question of whether or not it is advisable to put art within reach of the lower classes, by turning out pictures for sixpence apiece'. And 'Tell Degas it's about time he wrote to me, I gather form Duranty he's becoming a painter of high life; why not? It's too bad he didn't come to London, those well-trained horses would have inspired a few pictures' (Wolohojian & Dunn 2023, p.279).

1871, 5 June, Mme Morisot to Berthe: '[Your brother] as met two Communards, at this moment when they are all being shot... Manet and Degas! Even at this stage they are condemning the drastic measures used to repress them. I think they are insane, don't you?' (Wolohojian & Dunn 2023, p.281; Rouart 1959, p.73).
1872, 19 Nov, letter from Degas to Tissot: 'I haven't yet written to Manet and of course he hasn't sent me a note either'.

1872, 5 Dec, letter from Degas to Henri Rouart: 'Manet would see here more beautiful things than I have. But he wouldn't do any more than I have. We only give love and art to what we are used to. The new captivates and bores in turn' (Wolohojian & Dunn 2023, p.281; Reff 2020, letter 31, vol.1, p.172, vol.3, p.27).

1874, March, letter to Bracquemond (about the organisation of the 1st exhibition of the Société Anonyme des Artistes): 'Because of Fantin's influence and some self-induced panic, Manet still refuses to join us; but nothing seems to be definitive on this matter yet' (Wolohojian & Dunn 2023, p.282; Reff 2020, letter 41, vol.1, p.189, vol.3, p.33).

1874 letter from Degas to Tissot: 'There needs to be a realist Salon. Manet doesn't understand that. I believe him to be definitely more vain than intelligent' (Manet continues to exhibit at the official Salon despite multiple rejections) (Reff 2020, letter 40, vol.1, p.129, vol.3, p.32).
1875 at the inauguration of the Paris Opéra, Manet declares 'Why, it is Degas who should have painted the foyer of the Opéra' (Proust 1913, p.96).

1876 Georges Rivière: 'There were often many of us at the Nouvelles-Athènes, Manet, smiling, elegant, looking very young (...); Degas, with the profile of a bourgeois..., arrived well-equipped with cruel comments about his contemporaries' (Wolohojian & Dunn 2023, p.283; Rivière 1921, p.26).
1876 both artists are praised in Mallarmé's The Impressionists and Édouard Manet.
1880 Manet's exhibition at Galerie La Vie Moderne: Degas states 'he is better known than Garibaldi' ('Chronique: Exposition d'œuvres nouvelles de M. Édouard Manet', Le Temps, 10 April 1880, p.2).
1882 Degas to Henri Rouart: 'Manet stupid and shrewd, a blank playing card, Spanish trompe l'œil, painter' (Reff 2020, letter 170, vol.1, p.301, vol.3, p.68).
1883 at Manet's funeral, Degas states: 'He was greater than we thought'.

1885 Berthe Morisot on her notebook: 'Degas said that the study of nature was unimportant, painting being an art of convention...; that Edouard himself, although he boasted about slavishly copying nature, was the most mannered painter in the world, never making a brushstroke without thinking of the (old) masters' (Patry 2019, p.256).
1888 Degas hands Manet's Pear next to Ingres's Jupiter in his collection. He says to George Moore: 'I put it there, for a pear painted like that would overthrow any god' (Moore 1911, vol.3, p.149).
1895 Berthe Morisot on the eve of her death, to her daughter Julie Manet: 'Tell M. Degas that if he founds a museum he should select a Manet' (Rouart 1959, p.212).

1897 Degas reacted to Proust's book on Manet: 'That Manet! As soon as I did dancers, he did them... he always imitated. (...) He could never do anything except imitate' (Halévy 1960, pp.104-5, 110-11).

1904 Valéry says that Degas remembers Manet 'with a mixture of admiration, amotion, and real nastiness. A mixture so deep and natural, so true in its ocloring pleases me' (Reff 2020, letter 170, note 9, vol.1, p.301).
interactions: 'Manet and Degas belonged to the same interconnected circles of friends. They attend the soirées hosted by the Morisots and by Alfred Stevens and his wife; Degas takes part in Manet's mother's Thursday salons; and Manet is a regular at Degas's father's gatherings' (Wolohojian & Dunn 2023, p.280).
1869, July-Aug: Degas visits Manet in Boulogne-sur-Mer.

1870 they are drafted during the Franco-Prussian war (National Guard). They are both under the orders of Ernest Meissonier, and they join the artillery. They have a conflict about the defence strategy of Paris. 'Degas and I are in the artillery, volunteer gunners' (Wolohojian & Dunn 2023, p.281; Rodary 2014, p.70).
1871, 30 Sept: Degas visits Manet's atelier.
1880 they attend Edmond Duranty's funeral.
1880 they attend Alphonse Maureau's funeral.
edges.collection: Degas acquired 3 artworks by Manet in 1884, as well as Woman with a Cigarette (c.1878-80) in 1896.
edges.bibliography: Fayos Pérez 2024; Wolohojian & Dunn 2023; Reff 2020, The Letters of Edgar Degas; Patry 2019, Berthe Morisot; Rodary 2014, Correspondance du Siège de Paris; Gordon and Forge 1988; Rouart 1959, The Correspondence of Berthe Morisot; Rivière 1921, Renoir et ses amis; A. Proust 1913, Edouard Manet. Souvenirs; Moore 1911, Hail and Farewell!; Halévy 1960, Degas parle.

edges.relationship type: colleagues. Renoir was influenced by Manet
edges.portraits: they are both included in the group portrait in Fantin-Latour's Un atelier aux Batignolles (1870, Orsay), alongisde Zacharie Astruc, Otto Scholderer, Émile Zola, Edmond Maître, Frédéric Bazille and Claude Monet

edges.relationship type: Renoir was influenced by Delacroix, particularly in the use of colour

portraits: Bracquemond, Édouard Manet, 1864, pastel; 1867, etching (after a photograph by Godet).

They both appear in Fantin-Latour's Hommage à Delacroix (1864, Orsay), with Delacroix's portrait and depicting Fantin-Latour himself, Louis Edmond Duranty, Champfleury, Charles Baudelaire, Louis Cordier, Alphonse Legros, James Whistler, and Albert de Balleroy.
edges.collaborations: Bracquemond encourages Manet to use the printing technique. He helps Manet with his etchings of Olympia and L'Homme mort. Bracquemond also makes prints after works by Manet
edges.they share: they both appear in Fantin-Latour's Hommage à Delacroix (1864)

edges.copies: Bracquemond made a print in 1872 after Delacroix's Les Natchez (1823-24 and 1835, Metropolitan)
edges.portraits: Bracquemond appears in Fantin-Latour's Hommage à Delacroix (1864, Orsay), with Delacroix's portrait and depicting Fantin-Latour himself, Édouard Manet, Louis Edmond Duranty, Champfleury, Charles Baudelaire, Louis Cordier, Alphonse Legros, James Whistler, and Albert de Balleroy.
Bracquemond, Théophile Gautier, 1874, etching (presented at the 1st Exposition des peintres impressionnistes)
edges.mentions: in Bracquemond's first participation at the Salon, in 1852, Gautier compared his Portrait de ma grand-mère to Hans Holbein the Younger

portraits: Bracquemond, portrait of Baudelaire, etching, 1861 (BM 1865,1209.693): intended for the 2nd edition of Fleurs du Mal.

They both appear in Fantin-Latour's Hommage à Delacroix (1864, Orsay), alongside Fantin-Latour himself, Édouard Manet, Louis Edmond Duranty, Champfleury, Louis Cordier, Alphonse Legros, James Whistler, and Albert de Balleroy.
Bracquemond, portrait of Baudelaire, etching, 1874 (presented at the 1st Exposition des peintres impressionnistes).

edges.mentions: at the Salon of 1870, Gautier praises Regnault's Juan Prim. 8 octobre 1868 (1869, Orsay) and Salomé (1870, Metropolitan): 'Prim c'est toute l'Espagne, Salomé c'est tout l'Orient'
link to Goya's work: In 1870-71, Gautier wants to see Burty’s working-proof set of Disasters of War, probably to write his necrological piece on Regnault. Asselineau to Burty: 'Gautier has the pressing need to re-examine the Disasters of War (Goya’s invasion) whose copper plates were brought back by Dauzats' (Fayos Pérez 2024, p.54; Delesalle 1983, p.104)

2 February 1871, ‘Henri Regnault’, Journal Officiel de la République Française, 33, pp.65–66: Gautier tells about a meeting with Regnault where they talked about Goya and they looked at Burty's working-proof set of Disasters of War. Gautier's piece becomes focused on describing different plates from the series. 'La conversation s’engagea. On parla de l’Espagne et du Maroc. […] Après divers détours, la conversation en vint sur Goya. Nous avions précisément à la maison un superbe exemplaire des Estragos y desastres de la guerra, que nous avait prêté Ph. Burty, qui possède toutes les belles choses “dans le meilleur état”' (Fayos Pérez 2024, Appendix III, p.371). Gautier's piece on Regnault was then included in Tableaux de siège. Paris, 1870-1871, 1871

edges.link to Goya's work: in 1870-71, Gautier wants to see Burty’s working-proof set of Disasters of War, probably to write his necrological piece on Regnault. Asselineau to Burty: 'Gautier has the pressing need to re-examine the Disasters of War (Goya’s invasion) whose copper plates were brought back by Dauzats' (Fayos Pérez 2024, p.54; Delesalle 1983, p.104)

edges.they met: Marcello meets Regnault and Georges Clarin in Spain in 1868 (during the Revolution)

edges.link to Goya's work: 2 February 1871, ‘Henri Regnault’, Journal Officiel de la République Française, 33, pp.65–66: Théophile Gautier tells about a meeting with Regnault where they talked about Goya and they looked at Burty's working-proof set of Disasters of War. Gautier's piece becomes focused on describing different plates from the series. 'La conversation s’engagea. On parla de l’Espagne et du Maroc. […] Après divers détours, la conversation en vint sur Goya. Nous avions précisément à la maison un superbe exemplaire des Estragos y desastres de la guerra, que nous avait prêté Ph. Burty, qui possède toutes les belles choses “dans le meilleur état”' (Fayos Pérez 2024, Appendix III, p.371)

edges.interactions: Asselineau would support Baudelaire with the publication of Les Fleurs du Mal (1857)
edges.portraits: Baudelaire makes a pen portrait of Asselineau in 1850
edges.collaborations: Asselineau writes Baudelaire's first biography: Charles Baudelaire, sa vie et son œuvre (1869)
edges.bibliography: Jacques Crépet et Claude Pichois, Baudelaire et Asselineau, textes recueillis et commentés, Nizet, 1953

edges.collaborations: Asselineau produced lithographs for Jenaro Pérez Villaamil's España artística y monumental (1842-44).
Santa Cruz introduced Pérez Villaamil to Isabel II in 1844

edges.employment/patronage: Pérez Villaamil became honorary Pintor de cámara of Isabel II in 1840

edges.collaborations: 1828-31 Motte made lithographs after Asselineau's drawings in Vues pittoresques des châteaux de France: 'Château de Chantilly', 'Château de Morfontaine', 'Grand Trianon Versailles', 'Château de la Bourgonière', among others.

1829-1836 Asselineau was hired by José Madrazo at the Real Establecimiento Litográfico in Madrid to produce landscapes and 'views'. Asselineau worked translating into the lithographic stone most of the prints in Colección de vistas de sitios reales and the paintings in Colección litográfica de los cuadros del rey de España (BMP 18.148-18.450) (Vega 1992, pp.11-12).
edges.bibliography: Jesusa Vega, Museo del Prado, Catálogo de Estampas, 1992; Journal de Rouen, 27 March 1889, p.2.

edges.correspondence: 'Mon cher Burty, Gautier a l'impérieux besoin de revoir les Malheurs de la guerre (l'invansion de Goya) dont les cuivres ont été rapportés par Dauzats. Sous quelle forme pourriez-vous les lui communiquer pendant quelques heures ? Votre Charles Asselineau. À jeudi, Gautier demeure 12 rue de Beaune' [Sept 1870-March 1871]. Gautier probably wanted to look at the Disasters of War in order to write his nechrological piece on Regnault (Fayos Pérez 2024, p.54; Delesalle 1982, p.104)
edges.bibliography: Fayos Pérez 2024; Delesalle, 'Théophile et les Desastres de la guerre de Goya (A propos d'un billet de Charles Asselineau à Philippe Burty), 1982'

edges.collaborations: Burty had several prints by Bracquemond in his collection. They also collaborated in articles in the Gazette des Beaux-arts

edges.they met: on 12 November 1859, Carderera shows Bracquemond some Goya drawings: 'I ran into the engraver who etched my drawing of Don Quixote. I showed him the rest' (Lanzarote Guiral 2016, p.430)
edges.link to Goya's work: in order to copy Goya's drawing (Don Quixote) for the article, Bracquemond must have seen this work from Carderera's collection in Paris prior to 1860.
edges.collaborations: Bracquemond made a print after Goya to illustrate Carderera's first article in the Gazette des Beaux-arts in 1860: Don Quixote after drawing F.54 (Fayos Pérez 2024, pp. 43, 164, fig.II.42)

edges.link to Goya's work: in order to copy Goya's drawing (Scène espagnole) for the article, Jacquemart must have seen this work from Carderera's collection in Paris prior to 1863.
edges.collaborations: in 1863, Jacquemart made an illustration for Carderera's 2nd article in the Gazette des beaux-arts: Scène espagnole (Fayos Pérez 2024, fig.II.44); re-printed 1 July 1870. This print is either a pastiche after Capricho 17, 'Bien tirada está<>/i>, or a print after a lost drawing from the Carderera collection; it is mentioned by Gustave Brunet in his 1865 book.

edges.collection: Burty's collections included works by Jacquemart

edges.copies: Bracquemond made a print after Goya to illustrate Carderera's first article in the Gazette des Beaux-arts in 1860: Don Quixote after drawing F.54. He knew Goya's drawing via Carderera (Fayos Pérez 2024, p.164, fig.II.41)

edges.collaborations: at the Gazette des Beaux-arts c.1859-1861.
interactions: 1859, 15 Oct: Blanc asks Carderera to collaborate in the Gazette des Beaux-arts. They are with Aznárez. Carderera shows him Goya works (prints? drawings?) (Lanzarote Guiral 2016, p.411).
1859, 3 Nov: Carderera gives Blanc 'some Goyas' and 'lent him two original drawings, etc.' (LG 2016, p.424).
1861, 20 Sept: they meet (LG 2016, p.500)
1861, 2 Oct: they meet. Carderera asks Blanc for his small portrait of/by Goya ('retratito de Goya'). He tells Blanc and Houssaye about 'the article of Goya given to Burty' (LG 2016, p.508)
1861, 7 Oct: they meet (LG 2016, p.511)

1861, 9 Oct (Paris): Carderera takes a 'package of Goyas for Charles Blanc' to the Gazette's offices ('omé paquete de goyas para Charles Blanc, que entregué en el bureau de la Gaceta') (LG 2016, p.513)
edges.link to Goya's work: Carderera gives/sells Goya prints to Blanc (Paris, 1861).
edges.bibliography: Fayos Pérez 2025-2026 (upcoming); Fayos Pérez 2024; Lanzarote Guiral 2016

edges.mentions: Brunet mentions Carderera in his 1865 Goya book: his Goya collection of prints and drawings and his articles in the Gazette des Beaux-arts (pp.8, 9, 13-15, 20-25, 27, 28, 30, 62, 63).
edges.shared: correspondence. 1863-XI-5 (Carderera archive): mentions Goya's Caprichos, Tauromaquia, 'Scènes d'invasion' (Disasters of War) and 'Sueños o Proverbios' (Disparates) (Fayos Pérez 2020, pp.1052-53, 1055)

edges.mentions: Brunet plagiarised Montgolfier's 1831 article on Goya in 1855 (‘Bulletin bibliographique’, Revue Universelle des Arts, vol.1, pp.384–86)
Brunet acknowledges Gautier's essay on Goya (L’Artiste, 1845) in his 1855 article (‘Bulletin bibliographique’, Revue Universelle des Arts, vol.1, pp.384–86)

1861, 2 Oct (Paris): Blanc and Houssaye gave Carderera the 'entregas' from the Gazette des Beaux-arts. Carderera writes: 'I warned them about the article of Goya given to Burty, etc.' (Lanzarote Guiral 2016, p.508).

edges.they met: 22 Nov 1842 (diary): Carderera reviews with Piot his notes on Goya (Lanzarote Guiral 2016, p.167); 24 Sept 1855: Carderera visits Piot's house (ibid. p.565); 13 July 1861 Carderera shows Piot his drawings and Goyas'; 2 Aug 1861 Carderera gives Piot the copies explanation of Goya (Prado commentaries) (ibid. p.454, 462; they also meet other times 1861: pp.453, 459, 464)

edges.mentions: Yriarte acknowledges Carderera, Zarco del Valle, Fco Zapater and Lefort ('nous ont aidé de leurs lumières et de leurs documents), 1867, Avant-propos
Gautier writes a review of Yriarte's 1867 book on Goya: 'Goya, par Charles Yriarte', Le Monde Illustré, 27 April 1867, pp.261-62 (see Fayos Pérez 2024, Appendix II)
Manet partly discovers Goya thanks to Yriarte's book on Goya, published in April 1867, which had 50 prints after Goya, including The 3rd of May 1808 and the Majas at the balcony
Yriarte writes a review of Brunet's 1865 book on Goya. He is disappointed at the fact that Brunet only wrote about Goya's prints

edges.collaborations: during his mission to acquire artworks for the Galerie espagnole in 1835-36, Taylor y assisted by Dauzats and Blanchard, and also by the Madrazo family and Carderera
they met: 1837-X-2 Carderera offers Taylor to sell 2 Morales paintings, via Federico Madrazo (letter from Federico Madrazo to Baron Taylor, Bordeaux, 2 Oct 1837: Lanzarote Guiral 2016 p. XXIII; Porée 1907, p.296)
1841-V-5, Paris: Taylor invites him to the Comédie Française (Lanzarote Guiral 2016, p.XLIX, p.11); 1841 V 7, 9, 21; 1841 XI 21 (he introduces Ferdinand Denis); 1841 XII 19

1842 I 2, 5-7, 13, 17; 1842 IV 10; 1842 VIII 28; 1842 IX 11, 24, 28 (Taylor was 'catequizándome para que le vendiese mis dibujos y escritos' [Lanzarote Guiral 2016, p.XXXI]), 30 (Baron Taylor sees a portrait); 1842-XI-27
1845-V-6; 1845 X 12 (sees a Velázquez portrait 'in Vienna'); 1845 XI 12, 14, 15

edges.collaborations: Carderera published his first article on Goya in 1835 in El Artista, founded by Madrazo and Ochoa.

edges.collaborations: Carderera published his first article on Goya in 1835 in El Artista, founded by Madrazo and Ochoa.
they met: On many occasions. Some of them are:
In Paris in 1855: 5, 9, 16, 19, 21 and 29 September, 11, 17, 19 October, 11 and 27 November.
1861 they both participate in the Artistic Conference (Congreso Artístico) in Amberes.
19 Aug 1861 (Paris), with Baron Taylor and Eugenio Ochoa

edges.bibliography: Lanzarote Guiral 2016, pp.XXIII, 558; Díez 1994, no.528, pp.988-89.

edges.they meet: during the Madrazo brothers' trip to Paris in 1855 (4 September and other dates).

edges.relationship type: writes bout Goya; collector of his prints and drawings; acts as intermediary to buy/sell his works; disseminates Goya's prints and drawings in France from the 1830s

edges.collaborations: Real Establecimiento Litográfico. Madrazo hired Blanchard to make lithographic reproductions at the Real Museo in Madrid
during his mission to acquire artworks for the Galerie espagnole in 1835-36, Taylor y assisted by Dauzats and Blanchard, and also by the Madrazo family and Carderera

edges.portraits: 1833 (Madrazo portrays Taylor)

collaborations: 1835-37 travelled together to Spain to acquire artworks for the Galerie espagnole
Dauzats made lithographic illustrations for several books of Baron Taylor, including Voyages pittoresques de l'ancienne France
correspondence: 1837-VII-5, Taylor to Dauzats (Paris): he laments that Dauzats's trip in Spain is not being more fruitful; 'Je désire bien vivement qu'il en soit autrement. M. Gautier vous accompagnait. Revenez très promptement. [...] Mme Nodier, Mme Ménessier et tous vos amis de l'Arsenal vous font mille compliments, ainsi que Justin et Mayer' (coll. Claude Roger-Marx) (Guinard 1967-B p.271)
1837-VII-15, Taylor to Dauzats (Paris): about Dauzats's Spanish trip

1842-II-27, Taylor to Dauzats (London): 'Je vous avais bien dit que Carderera deviendrait fou, quand il s'agirait des prix. Proposez lui 20 frs. par dessin et 5 francs pour chaque explication. Nous en prendrons pour la somme qui me conviendra' (BNF MS NA FR 23192, f.176; quoted in Luxenberg 2008, p.195, note p.162; Lanzarote Guiral 2016, p.XXXI)

they met: 1829: 'Victor Hugo lut Un duel sous Richelieu à son cénacle élargi le 10 juillet 1829 : Sainte-Beuve, Boulanger, Vigny, Dumas, Soumet, Delacroix, Taylor, Musset, Mérimée, les Devéria, les Deschamps, les Bertin, d’autres encore, ils étaient tous là, et même Balzac, qui venait de publier son premier livre sous son nom, Le Dernier Chouan, ou la Bretagne en 1800' (Hovasse 2001, p.403)

1830 Hernani: 'Hugo et Taylor, cachés dans une encoignure, assistèrent au défilé des conjurés excentriques, qui allaient à des buts élevés par des voies étroites' (Hovasse 2001, p.424; quoting Victor Hugo raconté, p.462-63)
1832 Taylor communicates Hugo the government's censorship of his play Le roi s'aume (Hovasse 2001, p.570)
edges.collaborations: as commissaire royal of the Comédie-Française, Taylor 'opened the doors' for Hugo's plays (Challamel 1885, p.153)
edges.bibliography: Hovasse 2001; Ubersfeld & Rosa (eds.), Victor Hugo raconté, 1985; Challamel 1885

edges.shared: participation in the Battle of Hernani (1830); belonging to Victor Hugo's Cénacle

mentions: In 1840, Gautier and Eugène Piot watch Hugo's Hernani in Spain, translated by Eugenio Ochoa. Gautier praises the translation.

Eugenio Ochoa criticizes Gautier: “la vergonzosa tutela literaria en que nos tienen hace tanto tiempo los novelistas de Tras-os-Montes”, y en una nota: “Así titula M. Th. Gautier su llamado Viaje a España, libro tan verídico, tan chusco como las flamantes cartas de M. Alejandro Dumas” (Eugenio Ochoa, 'Doña Blanca de Navarra, crónica del siglo XV por D. F. Navarro Villoslada, Art. II', Renacimiento, 1847, p.79) (Randolph 1966, p.55).

edges.mentions: Ochoa describes his visit to Hugo (introduced by Adrien Dauzats) in 1837: 'Un padre rodeado de sus hijos, un monarca rodeado de su corte, no reciben más señales, aquel de cariño, este de respeto, que Victor Hugo en medio de sus habituales tertulianos, la mayor parte dscípulos suyos, imitadores de sus formas literarias, exageradores de sus extravíos, fanáticos de su gloria' (among this group of followers he mentions Vacqueria, Viardot, Nodier, Féval, Lucas, Feuillet, Gautier, Houssaye: 'jóvenes poetas y novelistas en la aurora de una brillante reputación') (Romero Tobar 1997, p. 222).
edges.collaborations: in 1836, Ochoa makes the translation of Hugo's Hernani (1830; set in 16th-century Spain). It first plays in Spain on 24 August 1836 at the Teatro del Príncipe in Madrid. This translation is praised by Gautier when he sees a representation in Spain with Piot in 1840. However, Ochoa made considerable changes from the original, removing any criticism towards the Church and elements perceived as 'immoral'. He also downplayed the 'diavolical and pathetic' nature of King Carlos, who was considered a historic hero of Carlism in the conservative sectors of 1830s Spain (Wikipedia). Dengler Gassin (1991, p.338-339) argues instead that Ochoa's translation is very close to the original, althoug he discusses some differences (such as translating 'baiser' as 'hug' instead of 'kiss' and ommitting a passage from Don Carlos) and says Ochoa falls into 'self-censorship'. Avrett (1954) did think that Ochoa's translation took far too many liberties, partly due to 'deep-rooted national and racial ideologies' and Spanish prudishness (p.362).
edges.bibliography: Ozaeta 2002; Romero Tobar 1997; Dengler Gassin 1991; Avrett 1954; Ochoa, 1861, París, Londres y Madrid.

edges.collaborations: in 1828, Delacroix designs the costumes for Hugo's Amy Robsart, a play based on Walter Scott's 'Kenilworth' (1821). It premieres on 13 Feb 1828 at Odeón and it was Hugo's first play to be staged, but it closes after only one night. [Wikipedia](https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amy_Robsart_(pièce_de_théâtre)
edges.comparisons: on 4 Nov 1826 in Le Globe, the critic Dubois compares Hugo with Delacroix: 'M. Victor Hugo est en poèsie ce que M. Delacroix est en peinture : il y a toujours une grande idée, un sentiment profond sous ces traits incorrects et heurtés ; et je l'avoue, pour moi, j'aime cette vigueur jeune et âpre; j'en puis blâmer de sang-froid les œuvres, mais ces œuvres mêmes me font sortir de ce sang-froid mortel à l'art; et c'est bien là un mérite aujourd'hui' (p.186) (see Hovasse 2001, p.325, note 115)
edges.mentions: For Hugo, Delacroix 'a toutes [les qualités] moins une ; il lui manque ce qu’ont toujours cherché et trouvé les artistes suprêmes, peintres ou poètes – la beauté.' He also complains about the lack of truly beautiful women, except for the angels in Christ au Jardin des Oliviers and one of the women in Scènes des massacres de Scio. According to Hugo, Delacroix's female characters are characterised by a 'laideur exquise', such as in Femmes d'Alger (Escholier, Victor Hugo raconté par ceux qui l'ont vu, 1931, p.321).
bibliography: Hovasse 2001, p.325 (about Delacroix's work for Amy Robsart).

Baudelaire-Pichois 1976: 'Le jugement de Hugo sur les femmes de Delacroix était connu, car Baudelaire y fait allusion dans son article sur l’exposition universelle de 1855 paru dans Le Pays' (p.593). 'C’est un peu avant 1827, donc avant Les Orientales, que quelques critiques, comme Dubois dans Le Globe du 4 nov 1826, s’avisèrent de rapprocher l’art de Delacroix de celui de Hugo. 20 ans après, Charles Baudelaire s’emportait violemment contre ce parallèle ‘resté dans le domaine banal des idées convenues’ (Salon de 1846; ibid., p.430-32)
'Poésies, par M. Victor Hugo', Le Globe, 4 Nov 1826, p.186

1847, 12 Dec: Thoré mentions Ceán Bermúdez's Diccionario histórico (‘Beaux-Arts. Abolition de l’école française a Rome’, Le Constitutionnel, p.3)

edges.correspondence: May? 1864, Baudelaire to Thoré: 'M. Manet, que l’on croit fou et enragé, est simplement un homme très loyal, très simple, faisant tout ce qu’il peut pour être raisonnable, mais malheureusement marqué de romantisme depuis sa naissance. Le mot pastiche n’est pas juste. M. Manet n’a jamais vu de Goya; M. Manet n’a jamais vu de Gréco; M. Manet n’a jamais vu la galerie Pourtalès. Cela vous paraît incroyable, mais cela est vrai. Moi-même, j’ai admiré, avec stupéfaction, ces mystérieuses coïncidences. […] On lui a tant parlé de ses pastiches de Goya que, maintenant, il cherche à voir des Goya. Il est vrai qu’il a vu des Velasquez, je ne sais où' (see Baudelaire 1906, pp.361-62; Fayos Pérez 2024)

edges.mentions: Gautier praised Manet's works at the Salon of 1861: 'Il y a beaucoup de talent dans cette figure de grandeur naturelle peinte en pleine pâte, d'une brosse vaillante et d'une couleur très vraie' (Le Moniteur universal, 3 July 1861) (Tabarant 1947, p.59)
edges.portraits: Gautier is portrayed in the crowd of 1862 Music in the Tuileries (NG/Hugh Lane Gallery Dublin)

mentions: Baudelaire: 'Delacroix was passionately in love with passion, but coldly determined to express passion as clearly as possible'
Baudelaire about Delacroix's Pietà at Saint-Denys-du-Saint-Sacrement (Paris): it leaves you with 'un profond sillon de mélancolie' (Curiosités esthétiques, 1868, p.108)

Baudelaire considers Delacroix no only a 'excellent dessinateur, prodigieux coloriste, compositeur ardent et fécond, tout cela est évident', but also that he 'exprime surtout l’intime du cerveau, l’aspect étonnant des choses'. For Baudelaire, a painting by Delacroix 'c’est l’infini dans le fini' (Œuvres complètes, ed. du Seuil, 1968, p.531). He is 'le plus suggestif de tous les peintres » en traduisant « avec la couleur ce qu’on pourrait appeler l’atmosphère du drame humain' (ibid.).

Excellent dessinateur, prodigieux coloriste, compositeur ardent et fécond, tout cela est évident, tout cela a été dit. Mais d’où vient qu’il produit la sensation de nouveauté ? Que nous donne-t-il de plus que le passé ? Aussi grand que les grands, aussi habile que les habiles, pourquoi nous plaît-il davantage ? On pourrait dire que, doué d’une plus riche imagination, il exprime surtout l’intime du cerveau, l’aspect étonnant des choses, tant son ouvrage garde fidèlement la marque et l’humeur de sa conception. C’est l’infini dans le fini. C’est le rêve ! et je n’entends pas par ce mot les capharnaüms de la nuit, mais la vision produite par une intense méditation, ou, dans les cerveaux moins fertiles, par un excitant artificiel. En un mot, Eugène Delacroix peint surtout l’âme dans ses belles heures' (Salon 1859).

Baudelaire: '[…] je n’ai jamais vu de palette aussi minutieusement et aussi délicatement préparée  que celle de Delacroix. Cela ressemblait à un bouquet de fleurs savamment assorties' (Baudelaire, L’Œuvre et la vie d’Eugène Delacroix, in Œuvres complètes, II, Pléiade Gallimard, p. 748).
edges.correspondence: Delacroix to Baudelaire, about the latter's review of Delacroix's work at the Salon in 1859 (Montée au Calvaire, L'Enlèvement de Rébecca and Hamlet): 'Comment vous remercier dignement pour cette nouvelle preuve de votre amitié ? […] Vous me traitez comme on ne traite que les grands morts ; vous me faites rougir tout en me plaisant beaucoup ; nous sommes faits comme cela' (Correspondance, t.II, p.218; also in Delacroix's Journal).

edges.mentions: For Dumas, Delacroix 'voit plutôt laid que beau, mais sa laideur est toujours poétisée par un profond sentiment' (Delacroix, Journal, 1822-1863, 1980, p.385); Dumas sees in him 'un peintre dans toute la force du terme [...] plein de défauts impossibles à défendre, plein de qualités impossibles à contester' (...) 'Delacroix est un fait de guerre et un cas de guerre' (...) 'Comme Hugo en littérature, [il] ne devait avoir que des fanatiques aveugles ou des détracteurs acharnés' (ibid.).

'M. Delacroix comprend parfaitement la portée de son art, car c’est un poète en même temps qu’un homme d’exécution. Il ne fait retourner la peinture ni aux puérilités gothiques ni aux radoteries pseudo-grecques. Son style est moderne et répond à celui de Victor Hugo dans Les Orientales : c’est la même fougue et le même tempérament' ('Eugène Delacroix vu par Théophile Gautier', sur Société Théophile Gautier)
Gros about The Massacre at Chios (1824): 'a massacre of art'

edges.they shared: Desbordes-Valmore frequently attended Delphine Gay's salon

edges.relationship type: colleagues; acquaintances. Balzac admired her writing
edges.mentions: Balzac admired the spontaneity of her writing, considering it 'assemblages délicats de sonorités douces et harmonieuses et qui évoquent la vie des gens simples' (Balzac, Correspondance, t.II, p.456). In April 1834, he also wrote about her: '[...] Elle a donc conservé le souvenir d'un cœur dans lequel elle a pleinement retenti, elle et ses paroles, elle et ses poésies de tout genre, car nous sommes du même pays, Madame, du pays des larmes et de la misère. Nous sommes aussi voisins que peuvent l'être, en France, la prose et la poésie, mais je me rapproche de vous par le sentiment avec lequel je vous admire' (Roger Pierrot, La Comédie humaine, La Pléiade, t. X, Introduction et notes à 'La Recherche de l'absolu'.)
edges.collaborations: Desbordes-Valmore helped Balzac to situate his novel La Recherche de l'absolu (1834) in Douai, a city she knew well (Samuel S. de Sacy, Notes sur Jésus-Christ en Flandre, Folio Classique, 1980, p. 298).

edges.mentions: Baudelaire wrote about her in 1861 that she was 'une âme d’élite […] qui est et sera toujours un grand poète' (Baudelaire, Œuvres complètes, 1968, p.474); 'Mme Desbordes-Valmore fut femme, fut toujours femme et ne fut absolument que femme ; mais elle fut à un degré extraordinaire l’expression poétique de toutes les beautés naturelles de la femme' (Curiosités esthétiques, L'Art romantique, Classiques Garnier, 1962, p. 745).

Baudelaire dedicated his Fleurs du mal (published in 1857) to Gautier ('au poète impeccable'). However, when Baudelaire was condemned for this work, Gautier remained silent and did not defend him publicly (Les Fleurs du mal, ed. Livre de poche, p.345). Baudelaire was helped, though, by Empress Eugenia de Montijo, to reduce the fee he was sentenced to pay.

Sainte-Beuve wrote about her: 'Elle a chanté comme l'oiseau chante' (numericable.fr, Marceline Desbordes-Valmore); he defines her poetry as 'si passionnée, si tendre, et véritablement unique en notre temps' (Notice dans Marceline Desbordes-Valmore, Poésies, Paris, Charpentier, 1842, p. I.)

edges.collaborations: Frédéric Quilliet started an inventory of the Spanish royal collections in 1810, a selection of which were to be gathered at the Museo Josefino, and others at the Musée Napoleón in Paris. Goya collaborated in two of these inventories: one signed on 25 October 1810, alongside Maella and Napoli (AGP, Gobierno Intruso, caja 29, exp.no.31) (see Antigüedad del Castillo-Olivares 1987, pp.298-301); and another one in November 1810, also with Maella and Napoli (AHN, Consejos, leg.17.787). The definitive list was written in April 1813 (AASF 1-34/5) (see Antigüedad del Castillo-Olivares 1999, pp.204-306)
edges.portraits: there are no finished or known portraits by Goya of Joseph Bonaparte, but there are speculations about a couple of unfinished portraits that were later modified due to political reasons. In 2011, the Rijksmuseum published a study asserting that X-ray analysis had shown that the Portrait of Ramón Satué from 1823 had an underlying portrait of Joseph Bonaparte. See [The Guardian](https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2011/sep/20/xrays-uncover-painting-goya-masterpiece). Goya's equestrian portrait of the Duke of Wellington (1812) at Apsley House was also examined with X-ray and another underlying drawing appeared; some scholars argued it could be the portrait of Joseph Bonaparte (see Braham 1966)
edges.bibliography: Antigüedad del Castillo-Olivares 1987; Antigüedad del Castillo-Olivares 1999; Allan Braham, 'Goya's Equestrian Portrait of the Duke of Wellington', The Burlington Magazine, vol.108, no.765, December 1966, pp.618-621, [JSTOR](https://www.jstor.org/stable/875108)

edges.mentions: Champfleury (1865) compared both artists, stating they shared the 'same interior flame, same political ardour, same improvisation', both passionately fighting against tradition, 'devouring all (its) rules'. Champfleury even found certain 'physiognomic analogies' in the way they depicted the upper lip, 'bourgeois on first sight' and typical of satirists, as in Goya's self-portrait in the Caprichos (Champfleury 1885, p.57; Fayos Pérez 2024, p.133).

edges.link to Goya: Hugo discovers Goya's work probably around 1828-29, perhaps through his friend Louis Boulanger
mentions of Goya: Hugo's poem 28 in Feuilles d'Automne (1830) carries the epigraph 'Buen viage! - GOYA-', a reference to Capricho 64. The title of this poem is ‘À mes amis S.-B. et L.B.’, who probably are Charles Agustin Sainte-Beuve and Louis Boulanger.
In Rayons et les ombres (1839), Hugo compared Goya's gnomes to Rembrandt's witches and Callot's Temptation of Saint Anthony (1635).
bibliography: Assante di Panzillo 2008, p.107 (Goya's mention in Rayons et les ombres).
Jean Adhémar & Jacques Lethève, 1958, vol. 10, p.527: they highlight 'his taste for violent contrasts of shadow and light'.
Paul Guinard 1957, p.102: Goya as Hugo's 'spiritual heir' in his use of nightmarish visions and tragic imagery, as well as sensual and picaresque themes'.

Adhémar 1935, XXVII. '[Hugo] must have observed enthusiastically the witches and demons that writhe in a darkness penetrated by violent glimmers, because his vision is very close to that of Goya. These prints must have nurtured his imagination, providing him with an endlessly rich repertoire of figures and themes from which he could draw for years' (p.XXVII).
Hugo-Hetzel 1857, p.297 (Goya's mention in Rayons et les ombres).

edges.discovers Goya's works: during his childhood, through Ferdinand Guillemardet (father of his close friends Louis and Félix), who brings to France Goya's portrait (1798) and a set of the Caprichos from Spain c.1800
edges.copies after Goya: at least 42 (see Fayos Pérez 2024, Appendix III, Catalogue of Eugène Delacroix's Works after Goya's Caprichos (c.1819-1827)
edges.artworks influenced by Goya: among others, the cover of Faust (1828), based on Capricho 66
